Extempore: Without previous study or meditation; without preparation; on the spur of the moment; suddenly; extemporaneously; as, to write or speak extempore.
Edituate: To guard as a churchwarden does.
Excavator: One who, or that which, excavates or hollows out; a machine, as a dredging machine, or a tool, for excavating.
Evangelic: Belonging to, or contained in, the gospel; evangelical.
Ensis: a genus of bivalve mollusks consisting of razor clams.
Elayl: Olefiant gas or ethylene; -- so called by Berzelius from its forming an oil combining with chlorine. [Written also elayle.] See Ethylene.
Espousement: The act of espousing, or the state of being espoused.
Entoplastic: Pertaining to, or composed of, entoplasm; as, the entoplastic products of some Protozoa, or the entoplastic modification of the cell protoplasm, by which a nucleus is produced.
Elegance: The state or quality of being elegant; beauty as resulting from choice qualities and the complete absence of what deforms or impresses unpleasantly; grace given by art or practice; fine polish; refinement; -- said of manners, language, style, form, architecture, etc.
Enunciate: To utter words or syllables articulately.
Egling: The European perch when two years old.
Eightling: A compound or twin crystal made up of eight individuals.
Ectobronchium: One of the dorsal branches of the main bronchi in the lungs of birds.
Extralimitary: Being beyond the limit or bounds; as, extraliminary land.
Eyestring: The tendon by which the eye is moved.
Experiential: Derived from, or pertaining to, experience.
exponentiation: the process of raising a quantity to some assigned power.
Extrastapedial: Pertaining to a part of the columella of the ear, which, in many animals, projects beyond the connection with the stapes.
Ensky: To place in the sky or in heaven.
Elative: Raised; lifted up; -- a term applied to what is also called the absolute superlative, denoting a high or intense degree of a quality, but not excluding the idea that an equal degree may exist in other cases.
Ex officio: From office; by virtue, or as a consequence, of an office; officially.
Evolutility: The faculty possessed by all substances capable of self-nourishment of manifesting the nutritive acts by changes of form, of volume, or of structure.
Excrement: An excrescence or appendage; an outgrowth.
Enslavement: The act of reducing to slavery; state of being enslaved; bondage; servitude.
Evilly: In an evil manner; not well; ill.
Empurple: To tinge or dye of a purple color; to color with purple; to impurple.
Erector: One who, or that which, erects.
Ectoplasm: The outer transparent layer of protoplasm in a developing ovum.
Encounter: A meeting face to face; a running against; a sudden or incidental meeting; an interview.
Egilopical: Pertaining to, of the nature of, or affected with, an Ægilops, or tumor in the corner of the eye.
Engravery: The trade or work of an engraver.
Evaporation: The process by which any substance is converted from a liquid state into, and carried off in, vapor; as, the evaporation of water, of ether, of camphor.
Ephippium: A depression in the sphenoid bone; the pituitary fossa.
Eyrie: The nest of a bird of prey or other large bird that builds in a lofty place; aerie.
Enshroud: To cover with, or as with, a shroud; to shroud.
Entomostraca: One of the subclasses of Crustacea, including a large number of species, many of them minute. The group embraces several orders; as the Phyllopoda, Ostracoda, Copepoda, and Pectostraca. See Copepoda, Phyllopoda, and Cladocera.
Episternum: A median bone connected with the sternum, in many vertebrates; the interclavicle.
Elevated: Uplifted; high; lofty; also, animated; noble; as, elevated thoughts.
Etymologize: To search into the origin of words; to deduce words from their simple roots.
Escapade: The fling of a horse, or ordinary kicking back of his heels; a gambol.
Electrotype: To make facsimile plates of by the electrotype process; as, to electrotype a page of type, a book, etc. See Electrotype, n.
Eye-splice: A splice formed by bending a rope's end back, and fastening it into the rope, forming a loop or eye. See Illust. under Splice.
Exultant: Inclined to exult; characterized by, or expressing, exultation; rejoicing triumphantly.
executing: putting a condemned person to death.
Elumbated: Weak or lame in the loins.
Engore: To gore; to pierce; to lacerate.
Exploder: One who or that which explodes.
Evidently: In an evident manner; clearly; plainly.
Electro-vital: Derived from, or dependent upon, vital processes; -- said of certain electric currents supposed by some physiologists to circulate in the nerves of animals.
Exclusivism: The act or practice of excluding being exclusive; exclusiveness.
Extraprofessional: Foreign to a profession; not within the ordinary limits of professional duty or business.
Epicene: Common to both sexes; -- a term applied, in grammar, to such nouns as have but one form of gender, either the masculine or feminine, to indicate animals of both sexes; as boy^s, bos, for the ox and cow; sometimes applied to eunuchs and hermaphrodites.
Elinguation: Punishment by cutting out the tongue.
Extradite: To deliver up by one government to another, as a fugitive from justice. See Extradition.
Eleatic: Of or pertaining to a certain school of Greek philosophers who taught that the only certain science is that which owes nothing to the senses, and all to the reason.
Eulytite: A mineral, consisting chiefly of the silicate of bismuth, found at Freiberg; -- called also culytine.
Excur: To run out or forth; to extend.
Enumeration: The act of enumerating, making separate mention, or recounting.
Eudipleura: The fundamental forms of organic life, that are composed of two equal and symmetrical halves.
Earthlight: The sunlight reflected from the earth to the moon, by which we see faintly, when the moon is near the sun (either before or after new moon), that part of the moon's disk unillumined by direct sunlight, or “the old moon in the arms of the new.”
Expertness: Skill derived from practice; readiness; as, expertness in seamanship, or in reasoning.
Elzevir: Applied to books or editions (esp. of the Greek New Testament and the classics) printed and published by the Elzevir family at Amsterdam, Leyden, etc., from about 1592 to 1680; also, applied to a round open type introduced by them.
Eschatology: The doctrine of the last or final things, as death, judgment, and the events therewith connected.
Ensample: To exemplify, to show by example.
Escopet: A kind of firearm; a carbine.
Excito-nutrient: Exciting nutrition; said of the reflex influence by which the nutritional processes are either excited or modified.
Epochal: Belonging to an epoch; of the nature of an epoch.
established: brought about or set up or accepted; especially long and widely accepted; as, distrust of established authority; a team established as a member of a major league; enjoyed his prestige as an established writer; an established precedent; the established Church.  Contrasted with unestablished.
Ephemerist: One who studies the daily motions and positions of the planets.
Enlightener: One who enlightens or illuminates; one who, or that which, communicates light to the eye, or clear views to the mind.
Escheator: An officer whose duty it is to observe what escheats have taken place, and to take charge of them.
Enravishment: The state of being enravished or enraptured; ecstasy; rapture.
Ellipticity: Deviation of an ellipse or a spheroid from the form of a circle or a sphere; especially, in reference to the figure of the earth, the difference between the equatorial and polar semidiameters, divided by the equatorial; thus, the ellipticity of the earth is 1/29966.
Encephalotomy: The act or art of dissecting the brain.
existentialism: a philosophical theory or attitude having various interpretations, generally emphasising the existence of the individual as a unique agent with free will and responsibility for his or her own acts, though living in a universe devoid of any certain knowledge of right and wrong; from one's plight as a free agent with uncertain guidelines may arise feelings of anguish.   Existentialism is concerned more with concrete existence rather than abstract theories of essences; is contrasted with rationalism and empiricism; and is associated with Kierkegaard, Heidegger and Sartre, as well as others.
Exuvi\u00e6: Cast skins, shells, or coverings of animals; any parts of animals which are shed or cast off, as the skins of snakes, the shells of lobsters, etc.
Ethicist: One who is versed in ethics, or has written on ethics.
Enrobe: To invest or adorn with a robe; to attire.
experimentalism: an empirical doctrine that advocates experimental principles.
eye opener: That which makes the eyes open, as startling news or occurrence; something which causes one to suddenly understand what was not previously known.
Endognath: The inner or principal branch of the oral appendages of Crustacea. See Maxilla.
Exode: Departure; exodus; esp., the exodus of the Israelites from Egypt.
Eutrophy: Healthy nutrition; soundless as regards the nutritive functions.
Ey: An interj. of wonder or inquiry.
Erythrochroism: An unusual redness, esp. in the plumage of birds, or hair of mammals, independently of age, sex, or season.
Evil-minded: Having evil dispositions or intentions; disposed to mischief or sin; malicious; malignant; wicked.
Ecumenic: General; universal; in ecclesiastical usage, that which concerns the whole church; as, an ecumenical council.
Elect: To pick out; to select; to choose.
Extra: Something in addition to what is due, expected, or customary; esp., an added charge or fee, or something for which an additional charge is made; as, at some hotels air conditioning is an extra.
Excavation: The act of excavating, or of making hollow, by cutting, scooping, or digging out a part of a solid mass.
Epiphytic: Pertaining to, or having the nature of, an epiphyte.
Epinastic: A term applied to that phase of vegetable growth in which an organ grows more rapidly on its upper than on its under surface. See Hyponastic.
Extravagantness: The state of being extravagant or in excess; excess; extravagance.
Eugenin: A colorless, crystalline substance extracted from oil of cloves; -- called also clove camphor.
Ectasis: The lengthening of a syllable from short to long.
Engaging: Tending to draw the attention or affections; attractive; as, engaging manners or address.
Exhaustible: Capable of being exhausted, drained off, or expended.  Opposite of inexhaustible.
Elephantidae: a natural family of mammals comrising the elephants.
Electorship: The office or status of an elector.
Ectypography: A method of etching in which the design upon the plate is produced in relief.
Exorbitantly: In an exorbitant, excessive, or irregular manner; enormously.
Electro-capillary: Pert. to, or caused by, electro-capillarity.
Esloin: To remove; to banish; to withdraw; to avoid; to eloign.
Ectasia: A dilatation of a hollow organ or of a canal.
Ethic: Of, or belonging to, morals; treating of the moral feelings or duties; containing percepts of morality; moral; as, ethic discourses or epistles; an ethical system; ethical philosophy.
Ecclesiarch: An official of the Eastern Church, resembling a sacrist in the Western Church.
Eradicative: A medicine that effects a radical cure.
Extraparochial: Beyond the limits of a parish.
Entocuneiform: One of the bones of the tarsus. See Cuneiform.
Envermeil: To color with, or as with, vermilion; to dye red.
eyeful: a view of something remarkable; a completely satisfying view; as much as, or more than, one would want to see; as, he got an eyeful of burnt-out buildings on his tour of the south Bronx.
Ellipsis: Omission; a figure of syntax, by which one or more words, which are obviously understood, are omitted; as, the virtues I admire, for, the virtues which I admire.
Epic: An epic or heroic poem. See Epic, a.
Enouncement: Act of enouncing; that which is enounced.
Ectropion: An unnatural eversion of the eyelids.
efficaciousness: the capacity or power to produce a desired effect.
Excandescence: A growing hot; a white or glowing heat; incandescence.
Exogyra: A genus of Cretaceous fossil shells allied to oysters.
Express: To press or squeeze out; as, to express the juice of grapes, or of apples; hence, to extort; to elicit.
Ecliptic: Pertaining to the ecliptic; as, the ecliptic way.
Earlock: A lock or curl of hair near the ear; a lovelock. See Lovelock.
Elementality: The condition of being composed of elements, or a thing so composed.
eggshake: a milkshake with egg in it.
Earthborn: Born of the earth; terrigenous; springing originally from the earth; human; having the characteristics of earthly life; as, earth-born beings.
Extendible: Capable of being extended, susceptible of being stretched, extended, enlarged, widened, or expanded.
Expulsive: Having the power of driving out or away; serving to expel.
Enoptomancy: Divination by the use of a mirror.
Electro-etching: A mode of etching upon metals by electrolytic action.
Eggnog: A drink consisting of eggs beaten up with sugar, milk, and (usually) wine or spirits.
Eelpot: A boxlike structure with funnel-shaped traps for catching eels; an eelbuck.
Expansibility: The capacity of being expanded; as, the expansibility of air.
Extramural: Outside of the walls, as of a fortified or walled city.
Ergotic: Pertaining to, or derived from, ergot; as, ergotic acid.
enervating: causing the loss of strength or vigor.
earth tones: colors like those of soil or earth; brownish-reds and browns.
Epi-: A prefix, meaning upon, beside, among, on the outside, above, over. It becomes ep-before a vowel, as in epoch, and eph-before a Greek aspirate, as in ephemeral.
Enkidu: the Sumerian legendary friend of Gilgamish.
evening-snow: small California annual (Linanthus dichotomus) with white flowers.
Enigmatic: Relating to or resembling an enigma; not easily explained or accounted for; darkly expressed; not clear to the understanding; obscure; puzzling; as, an enigmatical answer; I didn't grasp the meaning of that enigmatical comment until much later; prophetic texts so enigmatical that their meaning has been disputed for centuries.
Egghot: A kind of posset made of eggs, brandy, sugar, and ale.
Ethylate: To treat in such a way as to cause the introduction of one or more ethyl groups, C2H5-; as, to ethylate alcohol.
Ecardines: An order of Brachiopoda; the Lyopomata. See Brachiopoda.
erecting: the act of building or putting up.
Ephemera: A fever of one day's continuance only.
Elkwood: The soft, spongy wood of a species of Magnolia (M. Umbrella).
Enigmatize: To make, or talk in, enigmas; to deal in riddles.
Electrode: a conducting object by which electricity is conveyed into or from a solution or other non-metallic conducting medium; esp., the ends of the wires or conductors, leading from source of electricity, and terminating in the medium traversed by the current.
Exmoor: One of a breed of horned sheep of Devonshire, England, having white legs and face and black nostrils. They are esp. valuable for mutton.
Encense: To offer incense to or upon; to burn incense.
Expletive: A word, letter, or syllable not necessary to the sense, but inserted to fill a vacancy; an oath.
Eraser: One who, or that which, erases; esp., a sharp instrument or a piece of rubber used to erase writings, drawings, etc.
Ephyra: A stage in the development of discophorous medusæ, when they first begin to swim about after being detached from the strobila. See Strobila.
Eupittone: A yellow, crystalline substance, resembling aurin, and obtained by the oxidation of pittacal; -- called also eupittonic acid.
Esquire: To wait on as an esquire or attendant in public; to attend.
earth-god: a god of fertility and vegetation.
Enlarge: To grow large or larger; to be further extended; to expand; as, a plant enlarges by growth; an estate enlarges by good management; a volume of air enlarges by rarefaction.
Eupittonic: Pertaining to, or derived from, eupittone.
Energic: In a state of action; acting; operating.
Echiuroidea: A division of Annelida which includes the genus Echiurus and allies. They are often classed among the Gephyrea, and called the armed Gephyreans.
Explorable: That may be explored; as, an explorable region.
Electrotypy: The process of producing electrotype plates. See Note under Electrotype, n.
evening bag: a small dressy handbag,  richly decorated, carried by women for formal occasions in the evening.
Easeful: Full of ease; suitable for affording ease or rest; quiet; comfortable; restful.
Etch: To practice etching; to make etchings.
Earthen: Made of earth; made of burnt or baked clay, or other like substances; as, an earthen vessel or pipe.
Eagle: Any large, rapacious bird of the Falcon family, esp. of the genera Aquila and Haliæetus.  The eagle is remarkable for strength, size, graceful figure, keenness of vision, and extraordinary flight.  The most noted species are the golden eagle (Aquila chrysaëtus); the imperial eagle of Europe (Aquila mogilnik or Aquila imperialis); the American bald eagle (Haliæetus leucocephalus); the European sea eagle (Haliæetus albicilla); and the great harpy eagle (Thrasaetus harpyia).  The figure of the eagle, as the king of birds, is commonly used as an heraldic emblem, and also for standards and emblematic devices.  See Bald eagle, Harpy, and Golden eagle.
Egotist: One addicted to egotism; one who speaks much of himself or magnifies his own achievements or affairs.
elicited: called forth from a latent or potential state by stimulation; as, an elicited response.
Emulate: To strive to equal or to excel in qualities or actions; to imitate, with a view to equal or to outdo, to vie with; to rival; as, to emulate the good and the great.
Equipollent: Having equal power or force; equivalent.
Empower: To give authority to; to delegate power to; to commission; to authorize (having commonly a legal force); as, the Supreme Court is empowered to try and decide cases, civil or criminal; the attorney is empowered to sign an acquittance, and discharge the debtor.
Exsiccator: An apparatus for drying substances or preserving them from moisture; a desiccator; also, less frequently, an agent employed to absorb moisture, as calcium chloride, or concentrated sulphuric acid.
Equant: A circle around whose circumference a planet or the center of ann epicycle was conceived to move uniformly; -- called also eccentric equator.
Euxanthic: Having a yellow color; pertaining to, derived from, or resembling, euxanthin.
Expeditate: To deprive of the claws or the balls of the fore feet; as, to expeditate a dog that he may not chase deer.  See also declaw.
Endostyle: A fold of the endoderm, which projects into the blood cavity of ascidians. See Tunicata.
Egotism: The practice of too frequently using the word I; hence, a speaking or writing overmuch of one's self; self-exaltation; self-praise; the act or practice of magnifying one's self or parading one's own doings. The word is also used in the sense of egoism.
Eyalet: Formerly, one of the administrative divisions or provinces of the Ottoman Empire; -- now called a vilayet.
Excision: The act of excising or cutting out or off; extirpation; destruction.
Eritrea: a province of N Ethiopia on the Red Sea.
equalised: p. p. of equalise; same as equalized.
Eggar: Any bombycid moth of the genera Eriogaster and Lasiocampa; as, the oak eggar (L. roboris) of Europe.
Evectics: The branch of medical science which teaches the method of acquiring a good habit of body.
Energumen: One possessed by an evil spirit; a demoniac.
earlier: occurring at a prior time; as, on earlier occasions.
Established suit: A plain suit in which a player (or side) could, except for trumping, take tricks with all his remaining cards.
Echinoid: Of or pertaining to the Echinoidea.
equaliser: an electronic circuit which reduces frequency distortion.
Epiotic: The upper and outer element of periotic bone, -- in man forming a part of the temporal bone.
Eyre: A journey in circuit of certain judges called justices in eyre (or in itinere).
Extraneity: State of being without or beyond a thing; foreignness.
Expurgatorial: Tending or serving to expurgate; expurgatory.
empty-bellied: needing nourishment; hungry; as, empty-bellied children.
Exculpable: Capable of being exculpated; deserving exculpation.
Eyeshot: Range, reach, or glance of the eye; view; sight; as, to be out of eyeshot.
Earache: Ache or pain in the ear.
Elaborator: One who, or that which, elaborates.
Ender: One who, or that which, makes an end of something; as, the ender of my life.
Entasis: A slight convex swelling of the shaft of a column.
Entellus: An East Indian long-tailed bearded monkey (Semnopithecus entellus) regarded as sacred by the natives. It is remarkable for the caplike arrangement of the hair on the head. Called also hoonoomaun and hungoor.
Ecphoneme: A mark (!) used to indicate an exclamation.
Exalt: To raise high; to elevate; to lift up.
Efflate: To fill with breath; to puff up.
Ecphonema: A breaking out with some interjectional particle.
Economization: The act or practice of using to the best effect.
elapid: a venomous snake of the family Elapidae, including the .
Expectoration: The act of ejecting phlegm or mucus from the throat or lungs, by coughing, hawking, and spitting.
etched: Cut or impressed into a surface.
Equip: To furnish for service, or against a need or exigency; to fit out; to supply with whatever is necessary to efficient action in any way; to provide with arms or an armament, stores, munitions, rigging, etc.; -- said esp. of ships and of troops.
Ecclesiastes: One of the canonical books of the Old Testament.
Euxanthin: A yellow pigment imported from India and China. It has a strong odor, and is said to be obtained from the urine of herbivorous animals when fed on the mango.  It consists if a magnesium salt of euxanthic acid. Called also puri, purree, and Indian yellow.
Ebony: Made of ebony, or resembling ebony; black; as, an ebony countenance.
Electively: In an elective manner; by choice.
Entoprocta: A group of Bryozoa in which the anus is within the circle of tentacles. See Pedicellina.
Expressness: The state or quality of being express; definiteness.
Empyreumatic: Of or pertaining to empyreuma; as, an empyreumatic odor.
Explanatory: Serving to explain; containing explanation; as explanatory notes.
Epaule: The shoulder of a bastion, or the place where its face and flank meet and form the angle, called the angle of the shoulder.
Excreable: Capable of being discharged by spitting.
Evolution: The act of unfolding or unrolling; hence, any process of growth or development; as, the evolution of a flower from a bud, or an animal from the egg.
ergocalciferol: vitamin D2, one of the D vitamins, a group of related substances that prevent rickets.
Extirpative: Capable of rooting out, or tending to root out.
Ethnarch: The governor of a province or people.
Evolve: To become open, disclosed, or developed; to pass through a process of evolution.
Elaboration: The act or process of producing or refining with labor; improvement by successive operations; refinement.
Exhalant: Having the quality of exhaling or evaporating.
Elucidator: One who explains or elucidates; an expositor.
enlisted: designating to those members of the armed forces not commissioned as an officer; as, an enlisted man.
Emerald: Of a rich green color, like that of the emerald.
Eclegm: A medicine made by mixing oils with sirups.
Ethos: The character, sentiment, or disposition of a community or people, considered as a natural endowment; the spirit which actuates manners and customs; also, the characteristic tone or genius of an institution or social organization.
Excommunication: The act of communicating or ejecting; esp., an ecclesiastical censure whereby the person against whom it is pronounced is, for the time, cast out of the communication of the church; exclusion from fellowship in things spiritual.
Enschedule: To insert in a schedule. See Schedule.
Earthbag: A bag filled with earth, used commonly to raise or repair a parapet.
Exosculate: To kiss; especially, to kiss repeatedly or fondly.
Explicative: Serving to unfold or explain; tending to lay open to the understanding; explanatory.
Eyra: A wild cat (Felis eyra) ranging from southern Brazil to Texas. It is reddish yellow and about the size of the domestic cat, but with a more slender body and shorter legs.
expressionist: an artist who is an adherent of expressionism.
Epistolic: Pertaining to letters or epistles; in the form or style of letters; epistolary.
Excommune: To exclude from participation in; to excommunicate.
enterobacterium: one of the enterobacteria; a member of the family Enterobacteriaceae.
expressionism: an art movement early in the 20th century; the artist's subjective expression of inner experiences was emphasized.
Eurhipidurous: Having a fanlike tail; belonging to the Eurhipiduræ, a division of Aves which includes all living birds.
Eligibleness: The quality of being worthy or qualified to be chosen; suitableness; desirableness.
En-lil: the Sumerian god of the air, and king of the Sumerian gods.
Erratic: One who deviates from common and accepted opinions; one who is eccentric or preserve in his intellectual character.
Ecboline: An alkaloid constituting the active principle of ergot; -- so named from its power of producing abortion.
Enharbor: To find harbor or safety in; to dwell in or inhabit.
Elucidation: A making clear; the act of elucidating or that which elucidates, as an explanation, an exposition, an illustration; as, one example may serve for further elucidation of the subject.
Epsomite: Native sulphate of magnesia or Epsom salt.
Enmanch\u00e9: Resembling, or covered with, a sleeve; -- said of the chief when lines are drawn from the middle point of the upper edge upper edge to the sides.
Encyclopedist: The compiler of an encyclopedia, or one who assists in such compilation; also, one whose knowledge embraces the whole range of the sciences.
Exocarp: The outer portion of a fruit, as the flesh of a peach or the rind of an orange. See Illust. of Drupe.
\u00c9chauguette: A small chamber or place of protection for a sentinel, usually in the form of a projecting turret, or the like. See Castle.
Exodic: Conducting influences from the spinal cord outward; -- said of the motor or efferent nerves. Opposed to esodic.
Euhemerize: To interpret (mythology) on the theory of euhemerism.
Embezzle: To appropriate fraudulently to one's own use, as property intrusted to one's care; to apply to one's private uses by a breach of trust; as, to embezzle money held in trust.
Expediently: In an expedient manner; fitly; suitably; conveniently.
Enchainment: The act of enchaining, or state of being enchained.
Electioneer: To make interest for a candidate at an election; to use arts for securing the election of a candidate.
exhilarated: elated, in high spirits, and envigorated.  Opposite of dejected.
Entend: To attend to; to apply one's self to.
Essentiate: To become assimilated; to be changed into the essence.
Edifice: A building; a structure; an architectural fabric; -- chiefly applied to elegant houses, and other large buildings; as, a palace, a church, a statehouse.
Embrasure: A splay of a door or window.
Eriophyllum: a genus of hairy herbs and shrubs of Western North America.
Euclase: A brittle gem occurring in light green, transparent crystals, affording a brilliant clinodiagonal cleavage. It is a silicate of alumina and glucina.
Edulcorator: A contrivance used to supply small quantities of sweetened liquid, water, etc., to any mixture, or to test tubes, etc.; a dropping bottle.
Erectly: In an erect manner or posture.
Expiring: Breathing out air from the lungs; emitting fluid or volatile matter; exhaling; breathing the last breath; dying; ending; terminating.
Erasement: The act of erasing; a rubbing out; expunction; obliteration.
extroversion: The condition of being turned wrong side out; as, extroversion of the bladder.
Ebola virus: an exceptionally virulent hemorrhaic virus with a high mortality rate, first recognized in an outbreak on the Ebola river in africa.
Exculpatory: Clearing, or tending to clear, from alleged fault or guilt; excusing.
Embolismal: Pertaining to embolism; intercalary; as, embolismal months.
Eumenides: A euphemistic name for the Furies of Erinyes.
extrovert: A person who is extroverted; a person who is marked by an interest in others or concerned primarily with external reality.  Contrasted with introvert.
Enigmatography: The art of making or of solving enigmas.
Expansion: The act of expanding or spreading out; the condition of being expanded; dilation; enlargement.
Endermically: By the endermic method; as, applied endermically.
egg beater: a small device having one or usually two blades, each having several stiff oval wires at the tip.  The blades are swirled or rotated for beating eggs or whipping cream.  The electrical variety typically have two such blades, which are arranged so that the tips of the blades interlace while rotating.
Epicleidium: A projection, formed by a separate ossification, at the scapular end of the clavicle of many birds.
Eritrean: of or pertaining to Eritrea; as, Eritrean civil war.
Equipedal: Equal-footed; having the pairs of feet equal.
Expiatory: Having power, or intended, to make expiation; atoning; as, an expiatory sacrifice.
Enantiosis: A figure of speech by which what is to be understood affirmatively is stated negatively, and the contrary; affirmation by contraries.
Epigrammatically: In the way of epigram; in an epigrammatic style.
Extension: The act of extending or the state of being extended; a stretching out; enlargement in breadth or continuation of length; increase; augmentation; expansion.
Estrade: A portion of the floor of a room raised above the general level, as a place for a bed or a throne; a platform; a dais.
Exoskeletal: Pertaining to the exoskeleton; as exoskeletal muscles.
Enroll: To insert in a roil; to register or enter in a list or catalogue or on rolls of court; hence, to record; to insert in records; to leave in writing; as, to enroll men for service; to enroll a decree or a law; also, reflexively, to enlist.
enclosing: the act of surrounding something with something else, so that it is inside the surrounding object.
Enhydrous: Having water within; containing fluid drops; -- said of certain crystals.
Emydea: A group of chelonians which comprises many species of fresh-water tortoises and terrapins.
Exquisite: One who manifests an exquisite attention to external appearance; one who is overnice in dress or ornament; a fop; a dandy.
Euchymy: A good state of the blood and other fluids of the body.
ecliptic: A great circle of the celestial sphere, making an angle with the equinoctial of about 23° 28'. It is the apparent path of the sun, or the real path of the earth as seen from the sun.
Entomologize: To collect specimens in the study of entomology.
Equivalue: To put an equal value upon; to put (something) on a par with another thing.
Epitomize: To make an epitome of; to shorten or abridge, as a writing or discourse; to reduce within a smaller space; as, to epitomize the works of Justin.
Eyelet: A small hole or perforation to receive a cord or fastener, as in garments, sails, etc.
Erode: To eat into or away; to corrode; as, canker erodes the flesh.
Egg: To urge on; to instigate; to incite&unr_;
Everliving: Living always; immoral; eternal; as, the everliving God.
Epispermic: Pertaining, or belonging, to the episperm, or covering of a seed.
Embouchure: The mouth of a river; also, the mouth of a cannon.
Explicable: Capable of being explicated; that may be explained or accounted for; admitting explanation.
Expostulation: The act of expostulating or reasoning with a person in opposition to some impropriety of conduct; remonstrance; earnest and kindly protest; dissuasion.
Eyestalk: One of the movable peduncles which, in the decapod Crustacea, bear the eyes at the tip.
Ethenic: Pertaining to, derived from. or resembling, ethene or ethylene; as, ethenic ether.
expurgated: having material deleted; -- of books; as, at that time even Shakespeare was considered dangerous except in the expurgated versions.
Ecce homo: A picture which represents the Savior as given up to the people by Pilate, and wearing a crown of thorns.
Embassy: The public function of an ambassador; the charge or business intrusted to an ambassador or to envoys; a public message to; foreign court concerning state affairs; hence, any solemn message.
E-la: Originally, the highest note in the scale of Guido; hence, proverbially, any extravagant saying.
Equestrienne: A woman skilled in equestrianism; a horsewoman.
Embase: To bring down or lower, as in position, value, etc.; to debase; to degrade; to deteriorate.
Erecto-patent: Having a position intermediate between erect and patent, or spreading.
enraged: filled with or indicating extreme anger; as, an enraged bull.
\u00c9craseur: An instrument intended to replace the knife in many operations, the parts operated on being severed by the crushing effect produced by the gradual tightening of a steel chain, so that hemorrhage rarely follows.
Exponent: A number, letter, or any quantity written on the right hand of and above another quantity, and denoting how many times the latter is repeated as a factor to produce the power indicated
Executively: In the way of executing or performing.
Exciter: One who, or that which, excites.
Exactress: A woman who is an exactor.
Ewery: An office or place of household service where the ewers were formerly kept.
Everlastingness: The state of being everlasting; endless duration; indefinite duration.
Eyot: A little island in a river or lake. See Ait.
Encenia: A festival commemorative of the founding of a city or the consecration of a church; also, the ceremonies (as at Oxford and Cambridge, England) commemorative of founders or benefactors.
Estray: Any valuable animal, not wild, found wandering from its owner; a stray.
ex-spouse: a person who was formerly a spouse.
Emication: A flying off in small particles, as heated iron or fermenting liquors; a sparkling; scintillation.
Egophony: The sound of a patient's voice so modified as to resemble the bleating of a goat, heard on applying the ear to the chest in certain diseases within its cavity, as in pleurisy with effusion.
Equitant: Mounted on, or sitting upon, a horse; riding on horseback.
Expiscatory: Tending to fish out; searching out
Excitation: The act of exciting or putting in motion; the act of rousing up or awakening.
Euroclydon: A tempestuous northeast wind which blows in the Mediterranean. See Levanter.
Eurite: A compact feldspathic rock; felsite. See Felsite.
Effect: To produce, as a cause or agent; to cause to be.
Emulsify: To convert into an emulsion; to form an emulsion; to reduce from an oily substance to a milky fluid in which the fat globules are in a very finely divided state, giving it the semblance of solution; as, the pancreatic juice emulsifies the oily part of food.
-esque: A suffix of certain words from the French, Italian, and Spanish. It denotes manner or style; like; as, arabesque, after the manner of the Arabs.
Errantry: A wandering; a roving; esp., a roving in quest of adventures.
Edda: The religious or mythological book of the old Scandinavian tribes of German origin, containing two collections of Sagas (legends, myths) of the old northern gods and heroes.
Evaporometer: An instrument for ascertaining the quantity of a fluid evaporated in a given time; an atmometer.
Embolite: A mineral consisting of both the chloride and the bromide of silver.
Emphyteuticary: One who holds lands by emphyteusis.
Exossation: A depriving of bone or of fruit stones.
Expunge: To blot out, as with pen; to rub out; to efface designedly; to obliterate; to strike out wholly; as, to expunge words, lines, or sentences.
Entomophthora: the type genus of the Entomophthoraceae; fungi parasitic on insects.
Edgy: Easily irritated; sharp; as, an edgy temper.
Electro-chemistry: That branch of science which treats of the relation of electricity to chemical changes.
Embryogeny: The production and development of an embryo.
Emolument: The profit arising from office, employment, or labor; gain; compensation; advantage; perquisites, fees, or salary.
Enrapture: To transport with pleasure; to delight beyond measure; to enravish.
electroneutral: having no net electric charge; not electrified; uncharged; neutral.  Opposite of charged.
Epopt: One instructed in the mysteries of a secret system.
Enseel: To close eyes of; to seel; -- said in reference to a hawk.
Emanation: The act of flowing or proceeding from a fountain head or origin.
Earnestness: The state or quality of being earnest; intentness; anxiety.
Exaggerator: One who exaggerates; one addicted to exaggeration.
Eddy: To collect as into an eddy.
Embryonate: In the state of, or having, an embryonal.
Ecstasy: To fill ecstasy, or with rapture or enthusiasm.
Epigene: Foreign; unnatural; unusual; -- said of forms of crystals not natural to the substances in which they are found.
Enchodus: A genus of extinct Cretaceous fishes; -- so named from their spear-shaped teeth. They were allied to the pike (Esox).
Excoriation: The act of excoriating or flaying, or state of being excoriated, or stripped of the skin; abrasion.
Exhauster: One who, or that which, exhausts or draws out.
Ensphere: To place in a sphere; to envelop.
Escort: To attend with a view to guard and protect; to accompany as safeguard; to give honorable or ceremonious attendance to; -- used esp. with reference to journeys or excursions on land; as, to escort a public functionary, or a lady; to escort a baggage wagon.
Exigency: The state of being exigent; urgent or exacting want; pressing necessity or distress; need; a case demanding immediate action, supply, or remedy; as, an unforeseen exigency.
Earthfork: A pronged fork for turning up the earth.
Exosmose: The passage of gases, vapors, or liquids through membranes or porous media from within outward, in the phenomena of osmose; -- opposed to endosmose. See Osmose.
Emphysema: A swelling produced by gas or air diffused in the cellular tissue.
Exoptile: A name given by Lestiboudois to dicotyledons; -- so called because the plumule is naked.
Endogen: A plant which increases in size by internal growth and elongation at the summit, having the wood in the form of bundles or threads, irregularly distributed throughout the whole diameter, not forming annual layers, and with no distinct pith. The leaves of the endogens have, usually, parallel veins, their flowers are mostly in three, or some multiple of three, parts, and their embryos have but a single cotyledon, with the first leaves alternate. The endogens constitute one of the great primary classes of plants, and included all palms, true lilies, grasses, rushes, orchids, the banana, pineapple, etc. See Exogen.
ergonomics: biological science applied to study the relation between workers and their environments.
Elisor: An elector or chooser; one of two persons appointed by a court to return a jury or serve a writ when the sheriff and the coroners are disqualified.
Esnecy: A prerogative given to the eldest coparcener to choose first after an inheritance is divided.
Enneapetalous: Having nine petals, or flower leaves.
Enfroward: To make froward, perverse, or ungovernable.
Enarched: Bent into a curve; -- said of a bend or other ordinary.
estimated: calculated approximately; as, an estimated mass of 25 g.
Equipage: Furniture or outfit, whether useful or ornamental; especially, the furniture and supplies of a vessel, fitting her for a voyage or for warlike purposes, or the furniture and necessaries of an army, a body of troops, or a single soldier, including whatever is necessary for efficient service; equipments; accouterments; habiliments; attire.
Etherification: The act or process of making ether; specifically, the process by which a large quantity of alcohol is transformed into ether by the agency of a small amount of sulphuric, or ethyl sulphuric, acid.
Egyptian: A native, or one of the people, of Egypt; also, the Egyptian language.
Excretin: A nonnitrogenous, crystalline body, present in small quantity in human fæces.
Ethologic: treating of, or pertaining to, ethnic or morality, or the science of character.
Emigration: The act of emigrating; removal from one country or state to another, for the purpose of residence, as from Europe to America, or, in America, from the Atlantic States to the Western.
Exauthorate: To deprive of authority or office; to depose; to discharge.
Evincive: Tending to prove; having the power to demonstrate; demonstrative; indicative.
Eliminative: Relating to, or carrying on, elimination.
Expedite: To relieve of impediments; to facilitate; to accelerate the process or progress of; to hasten; to quicken; as, to expedite the growth of plants.
\u00c9tag\u00e8re: A piece of furniture having a number of uninclosed shelves or stages, one above another, for receiving articles of elegance or use.
evangelist: A bringer of the glad tidings of Church and his doctrines.
Edible: Fit to be eaten as food; eatable; esculent; as, edible fishes.
Etymic: Relating to the etymon; as, an etymic word.
Excommunion: A shutting out from communion; excommunication.
Extremely: In an extreme manner or state; in the utmost degree; to the utmost point; exceedingly; as, extremely hot or cold.
Egoism: The doctrine of certain extreme adherents or disciples of Descartes and Johann Gottlieb Fichte, which finds all the elements of knowledge in the ego and the relations which it implies or provides for.
Extortioner: One who practices extortion; an extortionist.
Eponymist: One from whom a race, tribe, city, or the like, took its name; an eponym.
Epidotic: Related to, resembling, or containing epidote; as, an epidotic granite.
Egoist: One given overmuch to egoism or thoughts of self.
Expurgate: To purify; to clear from anything noxious, offensive, or erroneous; to cleanse; to purge; as, to expurgate a book.
Enlist: To enroll and bind one's self for military or naval service; as, he enlisted in the regular army; the men enlisted for the war.
Encore: To call for a repetition or reappearance of; as, to encore a song or a singer.
encrustment: That which is formed as a crust; incrustment; incrustation.
Enthrallment: The act of enthralling, or state of being enthralled. See Inthrallment.
Enguard: To surround as with a guard.
Electrography: The art or process of making electrographs or using an electrograph.
Enthronement: The act of enthroning, or state of being enthroned.
Experientialism: The doctrine that experience, either that of ourselves or of others, is the test or criterion of general knowledge; -- opposed to intuitionalism.
Endoparasite: Any parasite which lives in the internal organs of an animal, as the tapeworms, Trichina, etc.; -- opposed to ectoparasite. See Entozoön.
Epithite: A lazy, worthless fellow; a vagrant.
Election: The act of choosing; choice; selection.
Episperm: The skin or coat of a seed, especially the outer coat. See Testa.
Epitasis: That part which embraces the main action of a play, poem, and the like, and leads on to the catastrophe; -- opposed to protasis.
Erythrocebus: a genus of consisting of patas.
Evocation: The act of calling out or forth.
Earth-tongue: A fungus of the genus Geoglossum.
Elliptic-lanceolate: Having a form intermediate between elliptic and lanceolate.
Eventual: Coming or happening as a consequence or result; consequential.
\u00c9tui: A case for one or several small articles; esp., a box in which scissors, tweezers, and other articles of toilet or of daily use are carried.
echoing: Reflecting sounds so as to create multiple echoes; as, a hotel with echoing halls.
Exacerbate: To render more violent or bitter; to irritate; to exasperate; to imbitter, as passions or disease.
Enlistment: The act or enlisting, or the state of being enlisted; voluntary enrollment to serve as a soldier or a sailor.
Entrochal: Pertaining to, or consisting of, entrochites, or the joints of encrinites; -- used of a kind of stone or marble.
Embolus: Something inserted, as a wedge; the piston or sucker of a pump or syringe.
Extender: One who, or that which, extends or stretches anything.
Exaction: The act of demanding with authority, and compelling to pay or yield; compulsion to give or furnish; a levying by force; a driving to compliance; as, the exaction to tribute or of obedience; hence, extortion.
European: A native or an inhabitant of Europe.
Edict: A public command or ordinance by the sovereign power; the proclamation of a law made by an absolute authority, as if by the very act of announcement; a decree; as, the edicts of the Roman emperors; the edicts of the French monarch.
Exsanguinity: Privation or destitution of blood; -- opposed to plethora.
Equestrian: One who rides on horseback; a horseman; a rider.
Extend: To stretch out; to prolong in space; to carry forward or continue in length; as, to extend a line in surveying; to extend a cord across the street.
electrophoresis: the motion of charged molecules or particles in a liquid medium under the influence of an electric field; particles with a positive charge move toward the cathode and negative to the anode.
Embrown: To give a brown color to; to imbrown.
Extent: Space or degree to which a thing is extended; hence, superficies; compass; bulk; size; length; as, an extent of country or of line; extent of information or of charity.
Endlessness: The quality of being endless; perpetuity.
Emperil: To put in peril. See Imperil.
Elul: The sixth month of the Jewish year, by the sacred reckoning, or the twelfth, by the civil reckoning, corresponding nearly to the month of September.
emphatically: With emphasis; forcibly; in a striking manner or degree; preëminently; as, he emphatically denied the allegations.
Ennuy\u00e9: One who is affected with ennui.
Extine: The outer membrane of the grains of pollen of flowering plants.
Errorist: One who encourages and propagates error; one who holds to error.
Energize: To give strength or force to; to make active; to alacrify; as, to energize the will.
\u00c9pure: A draught or model from which to build; especially, one of the full size of the work to be done; a detailed drawing.
Eozo\u00f6nal: Pertaining to the eozoön; containing eozoöns; as, eozoönal limestone.
Enlivener: One who, or that which, enlivens, animates, or invigorates.
ecologist: a biologist who studies the relation between organisms and their environment.
endodontics: the branch of dentistry dealing with diseases of the dental pulp.
Eurasian: Of European and Asiatic descent; of or pertaining to both Europe and Asia; as, the great Eurasian plain.
ethal: A white waxy solid, C16H33.OH; -- called also cetyl alcohol and cetylic alcohol. See Cetylic alcohol, under Cetylic.
Erinys: An avenging deity; one of the Furies; sometimes, conscience personified.
Encamp: To form into a camp; to place in a temporary habitation, or quarters.
Expectation: The act or state of expecting or looking forward to an event as about to happen.
Excise: To cut out or off; to separate and remove; as, to excise a tumor.
Extraforaneous: Pertaining to that which is out of doors.
Engineer Corps: In the United States army, the Corps of Engineers, a corps of officers and enlisted men consisting of one band and three battalions of engineers commanded by a brigadier general, whose title is Chief of Engineers. It has charge of the construction of fortifications for land and seacoast defense, the improvement of rivers and harbors, the construction of lighthouses, etc., and, in time of war, supervises the engineering operations of the armies in the field.
Exert: To thrust forth; to emit; to push out.
Eugenol: A colorless, aromatic, liquid hydrocarbon, C10H12O2 resembling the phenols, and hence also called eugenic acid. It is found in the oils of pimento and cloves.
Expansible: Capable of being expanded or spread out widely.
eye-beaming: a radiant glance of the eye; as, he pretended profundity by eye-beamings at people.
enfranchised: endowed with the rights of citizenship especially the right to vote.
erupt: To eject something, esp. lava, water, etc., as a volcano or geyser; as, when Mount Saint Helens erupted, some people were taken by surprise.
Elohim: One of the principal names by which God is designated in the Hebrew Scriptures.
Exterritoriality: The state of being beyond the limits of a country.
Eyewitness: One who sees a thing done; one who has ocular view of anything.
Enfeebler: One who, or that which, weakens or makes feeble.
Expound: To lay open; to expose to view; to examine.
Epiglottis: A cartilaginous lidlike appendage which closes the glottis while food or drink is passing while food or drink is passing through the pharynx.
Extensionist: One who favors or advocates extension.
-ess: A suffix used to form feminine nouns; as, actress, deaconess, songstress.
Enepidermic: Applied to the skin without friction; -- said of medicines.
Ex-: A prefix from the latin preposition, ex, akin to Gr. 'ex or 'ek signifying out of, out, proceeding from.  Hence, in composition, it signifies out of, as, in exhale, exclude; off, from, or out, as in exscind; beyond, as, in excess, exceed, excel; and sometimes has a privative sense of without, as in exalbuminous, exsanguinous.  In some words, it intensifies the meaning; in others, it has little affect on the signification.  It becomes ef- before f, as in effuse.  The form e- occurs instead of ex- before b, d, g, l, m, n, r, and v, as in ebullient, emanate, enormous, etc. In words from the French it often appears as es-, sometimes as s- or é-; as, escape, scape, élite.  Ex-, prefixed to names implying office, station, condition, denotes that the person formerly held the office, or is out of the office or condition now; as, ex-president, ex-governor, ex-mayor, ex-convict. The Greek form 'ex becomes ex in English, as in exarch; 'ek becomes ec, as in eccentric.
Electro-motion: The motion of electricity or its passage from one metal to another in a voltaic circuit; mechanical action produced by means of electricity.
-est: A suffix used to form the superlative of adjectives and adverbs; as, smoothest; earl(y)iest.
Excuser: One who offers excuses or pleads in extenuation of the fault of another.
Epiglottic: Pertaining to, or connected with, the epiglottis.
Elaphe: a genus of snakes comprising the Old World and American rat snakes.
Emblossom: To cover or adorn with blossoms.
Eaglestone: A concretionary nodule of clay ironstone, of the size of a walnut or larger, so called by the ancients, who believed that the eagle transported these stones to her nest to facilitate the laying of her eggs; aëtites.
Editorship: The office or charge of an editor; care and superintendence of a publication.
Equiangular: Having equal angles; as, an equiangular figure; a square is equiangular.
Extemporaneous: Composed, performed, or uttered on the spur of the moment, or without previous study; unpremeditated; off-hand; ad-lib; extempore; extemporary; as, an extemporaneous address or production.
Exuperation: The act of rising or coming into view.
Eschar: In Ireland, one of the continuous mounds or ridges of gravelly and sandy drift which extend for many miles over the surface of the country. Similar ridges in Scotland are called kames or kams.
Epicurize: To profess or tend towards the doctrines of Epicurus.
Eligibility: The quality of being eligible; eligibleness; as, the eligibility of a candidate; the eligibility of an offer of marriage.
Exospore: The extreme outer wall of a spore; the epispore.
Electromotor: A mover or exciter of electricity; as apparatus for generating a current of electricity.
Epigynous: Adnate to the surface of the ovary, so as to be apparently inserted upon the top of it; -- said of stamens, petals, sepals, and also of the disk.
Escrow: A deed, bond, or other written engagement, delivered to a third person, to be held by him till some act is done or some condition is performed, and then to be by him delivered to the grantee.
Ectosteal: Of or pertaining to ectostosis; as, ectosteal ossification.
Embark: To go on board a vessel or a boat for a voyage; as, the troops embarked for Lisbon.
Eurotiales: an order of fungi having a closed ascocarp (cleistothecium) with the asci scattered rather than gathered into a hymenial layer.
Epicycloidal: Pertaining to the epicycloid, or having its properties.
Embrace: Intimate or close encircling with the arms; pressure to the bosom; clasp; hug.
Exuviate:
To she
[1913 Webster]d an old covering or condition preliminary to taking on a new one; to molt.
Exedra: A room in a public building, furnished with seats.
exodontics: the branch of dentistry dealing with extraction of teeth.
Eternity: Infinite duration, without beginning in the past or end in the future; also, duration without end in the future; endless time.
Encratite: One of a sect in the 2d century who abstained from marriage, wine, and animal food; -- called also Continent.
Ental: Pertaining to, or situated near, central or deep parts; inner; -- opposed to ectal.
echinocyte: a red blood cell which has become crenated.
Entremets: A side dish; a dainty or relishing dish usually eaten after the joints or principal dish; also, a sweetmeat, served with a dinner.
eukaryotic: having cells with visible nuclei surrounded by a nuclear membrane; pertaining to eukaryotes.   Contrasted with prokaryotic.
Elknut: The buffalo nut. See under Buffalo.
Ensconce: To cover or shelter, as with a sconce or fort; to place or hide securely; to conceal.
Epicardium: That part of the pericardium which forms the outer surface of the heart; the cardiac pericardium.
Ethologist: One who studies or writes upon ethology.
Erythrogranulose: A term applied by Brücke to a substance present in small amount in starch granules, colored red by iodine.
Euonymin: A principle or mixture of principles derived from Euonymus atropurpureus, or spindle tree.
earth-goddess: a goddess of fertility and vegetation.
Excarnation: The act of depriving or divesting of flesh; excarnification; -- opposed to incarnation.
Elysian: Pertaining, or the abode of the blessed after death; hence, yielding the highest pleasures; exceedingly delightful; beatific.
Evensong: A song for the evening; the evening service or form of worship (in the Church of England including vespers and compline); also, the time of evensong.
Exchange editor: An editor who inspects, and culls from, periodicals, or exchanges, for his own publication.
Eighteen: The number greater by a unit than seventeen; eighteen units or objects.
Epiplexis: A figure by which a person seeks to convince and move by an elegant kind of upbraiding.
Ex\u00e6resis: In old writers, the operations concerned in the removal of parts of the body.
Esophagus: That part of the alimentary canal between the pharynx and the stomach; the gullet. See Illust. of Digestive apparatus, under Digestive.
Eudiometric: Of or pertaining to a eudiometer; as, eudiometrical experiments or results.
Emollescence: That degree of softness in a body beginning to melt which alters its shape; the first or lowest degree of fusibility.
Espringal: An engine of war used for throwing viretons, large stones, and other missiles; a springal.
Electricity: a property of certain of the fundamental particles of which matter is composed, called also electric charge, and being of two types, designated positive and negative; the property of electric charge on a particle or physical body creates a force field which affects other particles or bodies possessing electric charge; positive charges create a repulsive force between them, and negative charges also create a repulsive force.  A positively charged body and a negatively charged body will create an attractive force between them.  The unit of electrical charge is the coulomb, and the intensity of the force field at any point is measured in volts.
Eighty: The sum of eight times ten; eighty units or objects.
Executor: One who executes or performs; a doer; as, an executor of baseness.
Eyelash: The fringe of hair that edges the eyelid; -- usually in the pl.
Enchain: To bind with a chain; to hold in chains.
Ectoblast: The outer layer of the blastoderm; the epiblast; the ectoderm.
Ebrillade: A bridle check; a jerk of one rein, given to a horse when he refuses to turn.
Epiphyllum: A genus of cactaceous plants having flattened, jointed stems, and petals united in a tube. The flowers are very showy, and several species are in cultivation.
Envie: To vie; to emulate; to strive.
Enneagon: A polygon or plane figure with nine sides and nine angles; a nonagon.
Epicycloid: A curve traced by a point in the circumference of a circle which rolls on the convex side of a fixed circle.
Early: In advance of the usual or appointed time; in good season; prior in time; among or near the first; -- opposed to late; as, the early bird; an early spring; early fruit.
Emulatively: In an emulative manner; with emulation.
Enzo\u00f6tic: Afflicting animals; -- used of a disease affecting the animals of a district. It corresponds to an endemic disease among men.
Eastern Church: That portion of the Christian church which prevails in the countries once comprised in the Eastern Roman Empire and the countries converted to Christianity by missionaries from them. Its full official title is The Orthodox Catholic Apostolic Eastern Church. It became estranged from the Western, or Roman, Church over the question of papal supremacy and the doctrine of the filioque, and a separation, begun in the latter part of the 9th century, became final in 1054. The Eastern Church consists of twelve (thirteen if the Bulgarian Church be included) mutually independent churches (including among these the Hellenic Church, or Church of Greece, and the Russian Church), using the vernacular (or some ancient form of it) in divine service and varying in many points of detail, but standing in full communion with each other and united as equals in a great federation. The highest five authorities are the patriarch of Constantinople, or ecumenical patriarch (whose position is not one of supremacy, but of precedence), the patriarch of Alexandria, the patriarch of Jerusalem, the patriarch of Antioch, and the Holy Synod of Russia. The Eastern Church accepts the first seven ecumenical councils (and is hence styled only schismatic, not heretical, by the Roman Catholic Church), has as its creed the Niceno-Constantinopolitan (without the later addition of the filioque, which, with the doctrine it represents, the church decisively rejects), baptizes infants with trine immersion, makes confirmation follow immediately upon baptism, administers the Communion in both kinds (using leavened bread) and to infants as well as adults, permits its secular clergy to marry before ordination and to keep their wives afterward, but not to marry a second time, selects its bishops from the monastic clergy only, recognizes the offices of bishop, priest, and deacon as the three necessary degrees of orders, venerates relics and icons, and has an elaborate ritual. See also Greek Church, under Greek.
Epipteric: Pertaining to a small Wormian bone sometimes present in the human skull between the parietal and the great wing of the sphenoid.
Enunciation: The act of enunciating, announcing, proclaiming, or making known; open attestation; declaration; as, the enunciation of an important truth.
efficacy: Power to produce effects; operation or energy of an agent or force; production of the effect intended; as, the efficacy of medicine in counteracting disease; the efficacy of prayer.
Episepalous: Growing on the sepals or adnate to them.
Endothecium: The inner lining of an anther cell.
Erucifrom: Having the form of a caterpillar; -- said of insect larvæ.
Exterminator: One who, or that which, exterminates.
\u00c9migr\u00e9: One of the natives of France who were opposed to the first Revolution, and who left their country in consequence.
Electrophorus: An instrument for exciting electricity, and repeating the charge indefinitely by induction, consisting of a flat cake of resin, shellac, or ebonite, upon which is placed a plate of metal.
Episcopacy: Government of the church by bishops; church government by three distinct orders of ministers -- bishops, priests, and deacons -- of whom the bishops have an authority superior and of a different kind.
Euterpe: The Muse who presided over music.
Enneahedria: A figure having nine sides; a nonagon.
Exonerative: Freeing from a burden or obligation; tending to exonerate.
Exolete: Obsolete; out of use; state; insipid.
Exsiccation: The act of operation of drying; evaporation or expulsion of moisture; state of being dried up; dryness.
Ectodermal: Of or relating to the ectoderm.
Elasticity: The quality of being elastic; the inherent property in bodies by which they recover their former figure or dimensions, after the removal of external pressure or altering force; springiness; resilience; tendency to rebound; as, the elasticity of caoutchouc; the elasticity of the air.
Eighth: The quotient of a unit divided by eight; one of eight equal parts; an eighth part.
Esteem: Estimation; opinion of merit or value; hence, valuation; reckoning; price.
Elemi: A fragrant gum resin obtained chiefly from tropical trees of the genera Amyris and Canarium. Amyris elemifera yields Mexican elemi; Canarium commune, the Manila elemi. It is used in the manufacture of varnishes, also in ointments and plasters.
Edulcorate: To render sweet; to sweeten; to free from acidity.
Encasement: The act of encasing; also, that which encases.
Effigiate: To form as an effigy; hence, to fashion; to adapt.
-escent: A suffix signifying beginning, beginning to be; as, adolescent, effervescent, etc.
Epitithides: The uppermost member of the cornice of an entablature.
Exceptious: Disposed or apt to take exceptions, or to object; captious.
Extraaxillar: Growing outside of the axils; as, an extra-axillary bud.
Epiphora: The watery eye; a disease in which the tears accumulate in the eye, and trickle over the cheek.
Exceptive: That excepts; including an exception; as, an exceptive proposition.
Electro-polar: Possessing electrical polarity; positively electrified at one end, or on one surface, and negatively at the other; -- said of a conductor.
Expatriate: To banish; to drive or force (a person) from his own country; to make an exile of.
Evagation: A wandering about; excursion; a roving.
Embossed: Formed or covered with bosses or raised figures.
Euphausiacea: an order of small, commonly luminescent crustaceans: krill.
Engrosser: One who copies a writing in large, fair characters.
Eyebolt: A bolt with a looped head, or an opening in the head.
Eburin: A composition of dust of ivory or of bone with a cement; -- used for imitations of valuable stones and in making moldings, seals, etc.
Eremitic: Of or pertaining to an eremite; hermitical; living in solitude.
Epigram: A short poem treating concisely and pointedly of a single thought or event. The modern epigram is so contrived as to surprise the reader with a witticism or ingenious turn of thought, and is often satirical in character.
ethane: A gaseous hydrocarbon, C2H6, forming a constituent of ordinary illuminating gas. It is the second member of the paraffin series, and its most important derivatives are common alcohol (ethyl alcohol), acetaldehyde, ether, and acetic acid.  Called also dimethyl.
Erianthus: a genus of reedlike grasses having spikes crowded in a panicle covered with long silky hairs.
Encompassment: The act of surrounding, or the state of being surrounded; circumvention.
eucalypt: a tree of the genus Eucalyptus.
Exhaust: The steam let out of a cylinder after it has done its work there.
Electro-gilding: The art or process of gilding copper, iron, etc., by means of voltaic electricity.
emphatic: Uttered with emphasis; made prominent and impressive by a peculiar stress of voice; laying stress; deserving of stress or emphasis; forcible; impressive; strong; as, to remonstrate in an emphatic manner; emphatic denials; an emphatic word; an emphatic tone; emphatic reasoning.
emphasise: To place emphasis on; same as emphasize.
Emu wren: A small wrenlike Australian bird (Stipiturus malachurus), having the tail feathers long and loosely barbed, like emu feathers.
Employ\u00e9: One employed by another; a clerk or workman in the service of an employer.
Ember: Making a circuit of the year of the seasons; recurring in each quarter of the year; as, ember fasts.
exodontist: a dentist specializing in the extraction of teeth.
Exocetus: A genus of fishes, including the common flying fishes. See Flying fish.
Exfoliate: To remove scales, laminæ, or splinters from the surface of.
En bloc: In a lump; as a whole; all together.
Extravaganza: A composition, as in music, or in the drama, designed to produce effect by its wild irregularity; esp., a musical caricature.
Enubilous: Free from fog, mist, or clouds; clear.
Examinable: Capable of being examined or inquired into.
Epizeuxis: A figure by which a word is repeated with vehemence or emphasis, as in the following lines: --
expropriated: taken out of the possession of another and transferred to one's own use often without permission; as, the expropriated land was developed into a public playground.
Effacement: The act if effacing; also, the result of the act.
Equipoise: Equality of weight or force; hence, equilibrium; a state in which the two ends or sides of a thing are balanced, and hence equal; state of being equally balanced; -- said of moral, political, or social interests or forces.
Earring: An ornament consisting of a ring passed through the lobe of the ear, with or without a pendant.
Ergon: Work, measured in terms of the quantity of heat to which it is equivalent.
Exploration: The act of exploring, penetrating, or ranging over for purposes of discovery, especially of geographical discovery; examination; as, the exploration of unknown countries
Electrogeny: A term sometimes applied to the effects (tetanus) produced in the muscles of the limbs, when a current of electricity is passed along the spinal cord or nerves.
Emmarble: To turn to marble; to harden.
Enlighten: To supply with light; to illuminate; as, the sun enlightens the earth.
Estonian: a native or inhabitant of Estonia.
Enravishingly: So as to throw into ecstasy.
Ectopia: A morbid displacement of parts, especially such as is congenial; as, ectopia of the heart, or of the bladder.
Ectopic: Out of place; congenitally displaced; as, an ectopic organ.
Eisteddfod: An assembly or session of the Welsh bards; an annual congress of bards, minstrels and literati of Wales, -- being a patriotic revival of the old custom.
Entirety: The state of being entire; completeness; as, entirely of interest.
En rapport: In accord, harmony, or sympathy; having a mutual, esp. a private, understanding; of a hypnotic subject, being in such a mental state as to be especially subject to the influence of a particular person or persons.
Eacles: a genus of moths including the imperial moth (Eacles imperialis).
Expiscate: To fish out; to find out by skill or laborious investigation; to search out.
Eparchy: A province, prefecture, or territory, under the jurisdiction of an eparch or governor; esp., in modern Greece, one of the larger subdivisions of a monarchy or province of the kingdom; in Russia, a diocese or archdiocese.
Ennui: A feeling of weariness and disgust; dullness and languor of spirits, arising from satiety or want of interest; tedium.
Encrinite: A fossil crinoid, esp. one belonging to, or resembling, the genus Encrinus. Sometimes used in a general sense for any crinoid.
elk: The European wild or whistling swan (Cygnus ferus).
Enteropneusta: A group of wormlike invertebrates having, along the sides of the body, branchial openings for the branchial sacs, which are formed by diverticula of the alimentary canal. Balanoglossus is the only known genus. See Illustration in Appendix.
Endenizen: To admit to the privileges of a denizen; to naturalize.
Excrescential: Pertaining to, or resembling, an excrescence.
Eristalis: A genus of dipterous insects whose young (called rat-tailed larvæ) are remarkable for their long tapering tail, which spiracles at the tip, and for their ability to live in very impure and salt waters; -- also called drone fly.
Eumycota: a division consisting of the true fungi, eukaryotic heterotrophic walled organisms distinguished from the Myxomycota (funguslike slime molds).  It comprises subdivisions Mastigomycotina; Zygomycotina; Ascomycotina; Basidiomycotina; Deuteromycotina (imperfect fungi).
Epidermis: The outer, nonsensitive layer of the skin; cuticle; scarfskin. See Dermis.
Ethiops: A black substance; -- formerly applied to various preparations of a black or very dark color.
Endearment: The act of endearing or the state of being endeared; also, that which manifests, excites, or increases, affection.
Evangelistary: A selection of passages from the Gospels, as a lesson in divine service.
Effeminacy: Characteristic quality of a woman, such as softness, luxuriousness, delicacy, or weakness, which is unbecoming a man; womanish delicacy or softness; -- used reproachfully of men.
Euchloric: Relating to, or consisting of, euchlorine; as, euchloric gas.
Emmove: To move; to rouse; to excite.
Egyptological: Of, pertaining to, or devoted to, Egyptology.
Eurafric: Of, pertaining to, or designating, the continents of Europe and Africa combined.
Esteemer: One who esteems; one who sets a high value on any thing.
Embed: To lay as in a bed; to lay in surrounding matter; to bed; as, to embed a thing in clay, mortar, or sand.
Excitable: Capable of being excited, or roused into action; susceptible of excitement; easily stirred up, or stimulated.
Epiphyllospermous: Bearing fruit on the back of the leaves, as ferns.
Exciseman: An officer who inspects and rates articles liable to excise duty.
Expander: Anything which causes expansion esp. (Mech.) a tool for stretching open or expanding a tube, etc.
Entelechy: An actuality; a conception completely actualized, in distinction from mere potential existence.
Emplastration: The act or process of grafting by inoculation; budding.
Echo: To give an echo; to resound; to be sounded back; as, the hall echoed with acclamations.
Exarchate: The office or the province of an exarch.
Exscind: To cut off; to separate or expel from union; to extirpate.
Enorthotrope: An optical toy; a card on which confused or imperfect figures are drawn, but which form to the eye regular figures when the card is rapidly revolved. See Thaumatrope.
Epilogation: A summing up in a brief account.
Exuberance: The state of being exuberant; an overflowing quantity; a copious or excessive production or supply; superabundance; richness; as, an exuberance of joy, of fancy, or of foliage.
Essenism: The doctrine or the practices of the Essenes.
Enthymematic: Pertaining to, or of the form of, an enthymeme.
Ectype: A copy, as in pottery, of an artist's original work. Hence:
Euphuize: To affect excessive refinement in language; to be overnice in expression.
Exceptioner: One who takes exceptions or makes objections.
Entracte: The interval of time which occurs between the performance of any two acts of a drama.
Enharmonically: In the enharmonic style or system; in just intonation.
Ectomere: The more transparent cells, which finally become external, in many segmenting ova, as those of mammals.
Extraction: The act of extracting, or drawing out; as, the extraction of a tooth, of a bone or an arrow from the body, of a stump from earth, of a passage from a book, of an essence or tincture.
Earthpea: A species of pea (Amphicarpæa monoica). It is a climbing leguminous plant, with hairy underground pods.
Extirpable: Capable of being extirpated or eradicated; as, an extirpable plant.
Eozo\u00f6n: A peculiar structure found in the Archæan limestones of Canada and other regions. By some geologists it is believed to be a species of gigantic Foraminifera, but others consider it a concretion, without organic structure.
Earcockle: A disease in wheat, in which the blackened and contracted grain, or ear, is filled with minute worms.
Epithelioma: A malignant growth containing epithelial cells; -- called also epithelial cancer.
Escharotic: A substance which produces an eschar; a caustic, esp., a mild caustic.
Enmarble: To make hard as marble; to harden.
Eau forte: An etching or a print from an etched plate.
Elaiodic: Derived from castor oil; ricinoleic; as, elaiodic acid.
Empasm: A perfumed powder sprinkled upon the body to mask the odor of sweat.
Ensigncy: The rank or office of an ensign.
Erythrogen: Carbon disulphide; -- so called from certain red compounds which it produces in combination with other substances.
Entomology: That part of zoölogy which treats of insects.
Embarrassment: A state of being embarrassed; perplexity; impediment to freedom of action; entanglement; hindrance; confusion or discomposure of mind, as from not knowing what to do or to say; disconcertedness.
Epitome: A work in which the contents of a former work are reduced within a smaller space by curtailment and condensation; a brief summary; an abridgement.
Equipondious: Of equal weight on both sides; balanced.
Exuviable: Capable of being cast off in the form of exuviæ.
Effascination: A charming; state of being bewitched or deluded.
Examplary: Serving for example or pattern; exemplary.
Excitability: The quality of being readily excited; proneness to be affected by exciting causes.
Excamb: To exchange; -- used with reference to transfers of land.
Euphrates: an Asia river flowing into the Persian Gulf.
Ectental: Relating to, or connected with, the two primitive germ layers, the ectoderm and ectoderm; as, the “ectental line” or line of juncture of the two layers in the segmentation of the ovum.
Enaliosauria: An extinct group of marine reptiles, embracing both the Ichthyosauria and the Plesiosauria, now regarded as distinct orders.
Emperor: The sovereign or supreme monarch of an empire; -- a title of dignity superior to that of king; as, the emperor of Germany or of Austria; the emperor or Czar of Russia.
Epispastic: An external application to the skin, which produces a puriform or serous discharge by exciting inflammation; a vesicatory.
Extrorse: Facing outwards, or away from the axis of growth; -- said esp. of anthers occupying the outer side of the filament.
Explorer: One who explores; also, an apparatus with which one explores, as a diving bell.
Evocative: Calling forth; serving to evoke; developing.
Epicarp: The external or outermost layer of a fructified or ripened ovary. See Illust. under Endocarp.
Emplead: To accuse; to indict. See Implead.
Eighteenth: The quotient of a unit divided by eighteen; one of eighteen equal parts or divisions.
Evidence: To render evident or clear; to prove; to evince; as, to evidence a fact, or the guilt of an offender.
Euornithes: The division of Aves which includes all the typical birds, or all living birds except the penguins and birds of ostrichlike form.
enterobacterial: Of or pertaining to the enterobacteria.
endogenetic: Relating to or arising from an internal process; same as endogenous.
Electricalness: The state or quality of being electrical.
Extrabranchial: Outside of the branchial arches; -- said of the cartilages thus placed in some fishes.
Earthbank: A bank or mound of earth.
Estop: To impede or bar by estoppel.
Eddy current: An induced electric current circulating wholly within a mass of metal; -- called also Foucault current.
Endosternite: The part of each apodeme derived from the intersternal membrane in Crustacea and insects.
Elohist: The writer, or one of the writers, of the passages of the Old Testament, notably those of the Pentateuch, which are characterized by the use of Elohim instead of Jehovah, as the name of the Supreme Being; -- distinguished from Jehovist.
experienced: Taught by practice or by repeated observations; skillful or wise by means of trials, use, or observation; as, an experienced physician, workman, soldier; an experienced eye.
Exportable: Suitable for exportation; as, exportable products.
Entice: To draw on, by exciting hope or desire; to allure; to attract; as, the bait enticed the fishes. Often in a bad sense: To lead astray; to induce to evil; to tempt; as, the sirens enticed them to listen.
Enliven: To give life, action, or motion to; to make vigorous or active; to excite; to quicken; as, fresh fuel enlivens a fire.
Enchannel: To make run in a channel.
Ectoprocta: An order of Bryozoa in which the anus lies outside the circle of tentacles.
Envy: To be filled with envious feelings; to regard anything with grudging and longing eyes; -- used especially with at.
Environment: Act of environing; state of being environed.
Escarpment: A steep descent or declivity; steep face or edge of a ridge; ground about a fortified place, cut away nearly vertically to prevent hostile approach. See Scarp.
Ending: Termination; concluding part; result; conclusion; destruction; death.
Enneatic: Occurring once in every nine times, days, years, etc.; every ninth.
ethanol: The organic compound C2H5.OH, the common alcohol which is the intoxicating agent in beer, wine, and other fermented and distilled liquors; called also ethyl alcohol.  It is used pure or denatured as a solvent or in medicines and colognes and cleaning solutions, or mixed in gasoline as a fuel for automobiles, and as a rocket fuel (as in the V-2 rocket).
Extirpator: One who extirpates or roots out; a destroyer.
Enervation: The act of weakening, or reducing strength.
Epitrochlea: A projection on the outer side of the distal end of the humerus; the external condyle.
Eldership: The state of being older; seniority.
Erectable: Capable of being erected; as, an erectable feather.
Euthiochroic: Pertaining to, or denoting, an acid so called.
Ecclesia: The public legislative assembly of the Athenians.
Epipetalous: Borne on the petals or corolla.
Esculic: Pertaining to, or obtained from, the horse-chestnut; as, esculic acid.
Elapine: Like or pertaining to the Elapidæ, a family of poisonous serpents, including the cobras. See Ophidia.
Ecdysis: The act of shedding, or casting off, an outer cuticular layer, as in the case of serpents, lobsters, etc.; a coming out; as, the ecdysis of the pupa from its shell; exuviation.
Empassion: To move with passion; to affect strongly. See Impassion.
Epimachus: A genus of highly ornate and brilliantly colored birds of Australia, allied to the birds of Paradise.
Equilibration: Act of keeping a balance, or state of being balanced; equipoise.
Entophytic: Of or pertaining to entophytes; as, an entophytic disease.
Epistolary: Pertaining to epistles or letters; suitable to letters and correspondence; as, an epistolary style.
Envier: One who envies; one who desires inordinately what another possesses.
Expositor: One who, or that which, expounds or explains; an expounder; a commentator.
Euchroite: A mineral occurring in transparent emerald green crystals. It is hydrous arseniate of copper.
Entanglement: State of being entangled; intricate and confused involution; that which entangles; intricacy; perplexity.
Eer: A contraction for ever. See Ever.
Exterraneous: Foreign; belonging to, or coming from, abroad.
Eel: An elongated fish of many genera and species. The common eels of Europe and America belong to the genus Anguilla. The electrical eel is a species of Gymnotus. The so called vinegar eel is a minute nematode worm. See Conger eel, Electric eel, and Gymnotus.
Enopla: One of the orders of Nemertina, characterized by the presence of a peculiar armature of spines or plates in the proboscis.
Electrizer: One who, or that which, electrizes.
Ewe: The female of the sheep, and of sheeplike animals.
