Epanorthosis: A figure by which a speaker recalls a word or words, in order to substitute something else stronger or more significant; as, Most brave!  Brave, did I say? most heroic act!
Emotional: Pertaining to, or characterized by, emotion; excitable; easily moved; sensational; as, an emotional nature.
Englishism: A quality or characteristic peculiar to the English.
evaluative: exercising or involving careful analytical evaluations.
Equirotal: Having wheels of the same size or diameter; having equal rotation.
Erythrism: A condition of excessive redness. See Erythrochroism.
Electro-positive: A body which passes to the negative pole in electrolysis.
Estuary: Belonging to, or formed in, an estuary; as, estuary strata.
Electrotypic: Pertaining to, or effected by means of, electrotypy.
Exanimate: To deprive of animation or of life.
Expedition: The quality of being expedite; efficient promptness; haste; dispatch; speed; quickness; as to carry the mail with expedition.
Enantiomorphous: Similar, but not superposable, i. e., related to each other as a right-handed to a left-handed glove; -- said of certain hemihedral crystals.
Embezzlement: The fraudulent appropriation of property by a person to whom it has been intrusted; as, the embezzlement by a clerk of his employer's money; embezzlement of public funds by the public officer having them in charge.
Enginery: The act or art of managing engines, or artillery.
Excortication: The act of stripping off bark, or the state of being thus stripped; decortication.
Elodian: One of a tribe of tortoises, including the terrapins, etc., in which the head and neck can be withdrawn.
Encompass: To circumscribe or go round so as to surround closely; to encircle; to inclose; to environ; as, a ring encompasses the finger; an army encompasses a city; a voyage encompassing the world.
Enteric: Of or pertaining to the enteron, or alimentary canal; intestinal.
Electronic: Of or pertaining to an electron or electrons; as, electronic energy.
Ectostosis: A process of bone formation in which ossification takes place in the perichondrium and either surrounds or gradually replaces the cartilage.
Encloud: To envelop in clouds; to cloud.
Epidermal: Of or pertaining to the epidermis; epidermic; cuticular.
Exoticism: The state of being exotic; also, anything foreign, as a word or idiom; an exotic.
Encroachment: The act of entering gradually or silently upon the rights or possessions of another; unlawful intrusion.
Euclidian: Related to Euclid, or to the geometry of Euclid.
Entomophthoraceae: a natural family of mostly parasitic lower fungi that typically develop in the bodies of insects.
Excommunicable: Liable or deserving to be excommunicated; making excommunication possible or proper.
Engage: To promise or pledge one's self; to enter into an obligation; to become bound; to warrant.
Europeanization: the process of becoming like the Europeans in manners or character; assimilation into European culture.
Emplecton: A kind of masonry in which the outer faces of the wall are ashlar, the space between being filled with broken stone and mortar. Cross layers of stone are interlaid as binders.
Espionage: The practice or employment of spies; the practice of watching the words and conduct of others, to make discoveries, as spies or secret emissaries; secret watching.
Eyne: Plural of eye; -- now obsolete, or used only in poetry.
Endeavorer: One who makes an effort or attempt.
encrypt: to convert ordinary language into code; to hide the meaning of a message by converting it into a form that cannot be interpreted without knowing the secret method for interpretation, called the key.
Effable: Capable of being uttered or explained; utterable.
Equisetum: A genus of vascular, cryptogamic, herbaceous plants; -- also called horsetails.
Erelong: Before the &unr_;apse of a long time; soon; -- usually separated, ere long.
Envelope: That which envelops, wraps up, encases, or surrounds; a wrapper; an inclosing cover; esp., the cover or wrapper of a document, as of a letter.
Evolvent: The involute of a curve. See Involute, and Evolute.
Egg-cup: A cup used for holding an egg, at table.
Encrinoidea: That order of the Crinoidea which includes most of the living and many fossil forms, having jointed arms around the margin of the oral disk; -- also called Brachiata and Articulata. See Illusts. under Comatula and Crinoidea.
Eventration: A tumor containing a large portion of the abdominal viscera, occasioned by relaxation of the walls of the abdomen.
Ensignship: The state or rank of an ensign.
Enravish: To transport with delight; to enrapture; to fascinate.
east-central: of a region of the U. S. generally including Kentucky and West Virginia.
Engine-sized: Sized by a machine, and not while in the pulp; -- said of paper.
Erithacus: a genus of songbirds, consisting of certain of the Old World thrushes.
Enteron: The whole alimentary, or enteric, canal.
Excursionist: One who goes on an excursion, or pleasure trip.
E: The fifth letter of the English alphabet.
Effective: That which produces a given effect; a cause.
Epistrophe: A figure in which successive clauses end with the same word or affirmation; e. g., “Are they Hebrews? so am I. Are they Israelites? so am I.”
Edit: To superintend the publication of; to revise and prepare for publication; to select, correct, arrange, etc., the matter of, for publication; as, to edit a newspaper.
Excubitorium: A gallery in a church, where persons watched all night.
Elytriform: Having the form, or structure, of an elytron.
Ecthlipsis: The dropping out or suppression from a word of a consonant, with or without a vowel.
Endoskeleton: The bony, cartilaginous, or other internal framework of an animal, as distinguished from the exoskeleton.
Epact: The moon's age at the beginning of the calendar year, or the number of days by which the last new moon has preceded the beginning of the year.
Erica: A genus of shrubby plants, including the heaths, many of them producing beautiful flowers.
Emporetic: Pertaining to an emporium; relating to merchandise.
Epenthesis: The insertion of a letter or a sound in the body of a word; as, the b in “nimble” from AS. nēmol.
-ent: An adjective suffix signifying action or being; as, corrodent, excellent, emergent, continent, quiescent. See -ant.
Eftsoon: Again; anew; a second time; at once; speedily.
Entoderm: See Endoderm, and Illust. of Blastoderm.
Ellipse: An oval or oblong figure, bounded by a regular curve, which corresponds to an oblique projection of a circle, or an oblique section of a cone through its opposite sides. The greatest diameter of the ellipse is the major axis, and the least diameter is the minor axis. See Conic section, under Conic, and cf. Focus.
Eburnean: Made of or relating to ivory.
Extensible: Capable of being extended, whether in length or breadth; susceptible of enlargement; extensible; extendible; -- the opposite of contractible or compressible.
Eurypteroidea: An extinct order of Merostomata, of which the genus Eurypterus is the type. They are found only in Paleozoic rocks.
Empearl: To form like pearls; to decorate with, or as with, pearls; to impearl.
Episcopalian: One who belongs to an episcopal church, or adheres to the episcopal form of church government and discipline; a churchman; specifically, in the United States, a member of the Protestant Episcopal Church.
Eddish: Aftermath; also, stubble and stubble field. See Arrish.
Enumerative: Counting, or reckoning up, one by one.
Ectosarc: The semisolid external layer of protoplasm in some unicellular organisms, as the amœba; ectoplasm; exoplasm.
Echometry: The art of measuring the duration of sounds or echoes.
Entitle: To give a title to; to affix to as a name or appellation; hence, also, to dignify by an honorary designation; to denominate; to call; as, to entitle a book “Commentaries;” to entitle a man “Honorable.”
Eburnation: A condition of bone cartilage occurring in certain diseases of these tissues, in which they acquire an unnatural density, and come to resemble ivory.
Endocarp: The inner layer of a ripened or fructified ovary.
edaphosaurus: an extinct heavy-bodied reptile of the late Paleozoic having a dorsal sail or crest.
euphroe: A block or long slat of wood, perforated for the passage of the crowfoot, or cords by which an awning is held up.
epistemic: of or pertaining to epistemology; as, epistemic modal.
Enode: To clear of knots; to make clear.
Evening: The latter part and close of the day, and the beginning of darkness or night; properly, the decline of the day, or of the sun.
exculpated: freed from any question of guilt; having suspicion of guilt eliminated.
Encumber: To impede the motion or action of, as with a burden; to retard with something superfluous; to weigh down; to obstruct or embarrass; as, his movements were encumbered by his mantle; his mind is encumbered with useless learning.
Exactly: In an exact manner; precisely according to a rule, standard, or fact; accurately; strictly; correctly; nicely.
Evanescence: The act or state of vanishing away; disappearance; as, the evanescence of vapor, of a dream, of earthly plans or hopes.
Eye-saint: An object of interest to the eye; one worshiped with the eyes.
Exhalable: Capable of being exhaled or evaporated.
Equitableness: The quality of being equitable, just, or impartial; as, the equitableness of a judge, a decision, or distribution of property.
emasculation: The act of depriving of virility, or the state of being so deprived; castration.
encrypted: converted into a coded form that cannot be interpreted without knowing the secret method for interpretation, called the key; -- of messages or other forms of information.
Emancipatory: Pertaining to emancipation, or tending to effect emancipation.
Euplastic: Organizable substance by which the tissues of an animal body are renewed.
Epigenesis: The theory of generation which holds that the germ is created entirely new, not merely expanded, by the procreative power of the parents. It is opposed to the theory of evolution, also to syngenesis.
Equatorial: An instrument consisting of a telescope so mounted as to have two axes of motion at right angles to each other, one of them parallel to the axis of the earth, and each carrying a graduated circle, the one for measuring declination, and the other right ascension, or the hour angle, so that the telescope may be directed, even in the daytime, to any star or other object whose right ascension and declination are known. The motion in right ascension is sometimes communicated by clockwork, so as to keep the object constantly in the field of the telescope. Called also an equatorial telescope.
encephalon: The contents of the cranium; the brain.
Extrusive: Forced out at the surface; as, extrusive rocks; -- contrasted with intrusive.
Extensiveness: The state of being extensive; wideness; largeness; extent; diffusiveness.
evangel: Good news; announcement of glad tidings; especially, the gospel, or a gospel.
Ericales: an order including the Ericaceae; Clethraceae; Diapensiaceae; Epacridaceae; Lennoaceae; Pyrolaceae; and Monotropaceae.
Extravascular: Outside the vessels; -- said of the substance of all the tissues.
Exergue: The small space beneath the base line of a subject engraved on a coin or medal. It usually contains the date, place, engraver's name, etc., or other subsidiary matter.
Endomysium: The delicate bands of connective tissue interspersed among muscular fibers.
Etacism: The pronunciation of the Greek η (eta) like the Italian e long, that is like a in the English word ate. See Itacism.
Enter-: A prefix signifying between, among, part.
Eversive: Tending to evert or overthrow; subversive; with of.
echinococcosis: infestation with echinococci (tapeworms).  An infection with the larval form is called hydatid disease.
Equisetiform: Having the form of the equisetum.
Enrichment: The act of making rich, or that which enriches; increase of value by improvements, embellishment, etc.; decoration; embellishment.
Exotic: Anything of foreign origin; something not of native growth, as a plant, a word, a custom.
Euphonium: A bass instrument of the saxhorn family.
Enfoldment: The act of infolding. See Infoldment.
Endamageable: Capable of being damaged, or injured; damageable.
Electro-chronograph: An instrument for obtaining an accurate record of the time at which any observed phenomenon occurs, or of its duration. It has an electro-magnetic register connected with a clock. See Chronograph.
Elmos fire: See Corposant; also Saint Elmo's Fire, under Saint.
Engine-type generator: A generator having its revolving part carried on the shaft of the driving engine.
Englishable: Capable of being translated into, or expressed in, English.
Eyeball: The ball or globe of the eye.
Evacuative: Serving of tending to evacuate; cathartic; purgative.
Euripus: A strait; a narrow tract of water, where the tide, or a current, flows and reflows with violence, as the ancient frith of this name between Eubœa and Bœotia. Hence, a flux and reflux.
Excusable: That may be excused, forgiven, justified, or acquitted of blame; pardonable; as, the man is excusable; an excusable action.
Exalbuminous: Having no albumen about the embryo; -- said of certain seeds.
Exenterate: To take out the bowels or entrails of; to disembowel; to eviscerate; as, exenterated fishes.
Enthusiast: One moved or actuated by enthusiasm; as: (a) One who imagines himself divinely inspired, or possessed of some special revelation; a religious madman; a fanatic. (b) One whose mind is wholly possessed and heated by what engages it; one who is influenced by a peculiar; fervor of mind; an ardent and imaginative person.
Ephemeral: Anything lasting but a day, or a brief time; an ephemeral plant, insect, etc.
Eyeleteer: A small, sharp-pointed instrument used in piercing eyelet holes; a stiletto.
Exhumation: The act of exhuming that which has been buried; as, the exhumation of a body.
extenuating: serving or tending to reduce the severity of guilt or blameworthiness; as, extenuating circumstances.
Experimentative: Experimental; of the nature of experiment.
Evacuation: The act of emptying, clearing of the contents, or discharging.
Endosmotic: Pertaining to endosmose; of the nature endosmose; osmotic.
Electropoion: An exciting and depolarizing acid solution used in certain cells or batteries, as the Grenet battery. Electropoion is best prepared by mixing one gallon of concentrated sulphuric acid diluted with three gallons of water, with a solution of six pounds of potassium bichromate in two gallons of boiling water. It should be used cold.
Exannulate: Having the sporangium destitute of a ring; -- said of certain genera of ferns.
Etesian: Periodical; annual; -- applied to winds which annually blow from the north over the Mediterranean, esp. the eastern part, for an irregular period during July and August.
Euclid: A Greek geometer of the 3d century b. c.; also, his treatise on geometry, and hence, the principles of geometry, in general.
Enthusiasm: Inspiration as if by a divine or superhuman power; ecstasy; hence, a conceit of divine possession and revelation, or of being directly subject to some divine impulse.
Eddoes: The tubers of Colocasia antiquorum. See Taro.
Embryology: The science which relates to the formation and development of the embryo in animals and plants; a study of the gradual development of the ovum until it reaches the adult stage.
Efface: To cause to disappear (as anything impresses or inscribed upon a surface) by rubbing out, striking out, etc.; to erase; to render illegible or indiscernible; as, to efface the letters on a monument, or the inscription on a coin.
educate: To bring up or guide the powers of, as a child; to develop and cultivate, whether physically, mentally, or morally, but more commonly limited to the mental activities or senses; to expand, strengthen, and discipline, as the mind, a faculty, etc.; to form and regulate the principles and character of; to prepare and fit for any calling or business by systematic instruction; to cultivate; to train; to instruct; as, to educate a child; to educate the eye or the taste.
Ecchymosis: A livid or black and blue spot, produced by the extravasation or effusion of blood into the areolar tissue from a contusion.
Escritoire: A piece of furniture used as a writing table, commonly with drawers, pigeonholes, and the like; a secretary or writing desk.
Enfetter: To bind in fetters; to enchain.
encrusted: covered with or hardened into a crust.
Earthiness: The quality or state of being earthy, or of containing earth; hence, grossness.
eveningwear: attire to wear on formal occasions in the evening.
extraterrestrial: a hypothetical form of life existing outside the Earth or its atmosphere, especially intelligent life on other planets or in other solar systems; as, what would you say to an extraterrestrial?.
Explore: To seek for or after; to strive to attain by search; to look wisely and carefully for.
Escribed: Drawn outside of; -- used to designate a circle that touches one of the sides of a given triangle, and also the other two sides produced.
Entangle: To twist or interweave in such a manner as not to be easily separated; to make tangled, confused, and intricate; as, to entangle yarn or the hair.
Eutychianism: The doctrine of Eutyches and his followers.
Equality: The condition or quality of being equal; agreement in quantity or degree as compared; likeness in bulk, value, rank, properties, etc.; as, the equality of two bodies in length or thickness; an equality of rights.
Eventuality: The coming as a consequence; contingency; also, an event which comes as a consequence.
Eparterial: Situated upon or above an artery; -- applied esp. to the branches of the bronchi given off above the point where the pulmonary artery crosses the bronchus.
Elcesaite: One of a sect of Asiatic Gnostics of the time of the Emperor Trajan.
Empyreuma: The peculiar smell and taste arising from products of decomposition of animal or vegetable substances when burnt in close vessels.
Encase: To inclose in or as if in a case. See Incase.
eye shadow: a cosmetic powder or cream of a dark tint, applied on the eyelids or just under the eyebrows to accentuate the eyes.  Compare eyeliner.
Encash: To turn into cash; to cash.
Exestuate: To be agitated; to boil up; to effervesce.
Endorhiza: Any monocotyledonous plant; -- so named because many monocotyledons have an endorhizal embryo.
Eucharist: The act of giving thanks; thanksgiving.
Enodation: The act or operation of clearing of knots, or of untying; hence, also, the solution of a difficulty.
elephant-tusk: an annual of the southern U.S. and Mexico (Proboscidea louisianica) having large whitish or yellowish flowers mottled with purple and a long curving beak.
Eumops: one of the genera of mastiff bats, of the family Molossidae.
Entropy: A certain property of a body, expressed as a measurable quantity, such that when there is no communication of heat the quantity remains constant, but when heat enters or leaves the body the quantity increases or diminishes. If a small amount, h, of heat enters the body when its temperature is t in the thermodynamic scale the entropy of the body is increased by h ÷ t. The entropy is regarded as measured from some standard temperature and pressure. Sometimes called the thermodynamic function.
Epithalamium: A nuptial song, or poem in honor of the bride and bridegroom.
Emboweler: One who takes out the bowels.
Epibolic: Growing or covering over; -- said of a kind of invagination. See under Invagination.
Epithesis: The addition of a letter at the end of a word, without changing its sense; as, numb for num, whilst for whiles.
Exemplariness: The state or quality of being exemplary; fitness to be an example.
Excretive: Having the power of excreting, or promoting excretion.
Exulceratory: Having a tendency to form ulcers; rendering ulcerous.
erudite: Characterized by extensive reading or knowledge; well instructed; learned.
eyepiece: The lens, or combination of lenses, at the eye end of a microscope, telescope or other optical instrument, through which the image formed by the mirror or object glass is viewed.
Epipleural: Arising from the pleurapophysis of a vertebra.
Enough: A sufficiency; a quantity which satisfies desire, is adequate to the want, or is equal to the power or ability; as, he had enough to do take care of himself.
Etymological: Pertaining to etymology, or the derivation of words.
Excalibur: The name of King Arthur's mythical sword.
Exanthema: An efflorescence or discoloration of the skin; an eruption or breaking out, as in measles, smallpox, scarlatina, and the like diseases; -- sometimes limited to eruptions attended with fever.
embarrassing: hard to deal with; as, greeted with an embarrassing silence.
Evincement: The act of evincing or proving, or the state of being evinced.
Enmist: To infold, as in a mist.
Exorhiza: A plant Whose radicle is not inclosed or sheathed by the cotyledons or plumule.
Especial: Distinguished among others of the same class or kind; special; concerning a species or a single object; principal; particular; as, in an especial manner or degree.
Elbowroom: Room to extend the elbows on each side; ample room for motion or action; free scope.
Exophthalmic: Of or pertaining to, or characterized by, exophthalmia.
Episcopal: Governed by bishops; as, an episcopal church.
Eardrop: A pendant for the ear; an earring; as, a pair of eardrops.
Exustion: The act or operation of burning up.
Euchite: One who resolves religion into prayer.
El\u00e6olite: A variety of hephelite, usually massive, of greasy luster, and gray to reddish color.
electrophoretic: of or pertaining to electrophoresis; electrophoretic mobility; accomplished using electrophoresis; as, electrophoretic separation; electrophoretic analysis.
Enhancer: One who enhances; one who, or that which, raises the amount, price, etc.
Estimative: Inclined, or able, to estimate; serving for, or capable of being used in, estimating.
Exaltate: Exercising its highest influence; -- said of a planet.
Entomophilous: Fertilized by the agency of insects; -- said of plants in which the pollen is carried to the stigma by insects.
Evangelistic: Pertaining to the four evangelists; designed or fitted to evangelize; evangelical; as, evangelistic efforts.
Electro-ballistics: The art or science of measuring the force or velocity of projectiles by means of electricity.
Estuate: To boil up; to swell and rage; to be agitated.
Evanid: Liable to vanish or disappear; faint; weak; evanescent; as, evanid color.
Ebracteolate: Without bracteoles, or little bracts; -- said of a pedicel or flower stalk.
Epigraphic: Of or pertaining to epigraphs or to epigraphy; as, an epigraphic style; epigraphical works or studies.
Evade: To escape; to slip away; -- sometimes with from.
elective surgery: surgery that is not essential, especially surgery to correct a condition that is not life-threatening; surgery that is not required for survival.  See also cosmetic surgery.
Extemporiness: The quality of being done or devised extempore
Encapsulation: The act of inclosing in a capsule; the growth of a membrane around (any part) so as to inclose it in a capsule.
Exect: To cut off or out. [Obs.] See Exsect.
Engorgement: The act of swallowing greedily; a devouring with voracity; a glutting.
Echopathy: A morbid condition characterized by automatic and purposeless repetition of words or imitation of actions.
Expression: The act of expressing; the act of forcing out by pressure; as, the expression of juices or oils; also, of extorting or eliciting; as, a forcible expression of truth.
Enswathe: To swathe; to envelop, as in swaddling clothes.
Elocation: A removal from the usual place of residence.
Elopement: The act of eloping; secret departure; -- said of a woman and a man, one or both, who run away from their homes for marriage or for cohabitation.
Epidemiography: A treatise upon, or history of, epidemic diseases.
Enucleation: The act of enucleating; elucidation; exposition.
Epilepsy: The “falling sickness,” so called because the patient falls suddenly to the ground; a disease characterized by paroxysms (or fits) occurring at interval and attended by sudden loss of consciousness, and convulsive motions of the muscles.
Embrocate: To moisten and rub (a diseased part) with a liquid substance, as with spirit, oil, etc., by means of a cloth or sponge.
extracellular: located or occurring outside of a living cell or cells; as, extracellular fluid.  Opposite of intracellular.
Entrepreneur: One who takes the initiative to create a product or establish a business for profit; generally, whoever undertakes on his own account an enterprise in which others are employed and risks are taken.
Empark: To make a park of; to inclose, as with a fence; to impark.
Erin: An early, and now a poetic, name of Ireland.
Elaterite: A mineral resin, of a blackish brown color, occurring in soft, flexible masses; -- called also mineral caoutchouc, and elastic bitumen.
Escalator: A stairway or incline arranged like an endless belt so that the steps or treads ascend or descend continuously, and one stepping upon it is carried up or down; -- originally a trade term, which has become the generic name for such devices.  Such devices are in common use in large retail establishments such as department stores, and in public buildings having a heavy traffic of persons between adjacent floors.
Eyereach: The range or reach of the eye; eyeshot.
el cheapo: cheap; inexpensive and of inferior quality; as, an el cheapo cigar.
Effendi: Master; sir; -- a Turkish title of respect, applied esp. to a state official or man of learning, as one learned in the law, but often simply as the courtesy title of a gentleman.
extremum: the point located farthest from the middle of something.
Esparcet: The common sainfoin (Onobrychis sativa), an Old World leguminous forage plant.
Electrolytic: Pertaining to electrolysis; as, electrolytic action.
Elephantiac: Affected with elephantiasis; characteristic of elephantiasis.
Endolymph: The watery fluid contained in the membranous labyrinth of the internal ear.
Evident: Clear to the vision; especially, clear to the understanding, and satisfactory to the judgment; as, the figure or color of a body is evident to the senses; the guilt of an offender can not always be made evident.
Enarthrosis: A ball and socket joint, or the kind of articulation represented by such a joint. See Articulation.
Exorbitant: Departing from an orbit or usual track; hence, deviating from the usual or due course; going beyond the appointed rules or established limits of right or propriety; excessive; extravagant; enormous; inordinate; as, exorbitant appetites and passions; exorbitant charges, demands, or claims.
Endosmometric: Pertaining to, or designed for, the measurement of endosmotic action.
emotionless: unsusceptible to, destitute of, or showing no emotion; unmoved by feeling.  Opposite of emotional; as, he kept his emotionless objectivity and faith in the cause he served.
Extant: Standing out or above any surface; protruded.
Elementation: Instruction in the elements or first principles.
economy: The management of domestic affairs; the regulation and government of household matters; especially as they concern expense or disbursement; as, a careful economy.
effortful: requiring great physical effort.  Opposite of effortless.
Explanate: Spreading or extending outwardly in a flat form.
Exeat: A license for absence from a college or a religious house.
epidemiologic: Connected with, or pertaining to, epidemiology; as, epidemiological studies.
Effeminately: In an effeminate or womanish manner; weakly; softly; delicately.
Execrative: A word used for cursing; an imprecatory word or expression.
expiration-dated: bearing a date after which it is no longer valid or salable; -- of a security, option, or perishable item.
Exemplification: The act of exemplifying; a showing or illustrating by example.
exhibitionist: compulsively attracting attention to oneself especially by boasting or exaggerated behavior.
Embank: To throw up a bank so as to confine or to defend; to protect by a bank of earth or stone.
Equi-: A prefix, meaning equally; as, equidistant; equiangular.
Eclogue: A pastoral poem, in which shepherds are introduced conversing with each other; a bucolic; an idyl; as, the Ecloques of Virgil, from which the modern usage of the word has been established.
Epipodial: Pertaining to the epipodialia or the parts of the limbs to which they belong.
Equivalence: To be equivalent or equal to; to counterbalance.
Exclusive: One of a coterie who exclude others; one who from real of affected fastidiousness limits his acquaintance to a select few.
Eutychian: A follower of Eutyches [5th century], who held that the divine and the human in the person of Christ were blended together as to constitute but one nature; a monophysite; -- opposed to Nestorian.
Entail: To settle or fix inalienably on a person or thing, or on a person and his descendants or a certain line of descendants; -- said especially of an estate; to bestow as an heritage.
Encourager: One who encourages, incites, or helps forward; a favorer.
Edh: The name of the Anglo-Saxon letter ð, capital form Ð. It is sounded as “English th in a similar word: ōðer, other, dôð, doth.”
Expugnation: The act of taking by assault; conquest.
Endeictic: Serving to show or exhibit; as, an endeictic dialogue, in the Platonic philosophy, is one which exhibits a specimen of skill.
Encephalous: Having a head; -- said of most Mollusca; -- opposed to acephalous.
Ellipsograph: An instrument for describing ellipses; -- called also trammel.
Eye-spot: A simple visual organ found in many invertebrates, consisting of pigment cells covering a sensory nerve termination.
Epipubis: A cartilage or bone in front of the pubis in some amphibians and other animals.
Emboguing: The mouth of a river, or place where its waters are discharged.
Expiscation: The act of expiscating; a fishing.
Epizo\u00f6n: One of the artificial group of invertebrates of various kinds, which live parasitically upon the exterior of other animals; an ectozoön. Among them are the lice, ticks, many acari, the lerneans, or fish lice, and other crustaceans.
Escuage: Service of the shield, a species of knight service by which a tenant was bound to follow his lord to war, at his own charge. It was afterward exchanged for a pecuniary satisfaction. Called also scutage.
Epigraphy: The science of inscriptions; the art of engraving inscriptions or of deciphering them.
Epiblema: The epidermal cells of rootlets, specially adapted to absorb liquids.
Exfoliation: The scaling off of a bone, a rock, or a mineral, etc.; the state of being exfoliated.
Evolute: A curve from which another curve, called the involute or evolvent, is described by the end of a thread gradually wound upon the former, or unwound from it. See Involute.  It is the locus of the centers of all the circles which are osculatory to the given curve or evolvent.
Enticer: One who entices; one who incites or allures to evil.
ethic: the principles of right and wrong that are accepted by an individual or a social group; as, the Puritan ethic.
emmer: a hard red wheat (Triticum dicoccum) grown especially in Russia and Germany; also grown in the U. S. as stock feed.
Embitter: To make bitter or sad. See Imbitter.
Elaiometer: An apparatus for determining the amount of oil contained in any substance, or for ascertaining the degree of purity of oil.
Elephantoid: Resembling an elephant in form or appearance.
Expectorant: Tending to facilitate expectoration or to promote discharges of mucus, etc., from the lungs or throat.
Epencephalon: The segment of the brain next behind the midbrain, including the cerebellum and pons; the hindbrain. Sometimes abbreviated to epen.
Enwrapment: Act of enwrapping; a wrapping or an envelope.
Expenditor: A disburser; especially, one of the disbursers of taxes for the repair of sewers.
Entropium: The inversion or turning in of the border of the eyelids.
Eventful: Full of, or rich in, events or incidents; as, an eventful journey; an eventful period of history; an eventful period of life.
Excarnate: To deprive or clear of flesh.
Endurant: Capable of enduring fatigue, pain, hunger, etc.
Endamage: To bring loss or damage to; to harm; to injure.
expansiveness: a quality characterized by magnificence of scale; as, the expansiveness of their extravagant lifestyle was soon curtailed.
Eryngium: A large genus of umbelliferous plants somewhat like thistles in appearance, cosmopolitan in distribution. Eryngium maritimum, or sea holly, has been highly esteemed as an aphrodisiac, the roots being formerly candied.
Equibalance: To make of equal weight; to balance equally; to counterbalance; to equiponderate.
Entresol: A low story between two higher ones, usually between the ground floor and the first story; mezzanine.
Experience table: A table of mortality computed from the experience of one or more life-insurance companies.
earth colors: colors like those of soil or earth; brownish-reds and browns.
Electrotonus: The modified condition of a nerve, when a constant current of electricity passes through any part of it. See Anelectrotonus, and Catelectrotonus.
Enkindle: To set on fire; to inflame; to kindle.
Edingtonite: A grayish white zeolitic mineral, in tetragonal crystals. It is a hydrous silicate of alumina and baryta.
Esurient: One who is hungry or greedy.
equalitarianism: the doctrine of the equality of mankind and the desirability of political and economic and social equality.
Elusion: Act of eluding; adroit escape, as by artifice; a mockery; a cheat; trickery.
Equability: The quality or condition of being equable; evenness or uniformity; as, equability of temperature; the equability of the mind.
Epitheca: A continuous and, usually, structureless layer which covers more or less of the exterior of many corals.
Emissivity: Tendency to emission; comparative facility of emission, or rate at which emission takes place;
Enrank: To place in ranks or in order.
Enchanter: One who enchants; a sorcerer or magician; also, one who delights as by an enchantment.
Ethically: According to, in harmony with, moral principles or character.
Echidnophaga: a genus of fleas including the stick-tight flea (Echidnophaga gallinacea), which is a serious pest in subtropical America, infesting poultry and frequently attacking man and domestic animals.
Elegize: To lament in an elegy; to celebrate in elegiac verse; to bewail.
Exuviability: Capability of shedding the skin periodically.
Extraregular: Not comprehended within a rule or rules.
Enchanted: Under the power of enchantment; possessed or exercised by enchanters; as, an enchanted castle.
Eurypteroid: Like, or pertaining to, the genus Euryperus.
Executer: One who performs or carries into effect. See Executor.
Extravagant: One who is confined to no general rule.
Emptiness: The state of being empty; absence of contents; void space; vacuum; as, the emptiness of a vessel; emptiness of the stomach.
Epicaridan: An isopod crustacean, parasitic on shrimps.
Engorge: To feed with eagerness or voracity; to stuff one's self with food.
Exotheca: The tissue which fills the interspaces between the costæ of many madreporarian corals, usually consisting of small transverse or oblique septa.
Eleemosynarily: In an eleemosynary manner; by charity; charitably.
Epispadias: A deformity in which the urethra opens upon the top of the penis, instead of at its extremity.
Endurance: A state or quality of lasting or duration; lastingness; continuance.
Earthy: Consisting of, or resembling, earth; terrene; earthlike; as, earthy matter.
Epigrammatist: One who composes epigrams, or makes use of them.
Electrotonic: Of or pertaining to electrical tension; -- said of a supposed peculiar condition of a conducting circuit during its exposure to the action of another conducting circuit traversed by a uniform electric current when both circuits remain stationary.
Encouragement: The act of encouraging; incitement to action or to practice; as, the encouragement of youth in generosity.
entering: incoming; -- of a person or group assuming a role.  Opposite of leaving and outgoing.
Ergo: Therefore; consequently; -- often used in a jocular way.
Eusebian: A follower of Eusebius, bishop of Cæsarea, who was a friend and protector of Arius.
Ebullition: A boiling or bubbling up of a liquid; the motion produced in a liquid by its rapid conversion into vapor.
Elamite: A dweller in Flam (or Susiana), an ancient kingdom of Southwestern Asia, afterwards a province of Persia.
Eire: the Irish name for Ireland; the name used in 1937 to 1949 for the Republic of Ireland.
Enlightenment: Act of enlightening, or the state of being enlightened or instructed.
Elizabeth: Queen Elizabeth II. of the United Kingdom, born 1926.
Eclogite: A rock consisting of granular red garnet, light green smaragdite, and common hornblende; -- so called in reference to its beauty.
Eater: One who, or that which, eats.
Emission: The act of sending or throwing out; the act of sending forth or putting into circulation; issue; as, the emission of light from the sun; the emission of heat from a fire; the emission of bank notes.
Evection: The act of carrying up or away; exaltation.
Everest: the highest mountain in the world, situated in Nepal and Tibet; 29,028 feet high.
Enterocele: A hernial tumor whose contents are intestine.
Enamor: To inflame with love; to charm; to captivate; -- with of, or with, before the person or thing; as, to be enamored with a lady; to be enamored of books or science.
Exceptionable: Liable to exception or objection; objectionable.
Evangelization: The act of evangelizing; the state of being evangelized.
Electrolier: A branching frame, often of ornamental design, to support electric illuminating lamps.
Eugenesis: The quality or condition of having strong reproductive powers; generation with full fertility between different species or races, specif. between hybrids of the first generation.
Eclecticism: Theory or practice of an eclectic.
Employ: That which engages or occupies a person; fixed or regular service or business; employment.
Exorcism: The act of exorcising; the driving out of evil spirits from persons or places by conjuration; also, the form of conjuration used.
Either: Either precedes two, or more, coördinate words or phrases, and is introductory to an alternative. It is correlative to or.
Ensile: To store (green fodder) in a silo; to prepare as silage.
Enlute: To coat with clay; to lute.
Elongate: Drawn out at length; elongated; as, an elongate leaf.
Extraterritoriality: The state of being beyond the limits of a particular territory
Efflower: To remove the epidermis of (a skin) with a concave knife, blunt in its middle part, -- as in making chamois leather.
Etiquette: The forms required by good breeding, or prescribed by authority, to be observed in social or official life; observance of the proprieties of rank and occasion; conventional decorum; ceremonial code of polite society.
Endothermic: Designating, or pert. to, a reaction which occurs with absorption of heat; formed by such a reaction; as, an endothermic substance; -- opposed to exothermic.
Ennoble: To make noble; to elevate in degree, qualities, or excellence; to dignify.
entitlement: a right granted by law or contract, especially to financial benefits from the government.
Ekasilicon: The name of a hypothetical element predicted and afterwards discovered and named germanium; -- so called because it was a missing analogue of the silicon group. See Germanium, and cf. Ekabor.
Exhilaration: The act of enlivening the spirits; the act of making glad or cheerful; a gladdening.
Exemplarily: In a manner fitted or designed to be an example for imitation or for warning; by way of example.
Elder: A genus of shrubs (Sambucus) having broad umbels of white flowers, and small black or red berries.
Erogate: To lay out, as money; to deal out; to expend.
Estrepement: A destructive kind of waste, committed by a tenant for life, in lands, woods, or houses.
Excellence: The quality of being excellent; state of possessing good qualities in an eminent degree; exalted merit; superiority in virtue.
Epineurium: The connective tissue framework and sheath of a nerve which bind together the nerve bundles, each of which has its own special sheath, or perineurium.
Epigraphics: The science or study of epigraphs.
Earning: That which is earned; wages gained by work or services; money earned; -- used commonly in the plural.
Ecclesiastic: A person in holy orders, or consecrated to the service of the church and the ministry of religion; a clergyman; a priest.
Enclitically: In an enclitic manner; by throwing the accent back.
Even: In an equal or precisely similar manner; equally; precisely; just; likewise; as well.
-ee: A suffix used, chiefly in law terms, in a passive signification, to indicate the direct or indirect object of an action, or the one to whom an act is done or on whom a right is conferred; as in assignee, donee, alienee, grantee, etc. It is correlative to -or, the agent or doer.
Eluctation: A struggling out of any difficulty.
Emulsic: Pertaining to, or produced from, emulsin; as, emulsic acid.
extinguished: caused to die out because of the absence or withdrawal of reinforcement; -- of a conditioned response.
embroideress: a woman who embroiders; a woman embroiderer.
Epithelium: The superficial layer of cells lining the alimentary canal and all its appendages, all glands and their ducts, blood vessels and lymphatics, serous cavities, etc. It often includes the epidermis (i. e., keratin-producing epithelial cells), and it is sometimes restricted to the alimentary canal, the glands and their appendages, -- the term endothelium being applied to the lining membrane of the blood vessels, lymphatics, and serous cavities.
Empale: To fence or fortify with stakes; to surround with a line of stakes for defense; to impale.
Expiable: Capable of being expiated or atoned for; as, an expiable offense; expiable guilt.
Eupatorium: A genus of perennial, composite herbs including hemp agrimony, boneset, throughwort, etc.
Emulsin: The white milky pulp or extract of bitter almonds.
Ethiop: A native or inhabitant of Ethiopia; also, in a general sense, a negro or black man.
Electro-magnetism: magnetism produced by an electric current.
Extemporization: The act of extemporizing; the act of doing anything extempore.
Eunectes: a genus of boas consisting of anacondas, large South American snakes that may grow to 25 feet.
Evet: The common newt or eft. In America often applied to several species of aquatic salamanders.
Exarillate: Having no aril; -- said of certain seeds, or of the plants producing them.
Ever: At any time; at any period or point of time.
Epigrammatic: Writing epigrams; dealing in epigrams; as, an epigrammatical poet.
Euphuistic: Belonging to the euphuists, or euphuism; affectedly refined.
Ebionitism: The system or doctrine of the Ebionites.
Egotistic: Addicted to, or manifesting, egotism; having an exaggerated view of one's own importance or good qualities.
Elutriate: To wash or strain out so as to purify; as, to elutriate the blood as it passes through the lungs; to strain off or decant, as a powder which is separated from heavier particles by being drawn off with water; to cleanse, as by washing.
Ericius: The Vulgate rendering of the Hebrew word qipōd, which in the “Authorized Version” is translated bittern, and in the Revised Version, porcupine.
Entomb: To deposit in a tomb, as a dead body; to bury; to inter; to inhume.
Evocate: To call out or forth; to summon; to evoke.
Expatriation: The act of banishing, or the state of banishment; especially, the forsaking of one's own country with a renunciation of allegiance.
educationalist: a specialist in the theory of eduction.
Electro-chronographic: Belonging to the electro-chronograph, or recorded by the aid of it.
establishmentarianism: the doctrine or political position that advocates establishment of a church as the official state religion; -- applied especially to the Church of England.
Exceptional: Forming an exception; not ordinary; uncommon; rare; hence, better than the average; superior.
Exungulate: To pare off, as nails, the hoof, etc.
enigma: A dark, obscure, or inexplicable saying; a riddle; a statement, the hidden meaning of which is to be discovered or guessed.
Enterprise: To undertake an enterprise, or something hazardous or difficult.
Excursive: Prone to make excursions; wandering; roving; exploring; as, an excursive fancy.
Ebriety: Drunkenness; intoxication by spirituous liquors; inebriety.
eohippus: an extinct primitive dog-sized 4-toed Eocene mammal, the earliest horse known in the line of descent of the modern horse.  It is classed in the extinct genus Hydracotherium.  Called also dawn horse.
Eunomian: A follower of Eunomius, bishop of Cyzicus (4th century A. D.), who held that Christ was not God but a created being, having a nature different from that of the Father.
Equinox: The time when the sun enters one of the equinoctial points, that is, about March 21 and September 22. See Autumnal equinox, Vernal equinox, under Autumnal and Vernal.
-et: A noun suffix with a diminutive force; as in baronet, pocket, facet, floweret, latchet.
Extralogical: Lying outside of the domain of logic.
Eloign: To remove afar off; to withdraw.
Ex-voto: An offering to a church in fulfillment of a vow.
Endomorph: A crystal of one species inclosed within one of another, as one of rutile inclosed in quartz.
Enderon: The deep sensitive and vascular layer of the skin and mucous membranes.
ex-serviceman: a person who has served in the armed forces.
Extraterritorial: Beyond the limits of a territory or particular jurisdiction; exterritorial.
Exhortatory: Of or pertaining to exhortation; hortatory.
Enwoman: To endow with the qualities of a woman.
Extoller: One who extols; one who praises.
Enroot: To fix by the root; to fix fast; to implant deep.
Esodic: Conveying impressions from the surface of the body to the spinal cord; -- said of certain nerves. Opposed to exodic.
eclipsis: the omission or suppression of parts of words or sentences.
Enactor: One who enacts a law; one who decrees or establishes as a law.
Elation: A lifting up by success; exaltation; inriation with pride of prosperity.
Etymology: That branch of philological science which treats of the history of words, tracing out their origin, primitive significance, and changes of form and meaning.
Epithalamic: Belonging to, or designed for, an epithalamium.
erudition: The act of instructing; the result of thorough instruction; the state of being erudite or learned; the acquisitions gained by extensive reading or study; particularly, learning in literature or criticism, as distinct from the sciences; scholarship.
Eocene: Pertaining to the first in time of the three subdivisions into which the Tertiary formation is divided by geologists, and alluding to the approximation in its life to that of the present era; as, Eocene deposits.
Epanalepsis: A figure by which the same word or clause is repeated after intervening matter.
Ensanguine: To stain or cover with blood; to make bloody, or of a blood-red color; as, an ensanguined hue.
Engender: One who, or that which, engenders.
Economizer: One who, or that which, economizes.
efficient: Causing effects; producing results; that makes the effect to be what it is; actively operative; not inactive, slack, or incapable; characterized by energetic and useful activity; as, an efficient officer, power.
Exudation: The act of exuding; sweating; a discharge of humors, moisture, juice, or gum, as through pores or incisions; also, the substance exuded.
Ent-: A prefix signifying within. See Ento-.
endangered: Being in a condition or situation where life or serious harm is possible; in danger; at risk.
emphasis: A particular stress of utterance, or force of voice, given in reading and speaking to one or more words whose signification the speaker intends to impress specially upon his audience.
\u00c9prouvette: An apparatus for testing or proving the strength of gunpowder.
Epithem: Any external topical application to the body, except ointments and plasters, as a poultice, lotion, etc.
Ethnography: That branch of knowledge which has for its subject the characteristics of the human family, developing the details with which ethnology as a comparative science deals; descriptive ethnology. See Ethnology.
Ephraim: A hunter's name for the grizzly bear.
Enchase: To incase or inclose in a border or rim; to surround with an ornamental casing, as a gem with gold; to encircle; to inclose; to adorn.
Exonerate: To unload; to disburden; to discharge.
Essonite: Cinnamon stone, a variety of garnet. See Garnet.
Eroded: Eaten away; gnawed; irregular, as if eaten or worn away.
Eurythmy: Just or harmonious proportion or movement, as in the composition of a poem, an edifice, a painting, or a statue.
Earmark: To mark, as sheep, by cropping or slitting the ear.
Extraordinarily: In an extraordinary manner or degree.
evaluator: an authority who is able to estimate worth or quality; an appraiser.
encephalartos: any of numerous cycads of the genus Encephalartos having stout cylindrical trunks and a terminal crown of long, often spiny pinnate leaves.
Enclitics: The art of declining and conjugating words.
enlightening: enlightening so as to encourage intellectual or moral improvement.
Effumability: The capability of flying off in fumes or vapor.
Edenized: Admitted to a state of paradisaic happiness.
Esox: A genus of fresh-water fishes, including pike and pickerel.
Elicit: To draw out or entice forth; to bring to light; to bring out against the will; to deduce by reason or argument; as, to elicit truth by discussion.
Euphonism: An agreeable combination of sounds; euphony.
Echinoidea: The class Echinodermata which includes the sea urchins.  They have a calcareous shell, usually more or less spheroidal or disk-shaped, composed of many united plates, and covered with movable spines. See Spatangoid, Clypeastroid.
Emarginate: Having the margin interrupted by a notch or shallow sinus.
ethnocentrism: belief in the superiority of one's own ethnic group.
Earshot: Reach of the ear; distance at which words may be heard.
Ennoblement: The act of making noble, or of exalting, dignifying, or advancing to nobility.
Embonpoint: Plumpness of person; -- said especially of persons somewhat corpulent.
Exocardiac: Situated or arising outside of the heart; as, exocardial murmurs; -- opposed to endocardiac.
Emblematize: To represent by, or as by, an emblem; to symbolize.
Exonerator: One who exonerates or frees from obligation.
Embiotocoid: Belonging to, or resembling, the Embiotocidæ.
Enregister: To register; to enroll or record; to inregister.
Ethiopic: The language of ancient Ethiopia; the language of the ancient Abyssinian empire (in Ethiopia), now used only in the Abyssinian church. It is of Semitic origin, and is also called Geez.
Emend: To purge of faults; to make better; to correct; esp., to make corrections in (a literary work); to alter for the better by textual criticism, generally verbal.
Endotheca: The tissue which partially fills the interior of the interseptal chambers of most madreporarian corals. It usually consists of a series of oblique tranverse septa, one above another.
Evener: One who, or that which makes even.
Exarch: A viceroy; in Ravenna, the title of the viceroys of the Byzantine emperors; in the Eastern Church, the superior over several monasteries; in the modern Greek Church, a deputy of the patriarch , who visits the clergy, investigates ecclesiastical cases, etc.
Endurable: Capable of being endured or borne; sufferable.
Epiblastic: Of or relating to, or consisting of, the epiblast.
Encauma: An ulcer in the eye, upon the cornea, which causes the loss of the humors.
Effulgent: Diffusing a flood of light; shining; luminous; beaming; bright; splendid.
Expirable: That may expire; capable of being brought to an end.
Expostulatory: Containing expostulation or remonstrance; as, an expostulatory discourse or letter.
Eulogy: A speech or writing in commendation of the character or services of a person; as, a fitting eulogy to worth.
Earthquake: Like, or characteristic of, an earthquake; loud; startling.
Epipodite: The outer branch of the legs in certain Crustacea. See Maxilliped.
Embargo: To lay an embargo on and thus detain; to prohibit from leaving port; -- said of ships, also of commerce and goods.
Effluent: A stream that flows out of another stream or lake.
empty-handed: having acquired or gained nothing; as, the returned from the negotiations empty-handed.
extrasensory perception: the ability to perceive or gain information about external facts or events by means other than the senses.
Endopleurite: The portion of each apodeme developed from the interepimeral membrane in certain crustaceans.
Elaterium: A cathartic substance obtained, in the form of yellowish or greenish cakes, as the dried residue of the juice of the wild or squirting cucumber (Ecballium agreste, formerly called Momordica Elaterium).
Enchant: To charm by sorcery; to act on by enchantment; to get control of by magical words and rites.
Endopleura: The inner coating of a seed. See Tegmen.
Euphuist: One who affects excessive refinement and elegance of language; -- applied esp. to a class of writers, in the age of Elizabeth, whose productions are marked by affected conceits and high-flown diction.
Exhibit: Any article, or collection of articles, displayed to view, as in an industrial exhibition; a display; as, this exhibit was marked A; the English exhibit.
event horizon: the boundary surface surrounding a black hole, from outside of which nothing inside can be observed, because nothing inside that surface, even light, can escape beyond it.  See also black hole and escape velocity.
Enchorial: Belonging to, or used in, a country; native; domestic; popular; common; -- said especially of the written characters employed by the common people of ancient Egypt, in distinction from the hieroglyphics. See Demotic.
Eikosylene: A liquid hydrocarbon, C20H38, of the acetylene series, obtained from brown coal.
Ericolin: A glucoside found in the bearberry (and others of the Ericaceæ), and extracted as a bitter, yellow, amorphous mass.
Enseal: To impress with a seal; to mark as with a seal; hence, to ratify.
Enseam: To cover with grease; to defile; to pollute.
Extinguishable: Capable of being quenched, destroyed, or suppressed.
Eranthis: A genus of plants of the buttercup family including the winter aconite, Eranthis hyemalis.
Education: The act or process of educating; the result of educating, as determined by the knowledge skill, or discipline of character, acquired; also, the act or process of training by a prescribed or customary course of study or discipline; as, an education for the bar or the pulpit; he has finished his education.
Eirenarch: A justice of the peace; irenarch.
Ebonite: A hard, black variety of vulcanite. It may be cut and polished, and is used for many small articles, as combs and buttons, and for insulating material in electric apparatus.
Eulachon: The candlefish. [Written also oulachan, oolacan, and ulikon.] See Candlefish.
Equivoque: An ambiguous term; a word susceptible of different significations.
Enomoty: A band of sworn soldiers; a division of the Spartan army ranging from twenty-five to thirty-six men, bound together by oath.
Electrostatics: That branch of science which treats of statical electricity or electric force in a state of rest.
enlistee: any new member of an organization or supporter of a cause.
Empetrum: A genus of heathlike shrubs including the crowberry (Empetrum nigrum).
Ecostate: Having no ribs or nerves; -- said of a leaf.
Enfilade: To pierce, scour, or rake with shot in the direction of the length of, as a work, or a line of troops.
Entortilation: A turning into a circle; round figures.
Exhaustive: Serving or tending to exhaust; exhibiting all the facts or arguments; as, an exhaustive method.
Endosarc: The semifluid, granular interior of certain unicellular organisms, as the inner layer of sarcode in the amœba; entoplasm; endoplasta.
encouraged: made to feel more courage, hope, or optimism.
Ethylic: Pertaining to, derived from, or containing, ethyl; as, ethylic alcohol.
Equidifferent: Having equal differences; as, the terms of arithmetical progression are equidifferent.
\u00c9lan: Ardor inspired by passion or enthusiasm.
Exorhizal: Having a radicle which is not inclosed by the cotyledons or plumule; of or relating to an exorhiza.
Exegetics: The science of interpretation or exegesis.
Exaltation: The act of exalting or raising high; also, the state of being exalted; elevation.
Erogation: The act of giving out or bestowing.
Engineering: Originally, the art of managing engines; in its modern and extended sense, the art and science by which the properties of matter are made useful to man, whether in structures, machines, chemical substances, or living organisms; the occupation and work of an engineer.  In the modern sense, the application of mathematics or systematic knowledge beyond the routine skills of practise, for the design of any complex system which performs useful functions, may be considered as engineering, including such abstract tasks as designing software (software engineering).
Erectile: Capable of being erected; susceptible of being erected of dilated; as, erectile tissue.
enough: An exclamation denoting sufficiency, being a shortened form of it is enough.
Exorcist: One who expels evil spirits by conjuration or exorcism.
Embryotomy: The cutting a fetus into pieces within the womb, so as to effect its removal.
Engraver: One who engraves; a person whose business it is to produce engraved work, especially on metal or wood.
-ency: A noun suffix having much the same meaning as -ence, but more commonly signifying the quality or state; as, emergency, efficiency. See -ancy.
Epinglette: An iron needle for piercing the cartridge of a cannon before priming.
-ence: A noun suffix signifying action, state, or quality; also, that which relates to the action or state; as in emergence, diffidence, diligence, influence, difference, excellence. See -ance.
Exsufflate: To exorcise or renounce by blowing.
Endoss: To put upon the back or outside of anything; -- the older spelling of endorse.
Each: Every one of the two or more individuals composing a number of objects, considered separately from the rest. It is used either with or without a following noun; as, each of you or each one of you.
enthralling: capturing interest as if by a spell; as, an enthralling book.
Extinguish: To quench; to put out, as a light or fire; to stifle; to cause to die out; to put an end to; to destroy; as, to extinguish a flame, or life, or love, or hope, a pretense or a right.
Estreat: To extract or take out from the records of a court, and send up to the court of exchequer to be enforced; -- said of a forfeited recognizance.
Engraved: Made by engraving or ornamented with engraving.
Express train: Formerly, a railroad train run expressly for the occasion; a special train; now, a train run at express or special speed and making few stops.
Equally: In an equal manner or degree in equal shares or proportion; with equal and impartial justice; without difference; alike; evenly; justly; as, equally taxed, furnished, etc.
Eschara: A genus of Bryozoa which produce delicate corals, often incrusting like lichens, but sometimes branched.
Eudialyte: A mineral of a brownish red color and vitreous luster, consisting chiefly of the silicates of iron, zirconia, and lime.
Erythroxylon: A genus of shrubs or small trees of the Flax family, growing in tropical countries. E. Coca is the source of cocaine. See Coca.
Expilator: One who pillages; a plunderer; a pillager.
Epignathous: Hook-billed; having the upper mandible longer than the lower.
Exo-: A prefix signifying out of, outside; as in exocarp, exogen, exoskeleton.
ethnocentric: centered on a specific ethnic group, usually one's own; exhibiting ethnocentrism (in both senses).
Ectad: Toward the outside or surface; -- opposed to entad.
Exemplifier: One who exemplifies by following a pattern.
Evernic: Pertaining to Evernia, a genus of lichens; as, evernic acid.
Echeneis: the type genus of the Echeneididae; they are typical remoras.
Entophyte: A vegetable parasite subsisting in the interior of the body.
Ectal: Pertaining to, or situated near, the surface; outer; -- opposed to ental.
Endecane: One of the higher hydrocarbons of the paraffin series, C11H24, found as a constituent of petroleum.
Employment: The act of employing or using; also, the state of being employed.
Everyday: Used or fit for every day; common; usual; as, an everyday suit of clothes.
Encaustic: The method of painting in heated wax, or in any way where heat is used to fix the colors.
Extravagance: A wandering beyond proper limits; an excursion or sally from the usual way, course, or limit.
Englishman: A native or a naturalized inhabitant of England.
Enginer: A contriver; an inventor; a contriver of engines.
Excretory: Having the quality of excreting, or throwing off excrementitious matter.
Elizabethan: Pertaining to Queen Elizabeth I. or her times, esp. to the architecture or literature of her reign; as, the Elizabethan writers, drama, literature.
Enterer: One who makes an entrance or beginning.
Eyehole: A circular opening to recive a hook, cord, ring, or rope; an eyelet.
Entosthoblast: The granule within the nucleolus or entoblast of a nucleated cell.
Evil-favored: Having a bad countenance or appearance; ill-favored; blemished; deformed.
eight-spot: a playing card with eight pips on the face; an eight.
Empyema: A collection of blood, pus, or other fluid, in some cavity of the body, especially that of the pleura.
Extreme: The utmost point or verge; that part which terminates a body; extremity.
Egotize: To talk or write as an egotist.
Eutaxy: Good or established order or arrangement.
epistemology: The theory or science of the method or grounds of knowledge.
Electric: A nonconductor of electricity, as amber, glass, resin, etc., employed to excite or accumulate electricity.
Entozo\u00f6logist: One versed in the science of the Entozoa.
Equipendency: The act or condition of hanging in equipoise; not inclined or determined either way.
Entwinement: A twining or twisting together or round; union.
Endecaphyllous: Composed of eleven leaflets; -- said of a leaf.
Excess: The state of surpassing or going beyond limits; the being of a measure beyond sufficiency, necessity, or duty; that which exceeds what is usual or proper; immoderateness; superfluity; superabundance; extravagance; as, an excess of provisions or of light.
Equisetaceous: Belonging to the Equisetaceæ, or Horsetail family.
electric chair: a device used for execution of criminals, consisting of a specially designed chair in which the victim is killed by passing a large current of electricity through the body.  This method of killing is called electrocution.
Exinanite: To make empty; to render of no effect; to humble.
educatee: a learner who is enrolled in an educational institution.
Echinate: Set with prickles; prickly, like a hedgehog; bristled; as, an echinated pericarp.
Equilibrity: The state of being balanced; equality of weight.
Epicentral: Arising from the centrum of a vertebra.
Episodic: Of or pertaining to an episode; adventitious.
Epistilbite: A crystallized, transparent mineral of the Zeolite family. It is a hydrous silicate of alumina and lime.
Errantia: A group of chætopod annelids, including those that are not confined to tubes. See Chætopoda.
Enhearten: To give heart to; to fill with courage; to embolden.
Exceeding: In a very great degree; extremely; exceedingly.
Erose: Irregular or uneven as if eaten or worn away.
Equalize: To make equal; to cause to correspond, or be like, in amount or degree as compared; as, to equalize accounts, burdens, or taxes.
eye-catching: Seizing the attention; as, eye-catching posters; as, she wore an eye-catching low-cut gown.
Embryonic: Of or pertaining to an embryo; embryonal; rudimentary.
Exinanition: An emptying; an enfeebling; exhaustion; humiliation.
Eyesight: Sight of the eye; the sense of seeing; view; observation.
Ejaculation: The act of throwing or darting out with a sudden force and rapid flight.
Elasmobranchii: A subclass of fishes, comprising the sharks, the rays, and the Chimæra. The skeleton is mainly cartilaginous.
Epicoracoid: A ventral cartilaginous or bony element of the coracoid in the shoulder girdle of some vertebrates.
Excusator: One who makes, or is authorized to make, an excuse; an apologist.
Emblazoner: One who emblazons; also, one who publishes and displays anything with pomp.
Etiolation: The operation of blanching plants, by excluding the light of the sun; the condition of a blanched plant.
Equites: An order of knights holding a middle place between the senate and the commonalty; members of the Roman equestrian order.
Ethereal: Pertaining to the hypothetical upper, purer air, or to the higher regions beyond the earth or beyond the atmosphere; celestial; as, ethereal space; ethereal regions.
eye-opening: Causing one suddenly to learn or understand what was not previously known; as, an eye-opening look into the private machinations of the governor.
Elleck: The red gurnard or cuckoo fish.
Ermined: Clothed or adorned with the fur of the ermine.
Energetics: That branch of science which treats of the laws governing the physical or mechanical, in distinction from the vital, forces, and which comprehends the consideration and general investigation of the whole range of the forces concerned in physical phenomena.
Edification: The act of edifying, or the state of being edified; a building up, especially in a moral or spiritual sense; moral, intellectual, or spiritual improvement; instruction.
Embellishment: The act of adorning, or the state of being adorned; adornment.
Exhibitioner: One who has a pension or allowance granted for support.
Ecgonine: A colorless, crystalline, nitrogenous base, obtained by the decomposition of cocaine.
Ethiopian: Of or relating to Ethiopia or the Ethiopians.
Exigenter: An officer in the Court of King's Bench and Common Pleas whose duty it was to make out exigents. The office is now abolished.
Elevator: One who, or that which, raises or lifts up anything.
Excusatory: Making or containing excuse or apology; apologetical; as, an excusatory plea.
Eucairite: A metallic mineral, a selenide of copper and silver; -- so called by Berzelius on account of its being found soon after the discovery of the metal selenium.
Endothorax: An internal process of the sternal plates in the thorax of insects.
Eliminate: To put out of doors; to expel; to discharge; to release; to set at liberty.
Endosteum: The layer of vascular connective tissue lining the medullary cavities of bone.
Empiricism: The method or practice of an empiric; pursuit of knowledge by observation and experiment.
Equine: Of, pertaining to, or resembling, a horse.
Enjoyable: Capable of being enjoyed or of giving joy; yielding enjoyment.
Exscriptural: Not in accordance with the doctrines of Scripture; unscriptural.
Euphonon: An instrument resembling the organ in tone and the upright piano in form. It is characterized by great strength and sweetness of tone.
Echinulate: Set with small spines or prickles.
Erasion: The act of erasing; a rubbing out; obliteration.
eggshell: of a pale, yellowish-white color; as, an eggshell ceiling and light green walls.
Exclusory: Able to exclude; excluding; serving to exclude.
Excuse: The act of excusing, apologizing, exculpating, pardoning, releasing, and the like; acquittal; release; absolution; justification; extenuation.
Estrangement: The act of estranging, or the state of being estranged; alienation.
\u00c9cossaise: A dancing tune in the Scotch style.
Embulk: To enlarge in the way of bulk.
Exultation: The act of exulting; lively joy at success or victory, or at any advantage gained; rapturous delight; triumph.
Erythrolein: A red substance obtained from litmus.
Elliptically: In the form of an ellipse.
Episkeletal: Above or outside of the endoskeleton; epaxial.
Escape: The act of fleeing from danger, of evading harm, or of avoiding notice; deliverance from injury or any evil; flight; as, an escape in battle; a narrow escape; also, the means of escape; as, a fire escape.
Erythroleic: Having a red color and oily appearance; -- applied to a purple semifluid substance said to be obtained from archil.
Estaminet: A café, or room in a café, in which smoking is allowed.
Estovers: Necessaries or supplies; an allowance to a person out of an estate or other thing for support; as of wood to a tenant for life, etc., of sustenance to a man confined for felony out of his estate, or alimony to a woman divorced out of her husband's estate.
Ear-splitting: Deafening; disagreeably loud or shrill; as, ear-splitting strains.
Epigastrium: The upper part of the abdomen.
Endosporous: Having the spores contained in a case; -- applied to fungi.
Enticement: The act or practice of alluring or tempting; as, the enticements of evil companions.
Entwist: To twist or wreathe round; to intwine.
Exhaustion: The act of draining out or draining off; the act of emptying completely of the contents.
Explode: To drive from the stage by noisy expressions of disapprobation; to hoot off; to drive away or reject noisily; as, to explode a play.
Eozoic: Of or pertaining to rocks or strata older than the Paleozoic, in many of which the eozoön has been found.
Euplectella: A genus of elegant, glassy sponges, consisting of interwoven siliceous fibers, and growing in the form of a cornucopia; -- called also Venus's flower-basket.
Ere: To plow. [Obs.] See Ear, v. t.
Euphorbiaceous: Of, relating to, or resembling, the Euphorbia family.
Erethism: A morbid degree of excitement or irritation in an organ.
Endophragma: A chitinous structure above the nervous cord in the thorax of certain Crustacea.
Esquisse: The first sketch of a picture or model of a statue.
Encage: To confine in a cage; to coop up.
Extensometer: An instrument for measuring the extension of a body, especially for measuring the elongation of bars of iron, steel, or other material, when subjected to a tensile force.
Exchangeability: The quality or state of being exchangeable.
Enswathement: The act of enswathing, or the state of being enswathed.
Earthly-minded: Having a mind devoted to earthly things; worldly-minded; -- opposed to spiritual-minded.
Erstwhile: Till then or now; heretofore; formerly.
Eczematous: Pertaining to eczema; having the characteristic of eczema.
Emotionalism: The cultivation of an emotional state of mind; tendency to regard things in an emotional manner.
Elenctic: Serving to refute; refutative; -- applied to indirect modes of proof, and opposed to deictic.
Eosin: A yellow or brownish red dyestuff obtained by the action of bromine on fluoresceïn, and named from the fine rose-red which it imparts to silk. It is also used for making a fine red ink. Its solution is fluorescent.
euphrasy: The plant eyebright (Euphrasia officionalis), formerly regarded as beneficial in disorders of the eyes.
Exscutellate: Without, or apparently without, a scutellum; -- said of certain insects.
Eaglewood: A kind of fragrant wood. See Agallochum.
Ex post facto: From or by an after act, or thing done afterward; in consequence of a subsequent act; retrospective.
Examination: The act of examining, or state of being examined; a careful search, investigation, or inquiry; scrutiny by study or experiment.
Ehlite: A mineral of a green color and pearly luster; a hydrous phosphate of copper.
Exilition: A sudden springing or leaping out.
Embodiment: The act of embodying; the state of being embodied.
Excarnificate: To clear of flesh; to excarnate.
Epitomist: One who makes an epitome; one who abridges; an epitomizer.
Eyeflap: A blinder on a horse's bridle.
Etching: The act, art, or practice of engraving by means of acid which eats away lines or surfaces left unprotected in metal, glass, or the like. See Etch, v. t.
Encampment: The act of pitching tents or forming huts, as by an army or traveling company, for temporary lodging or rest.
Enneandria: A Linnæan class of plants having nine stamens.
Embale: To make up into a bale or pack.
Electrology: That branch of physical science which treats of the phenomena of electricity and its properties.
Eradication: The act of plucking up by the roots; a rooting out; extirpation; utter destruction.
Eavesdrop: The water which falls in drops from the eaves of a house.
Explicator: One who unfolds or explains; an expounder; an explainer.
Embalm: To anoint all over with balm; especially, to preserve from decay by means of balm or other aromatic oils, or spices; to fill or impregnate (a dead body), with aromatics and drugs that it may resist putrefaction.
Eudoxian: A follower of Eudoxius, patriarch of Antioch and Constantinople in the 4th century, and a celebrated defender of the doctrines of Arius.
Extrados: The exterior curve of an arch; esp., the upper curved face of the whole body of voussoirs. See Intrados.
Ettle: To earn. [Obs.] See Addle, to earn.
Ethics: The science of human duty; the body of rules of duty drawn from this science; a particular system of principles and rules concerting duty, whether true or false; rules of practice in respect to a single class of human actions; as, political or social ethics; medical ethics.
Eulogize: To speak or write in commendation of (another); to extol in speech or writing; to praise.
\u00c9clair: A kind of frosted cake, containing flavored cream.
Ebullient: Boiling up or over; hence, manifesting exhilaration or excitement, as of feeling; effervescing.
Etheostomoid: Pertaining to, or like, the genus Etheostoma.
evasive: Tending to evade, or marked by evasion; elusive; shuffling; avoiding by artifice.
Extremity: The extreme part; the utmost limit; the farthest or remotest point or part; as, the extremities of a country.
Evil-eyed: Possessed of the supposed evil eye; also, looking with envy, jealousy, or bad design; malicious.
Examine: To test by any appropriate method; to inspect carefully with a view to discover the real character or state of; to subject to inquiry or inspection of particulars for the purpose of obtaining a fuller insight into the subject of examination, as a material substance, a fact, a reason, a cause, the truth of a statement; to inquire or search into; to explore; as, to examine a mineral; to examine a ship to know whether she is seaworthy; to examine a proposition, theory, or question.
Ethnologically: In an ethnological manner; by ethnological classification; as, one belonging ethnologically to an African race.
Eventuate: To come out finally or in conclusion; to result; to come to pass.
Echoer: One who, or that which, echoes.
Edgelong: In the direction of the edge.
Elegantly: In a manner to please nice taste; with elegance; with due symmetry; richly.
Example: To set an example for; to give a precedent for; to exemplify; to give an instance of; to instance.
Epilogize: To speak an epilogue to; to utter as an epilogue.
Erroneous: Wandering; straying; deviating from the right course; -- hence, irregular; unnatural.
Elasmosaurus: An extinct, long-necked, marine, cretaceous reptile from Kansas, allied to Plesiosaurus.
Endostome: The foramen or passage through the inner integument of an ovule.
Exchange: To be changed or received in exchange for; to pass in exchange; as, dollar exchanges for ten dimes.
Elasmobranch: Of or pertaining to the Elasmobranchii.
Embryogenic: Pertaining to the development of an embryo.
Enhancement: The act of increasing, or state of being increased; augmentation; aggravation; as, the enhancement of value, price, enjoyments, crime.
Exsuccous: Destitute of juice; dry; sapless. Latham.
Eclat: Brilliancy of success or effort; splendor; brilliant show; striking effect; glory; renown.
El\u00e6agnus: A genus of shrubs or small trees, having the foliage covered with small silvery scales; oleaster.
Episcopize: To perform the duties of a bishop.
Enounce: To announce; to declare; to state, as a proposition or argument.
Endostoma: A plate which supports the labrum in certain Crustacea.
Edictal: Relating to, or consisting of, edicts; as, the Roman edictal law.
Explicitness: The quality of being explicit; clearness; directness.
Entertainment: The act of receiving as host, or of amusing, admitting, or cherishing; hospitable reception; also, reception or treatment, in general.
Epicondylar: Pertaining to, or resembling, an epicondyle.
Exacerbation: The act of rendering more violent or bitter; the state of being exacerbated or intensified in violence or malignity; as, exacerbation of passion.
Eyesore: Something offensive to the eye or sight; a blemish.
Enthymeme: An argument consisting of only two propositions, an antecedent and consequent deduced from it; a syllogism with one premise omitted; as, We are dependent; therefore we should be humble. Here the major proposition is suppressed. The complete syllogism would be, Dependent creatures should be humble; we are dependent creatures; therefore we should be humble.
Employer: One who employs another; as, an employer of workmen.
Euchre: To defeat, in a game of euchre, the side that named the trump.
Extraneous: Not belonging to, or dependent upon, a thing; without or beyond a thing; not essential or intrinsic; foreign; as, to separate gold from extraneous matter.
Electro-muscular: Pertaining to the reaction (contraction) of the muscles under electricity, or their sensibility to it.
Exfetation: Imperfect fetation in some organ exterior to the uterus; extra-uterine fetation.
Enantiomer: either of a pair of optical isomers of a chemical substance whose molecules are mirror images of each other, i. e., are related to each other as a right-handed to a left-handed glove; -- meaningful only for structures which have internal asymmetry.
Ennead: The number nine or a group of nine.
Etiological: Pertaining to, or inquiring into, causes; ætiological.
ergosterol: a plant sterol that is converted into vitamin D by ultraviolet radiation.
Epispore: The thickish outer coat of certain spores.
Elastically: In an elastic manner; by an elastic power; with a spring.
Effet: The common newt; -- called also asker, eft, evat, and ewt.
Explosion: The act of exploding; detonation; a chemical action which causes the sudden formation of a great volume of expanded gas; as, the explosion of gunpowder, of fire damp, etc.
Epimere: One of the segments of the transverse axis, or the so called homonymous parts; as, for example, one of the several segments of the extremities in vertebrates, or one of the similar segments in plants, such as the segments of a segmented leaf.
Electro-tint: A style   of engraving in relief by means of voltaic electricity. A picture is drawn on a metallic plate with some material which resists the fluids of a battery; so that, in electro-typing, the parts not covered by the varnish, etc., receive a deposition of metal, and produce the required copy in intaglio. A cast of this is then the plate for printing.
Egesta: That which is egested or thrown off from the body by the various excretory channels; excrements; -- opposed to ingesta.
Exorate: To persuade, or to gain, by entreaty.
Excussion: The act of excusing; seizure by law.
Engregge: To aggravate; to make worse; to lie heavy on.
Electro-dynamic: Pertaining to the movements or force of electric or galvanic currents; dependent on electric force.
Equus: A genus of mammals, including the horse, ass, etc.
egocentric: a self-centered person with little regard for others.
Ejector: One who, or that which, ejects or dispossesses.
