Emblement: The growing crop, or profits of a crop which has been sown or planted; -- used especially in the plural. The produce of grass, trees, and the like, is not emblement.
Endogeny: Growth from within; multiplication of cells by endogenous division, as in the development of one or more cells in the interior of a parent cell.
Extinguishment: The act of extinguishing, putting out, or quenching, or the state of being extinguished; extinction; suppression; destruction; nullification; as, the extinguishment of fire or flame, of discord, enmity, or jealousy, or of love or affection.
Ether: A medium of great elasticity and extreme tenuity, once supposed to pervade all space, the interior of solid bodies not excepted, and to be the medium of transmission of light and heat; hence often called luminiferous ether.  It is no longer believed that such a medium is required for the transmission of electromagnetic waves; the modern use of the term is mostly a figurative term for empty space, or for literary effect, and not intended to imply the actual existence of a physical medium.  However. modern cosmological theories based on quantum field theory do not rule out the possibility that the inherent energy of the vacuum is greater than zero, in which case the concept of an ether pervading the vacuum may have more than metaphoric meaning.
Endanger: To put to hazard; to bring into danger or peril; to expose to loss or injury; as, to endanger life or peace.
emasculate: Deprived of virility or vigor; unmanned; weak.
Eudiometry: The art or process of determining the constituents of a gaseous mixture by means of the eudiometer, or for ascertaining the purity of the air or the amount of oxygen in it.
Extensor: A muscle which serves to extend or straighten any part of the body, as an arm or a finger; -- opposed to flexor.
evaporated: reduced in volume by having moisture expelled before canning; same as condensed, 3; as, unsweetened evaporated milk.
Ekename: An additional or epithet name; a nickname.
\u00c9tat Major: The staff of an army, including all officers above the rank of colonel, also, all adjutants, inspectors, quartermasters, commissaries, engineers, ordnance officers, paymasters, physicians, signal officers, judge advocates; also, the noncommissioned assistants of the above officers.
Exceedingly: To a very great degree; beyond what is usual; surpassingly. It signifies more than very.
Electro-puncture: An operation that consists in inserting needless in the part affected, and connecting them with the poles of a galvanic apparatus.
Epipodium: One of the lateral lobes of the foot in certain gastropods.
Embryotroph: The material from which an embryo is formed and nourished.
Embronze: To embody in bronze; to set up a bronze representation of, as of a person.
encryption: the process of converting messages in ordinary language, or other information into a secret coded form that cannot be interpreted without knowing the secret method for interpretation, called the key.
Entreater: One who entreats; one who asks earnestly; a beseecher.
Erecter: An erector; one who raises or builds.
Epiploce: A figure by which one striking circumstance is added, in due gradation, to another; climax; e. g., “He not only spared his enemies, but continued them in employment; not only continued, but advanced them.”
echoic: Formed in imitation of a natural sound; -- of words.  Contrasted to nonechoic.
Embillow: To swell or heave like a wave of the sea.
Ethylene: A colorless, gaseous hydrocarbon, C2H4, forming an important ingredient of illuminating gas, and also obtained by the action of concentrated sulphuric acid in alcohol. It is an unsaturated compound and combines directly with chlorine and bromine to form oily liquids (Dutch liquid), -- hence called olefiant gas. Called also ethene, elayl, and formerly, bicarbureted hydrogen.
Expugn: To take by assault; to storm; to overcome; to vanquish; as, to expugn cities; to expugn a person by arguments.
Electrition: The recognition by an animal body of the electrical condition of external objects.
Electrine: Belonging to, or made of, amber.
Exequy: A funeral rite (usually in the plural); the ceremonies of burial; obsequies; funeral procession.
Endysis: The act of developing a new coat of hair, a new set of feathers, scales, etc.; -- opposed to ecdysis.
Epiplastron: One of the first pair of lateral plates in the plastron of turtles.
Equate: To make equal; to reduce to an average; to make such an allowance or correction in as will reduce to a common standard of comparison; to reduce to mean time or motion; as, to equate payments; to equate lines of railroad for grades or curves; equated distances.
Experimentation: The act of experimenting; practice by experiment.
erythroblast: a nucleated cell in bone marrow from which red blood cells develop.
Empty: To discharge itself; as, a river empties into the ocean.
Equilibrium: Equality of weight or force; an equipoise or a state of rest produced by the mutual counteraction of two or more forces.
Exporter: One who exports; the person who sends goods or commodities to a foreign country, in the way of commerce; -- opposed to importer.
Experiment: To try; to know, perceive, or prove, by trial or experience.
Enchyma: The primitive formative juice, from which the tissues, particularly the cellular tissue, are formed.
Embar: To bar or shut in; to inclose securely, as with bars.
Eventognathi: An order of fishes including a vast number of freshwater species such as the carp, loach, chub, etc.
Encephalopathy: Any disease or symptoms of disease referable to disorders of the brain; as, lead encephalopathy, the cerebral symptoms attending chronic lead poisoning.
Ect-: A combining form signifying without, outside, external.
Embay: To shut in, or shelter, as in a bay.
Endosmose: The transmission of a fluid or gas from without inward in the phenomena, or by the process, of osmose.
Evaporator: An apparatus for condensing vegetable juices, or for drying fruit by heat.
Electrometer: An instrument for measuring the quantity or intensity of electricity; also, sometimes, and less properly, applied to an instrument which indicates the presence of electricity (usually called an electroscope).
Estre: The inward part of a building; the interior.
Epoch: A fixed point of time, established in history by the occurrence of some grand or remarkable event; a point of time marked by an event of great subsequent influence; as, the epoch of the creation; the birth of Christ was the epoch which gave rise to the Christian era.
Extractor: One who, or that which, extracts
Earthling: An inhabitant of the earth; a mortal.
Experience: To make practical acquaintance with; to try personally; to prove by use or trial; to have trial of; to have the lot or fortune of; to have befall one; to be affected by; to feel; as, to experience pain or pleasure; to experience poverty; to experience a change of views.
Extern: A pupil in a seminary who lives without its walls; a day scholar.
Endophragmal: Of or pertaining to the endophragma.
Elective: In an American college, an optional study or course of study; a course that is not required.
Error: A wandering; a roving or irregular course.
Eyeservant: A servant who attends faithfully to his duty only when watched.
Eyelid: The cover of the eye; that portion of movable skin with which an animal covers or uncovers the eyeball at pleasure.
Eupeptic: Of or pertaining to good digestion; easy of digestion; having a good digestion; as, eupeptic food; an eupeptic man.
Ethide: Any compound of ethyl of a binary type; as, potassium ethide.
Emerge: To rise out of a fluid; to come forth from that in which anything has been plunged, enveloped, or concealed; to issue and appear; as, to emerge from the water or the ocean; the sun emerges from behind the moon in an eclipse; to emerge from poverty or obscurity.
Exciting: Calling or rousing into action; producing excitement; as, exciting events; an exciting story.
Ethylidene: An unsymmetrical, divalent, hydrocarbon radical, C2H4 metameric with ethylene but written thus, CH3.CH= to distinguish it from the symmetrical ethylene, CH2=CH2. Its compounds are derived from aldehyde. Formerly called also ethidene.
Electrophoridae: small natural family comprising the electric eels.
embedded: enclosed or fixed firmly in a surrounding mass; surrounded on all sides; as, found pebbles embedded in the silt; stone containing many embedded fossils; as, peach and plum seeds embedded in a sweet edible pulp.
Expand: To become widely opened, spread apart, dilated, distended, or enlarged; as, flowers expand in the spring; metals expand by heat; the heart expands with joy.
Epistoma: The region between the antennæ and the mouth, in Crustacea.
Ekaluminium: The name given to a hypothetical element, -- later discovered and called gallium. See Gallium, and cf. Ekabor.
Enneagynous: Having or producing nine pistils or styles; -- said of a flower or plant.
Embedment: The act of embedding, or the state of being embedded.
Earldom: The jurisdiction of an earl; the territorial possessions of an earl.
Enucleate: To bring or peel out, as a kernel from its enveloping husks its enveloping husks or shell.
Embattail: To furnish with battlements; to fortify as with battlements.
Etherol: An oily hydrocarbon regarded as a polymeric variety of ethylene, produced with etherin.
East-insular: Relating to the Eastern Islands; East Indian.
Egyptize: To give an Egyptian character or appearance to.
Exhibition: The act of exhibiting for inspection, or of holding forth to view; manifestation; display.
Eland: A species of large South African antelope (Oreas canna). It is valued both for its hide and flesh, and is rapidly disappearing in the settled districts; -- called also Cape elk.
Ethylamine: A colorless, mobile, inflammable liquid, C2H5.NH2, very volatile and with an ammoniacal odor. It is a strong base, and is a derivative of ammonia. Called also ethyl carbamine, and amido ethane.
Eligible: That may be selected; proper or qualified to be chosen; legally qualified to be elected and to hold office.
Efficient: An efficient cause; a prime mover.
Exotery: That which is obvious, public, or common.
Excarnification: The act of excarnificating or of depriving of flesh; excarnation.
Eliquament: A liquid obtained from fat, or fat fish, by pressure.
ensuing: subsequent, or occurring as a result; as, ensuing events confirmed the prediction.
Ethnologist: One versed in ethnology; a student of ethnology.
Ester: An ethereal salt, or compound ether, consisting of an organic radical united with the residue of any oxygen acid, organic or inorganic; thus the natural fats are esters of glycerin and the fatty acids, oleic, etc.
Eyestone: A small, lenticular, calcareous body, esp. an operculum of a small marine shell of the family Turbinidæ, used to remove a foreign substance from the eye. It is put into the inner corner of the eye under the lid, and allowed to work its way out at the outer corner, bringing with it the substance.
Everywhen: At any or all times; every instant.
Erythronium: A name originally given (from its red acid) to the metal vanadium.
Emmental: a type of large-holed Swiss cheese.
Efficacious: Possessing the quality of being effective; productive of, or powerful to produce, the effect intended; as, an efficacious law.
Endocardium: The membrane lining the cavities of the heart.
Etherin: A white, crystalline hydrocarbon, regarded as a polymeric variety of ethylene, obtained in heavy oil of wine, the residue left after making ether; -- formerly called also concrete oil of wine.
Eternal: One of the appellations of God.
Empawn: To put in pawn; to pledge; to impawn.
Erythema: A disease of the skin, in which a diffused inflammation forms rose-colored patches of variable size.
Earcap: A cap or cover to protect the ear from cold.
Encyclic: An encyclical letter, esp. one from a pope.
enrollee: one who is enrolled, especially a learner who enrolls in (or is enrolled in) a class or course of study.
Embarkation: The act of putting or going on board of a vessel; as, the embarkation of troops.
Ethionic: Pertaining to, derived from, or designating, an acid so called.
Estrepe: To strip or lay bare, as land of wood, houses, etc.; to commit waste.
Elecampane: A large, coarse herb (Inula Helenium), with composite yellow flowers. The root, which has a pungent taste, is used as a tonic, and was formerly of much repute as a stomachic.
Element: To compound of elements or first principles.
Ethnology: The science which treats of the division of mankind into races, their origin, distribution, and relations, and the peculiarities which characterize them.
Electrograph: A mark, record, or tracing, made by the action of electricity.
Euxenite: A brownish black mineral with a metallic luster, found in Norway. It contains niobium, titanium, yttrium, and uranium, with some other metals.
Entry: The act of entering or passing into or upon; entrance; ingress; hence, beginnings or first attempts; as, the entry of a person into a house or city; the entry of a river into the sea; the entry of air into the blood; an entry upon an undertaking.
Englue: To join or close fast together, as with glue; as, a coffer well englued.
Empyrical: Containing the combustible principle of coal.
Essay: To exert one's power or faculties upon; to make an effort to perform; to attempt; to endeavor; to make experiment or trial of; to try.
Empalement: A fencing, inclosing, or fortifying with stakes.
Emblazoning: The act or art of heraldic decoration; delineation of armorial bearings.
Eavedrop: A drop from the eaves; eavesdrop.
Executive: An impersonal title of the chief magistrate or officer who administers the government, whether king, president, or governor; the governing person or body.
elkhound: a breed of compact medium-sized dog with a heavy gray coat developed in Norway for hunting elk.
Excern: To excrete; to throw off through the pores; as, fluids are excerned in perspiration.
Epicycle: A circle, whose center moves round in the circumference of a greater circle; or a small circle, whose center, being fixed in the deferent of a planet, is carried along with the deferent, and yet, by its own peculiar motion, carries the body of the planet fastened to it round its proper center.
Explicate: To unfold; to expand; to lay open.
Envoyship: The office or position of an envoy.
Exsputory: Spit out, or as if spit out.
Exequial: Of or pertaining to funerals; funereal.
exit poll: a survey poll taken by interviewing voters as they leave (exit) the polling place, to determine how they voted and for what reasons; -- it is usually taken by news media to learn at an early time (often before the balloting has finished) who the winners are, and sometimes the reasons for the voters' choices.
Erotesis: A figure of speech by which a strong affirmation of the contrary, is implied under the form of an earnest interrogation, as in the following lines; -
Exterritorial: Beyond the territorial limits; foreign to, or exempt from, the territorial jurisdiction.
Ear-minded: Thinking chiefly or most readily through, or in terms related to, the sense of hearing; specif., thinking words as spoken, as a result of familiarity with speech or of mental peculiarity; -- opposed to eye-minded.
eye-catcher: An object or person that seizes the attention; as, her Statue of Liberty outfit was an eye-catcher.
Equimultiple: One of the products arising from the multiplication of two or more quantities by the same number or quantity. Thus, seven times 2, or  14, and seven times 4, or 28, are equimultiples of 2 and 4.
Eulogic: Bestowing praise of eulogy; commendatory; eulogistic.
Eosaurus: An extinct marine reptile from the coal measures of Nova Scotia; -- so named because supposed to be of the earliest known reptiles.
Embroidery: Needlework used to enrich textile fabrics, leather, etc.; also, the art of embroidering.
Entrochite: A fossil joint of a crinoid stem.
Eubacteriales: one of two usually recognized orders of true bacteria; gram-positive spherical or rod-shaped forms; some are motile; in some classifications it is considered an order of Schizomycetes.
Essene: One of a sect among the Jews in the time of our Savior, remarkable for their strictness and abstinence.
Electro-therapeutics: The branch of medical science which treats of the applications agent.
Elver: A young eel; a young conger or sea eel; -- called also elvene.
Eyeglass: A lens of glass worn in front of the eye to assist vision; -- usually used in the plural, referring to a pair of lenses fixed together in a frame, and worn resting on the bridge of the nose, to improve the vision. A single eyeglass in a frame is called a monocle.
Exoskeleton: The hardened parts of the external integument of an animal, including hair, feathers, nails, horns, scales, etc.,as well as the armor of armadillos and many reptiles, and the shells or hardened integument of numerous invertebrates; external skeleton; dermoskeleton.
Ean: To bring forth, as young; to yean.
Exopodite: The external branch of the appendages of Crustacea.
Epanthous: Growing upon flowers; -- said of certain species of fungi.
Expiratory: Pertaining to, or employed in, the expiration or emission of air from the lungs; as, the expiratory muscles.
Efflux: To run out; to flow forth; to pass away.
Evil: In an evil manner; not well; ill; badly; unhappily; injuriously; unkindly.
Excruciation: The act of inflicting agonizing pain, or the state of being thus afflicted; that which excruciates; torture.
Estacade: A dike of piles in the sea, a river, etc., to check the approach of an enemy.
Everywhere: In every place; in all places; hence, in every part; thoroughly; altogether.
Ear: To plow or till; to cultivate.
Eat: To take food; to feed; especially, to take solid, in distinction from liquid, food; to board.
Emancipationist: An advocate of emancipation, esp. the emancipation of slaves.
Environs: The parts or places which surround another place, or lie in its neighborhood; suburbs; as, the environs of a city or town.
Enmity: The quality of being an enemy; hostile or unfriendly disposition.
Emphyteusis: A real right, susceptible of assignment and of descent, charged on productive real estate, the right being coupled with the enjoyment of the property on condition of taking care of the estate and paying taxes, and sometimes a small rent.
Exudate: A product of exudation; an exuded substance.
Elaps: A genus of venomous snakes found both in America and the Old World. Many species are known. See Coral snake, under Coral.
Ecteron: The external layer of the skin and mucous membranes; epithelium; ecderon.
Exhaustless: Not be exhausted; inexhaustible; as, an exhaustless fund or store.
Eumycetes: a class used in some classifications, which is coextensive with the division Eumycota.
Entire-wheat: Designating, made of, or relating to, flour including a considerable part of the bran; whole-wheat.
Exsiccate: To exhaust or evaporate moisture from; to dry up.
Enamelar: Consisting of enamel; resembling enamel; smooth; glossy.
Erythroid: Of a red color; reddish; as, the erythroid tunic (the cremaster muscle).
Epicureanism: Attachment to the doctrines of Epicurus; the principles or belief of Epicurus.
Egoistic: Pertaining to egoism; imbued with egoism or excessive thoughts of self; self-loving.
Equanimous: Of an even, composed frame of mind; of a steady temper; not easily elated or depressed.
Excrementitial: Pertaining to, or consisting of, excrement; of the nature of excrement.
Entity: A real being, whether in thought (as an ideal conception) or in fact; being; essence; existence.
Ember-goose: The loon or great northern diver. See Loon.
Endeavor: An exertion of physical or intellectual strength toward the attainment of an object; a systematic or continuous attempt; an effort; a trial.
Egret: The name of several species of herons which bear plumes on the back. They are generally white. Among the best known species are the American egret (Ardea egretta syn. Herodias egretta); the great egret (Ardea alba); the little egret (Ardea garzetta), of Europe; and the American snowy egret (Ardea candidissima).
Endodermal: Of or pertaining to the endoderm.
Endocyst: The inner layer of the cells of Bryozoa.
exposed: with no protection or shield; as, the exposed northeast frontier.
Ease: To free from anything that pains, disquiets, or oppresses; to relieve from toil or care; to give rest, repose, or tranquillity to; -- often with of; as, to ease of pain; to ease the body or mind.
Elephant: A mammal of the order Proboscidia and family Elephantidae, of which two living species, Elephas maximus (formerly Elephas Indicus) and Loxodonta Africana (formerly E. Africanus), and several fossil species, are known. They have five toes, a long proboscis or trunk, and two large ivory tusks proceeding from the extremity of the upper jaw, and curving upwards. The molar teeth are large and have transverse folds. Elephants are the largest land animals now existing.  The elephant is classed as a pachyderm.
Extensively: To a great extent; widely; largely; as, a story is extensively circulated.
Exaration: Act of plowing; also, act of writing.
Ewer: A kind of wide-mouthed pitcher or jug; esp., one used to hold water for the toilet.
Eosphorite: A hydrous phosphate of alumina and manganese. It is generally of a rose-pink color, -- whence the name.
Euphemize: To express by a euphemism, or in delicate language; to make use of euphemistic expressions.
Earthboard: The part of a plow, or other implement, that turns over the earth; the moldboard.
Easy: At ease; free from pain, trouble, or constraint
Endorse: A subordinary, resembling the pale, but of one fourth its width (according to some writers, one eighth).
Endospore: The thin inner coat of certain spores.
East: To move toward the east; to veer from the north or south toward the east; to orientate.
Elance: To throw as a lance; to hurl; to dart.
Eruginous: Partaking of the substance or nature of copper, or of the rust of copper; resembling the rust of copper or verdigris; æruginous.
Excitant: An agent or influence which arouses vital activity, or produces increased action, in a living organism or in any of its tissues or parts; a stimulant.
Experimenter: One who makes experiments; one skilled in experiments.
Entombment: The act of entombing or burying, or state of being entombed; burial.
Ethmovomerine: Pertaining to the region of the vomer and the base of the ethmoid in the skull.
Egad: An exclamation expressing exultation or surprise, etc.
entrepreneurial: of or pertaining to an entrepreneur or entrepreneurship; as, entrepreneurial risks.
Extense: Outreaching; expansive; extended, superficially or otherwise.
euphoriant: a substance which may induce euporia.
elasticized: made with strands or inserts of elastic, allowing it to stretch; -- of fabrics; as, slacks with an elasticized waistband.
Explodent: An instrument or agent causing explosion; an exploder; also, an explosive.
Epicranial: Pertaining to the epicranium; as, epicranial muscles.
Elemin: A transparent, colorless oil obtained from elemi resin by distillation with water; also, a crystallizable extract from the resin.
Embolismic: Pertaining to embolism or intercalation; intercalated; as, an embolismic year, i. e., the year in which there is intercalation.
edited: improved or corrected by critical editing.
Execratory: Of the nature of execration; imprecatory; denunciatory.
Exaggerated: Enlarged beyond bounds or the truth.
Errhine: A medicine designed to be snuffed up the nose, to promote discharges of mucus; a sternutatory.
Eon: An immeasurable or infinite space of time; eternity; a long space of time; an age.
Encroacher: One who by gradual steps enters on, and takes possession of, what is not his own.
Elector: Pertaining to an election or to electors.
Erodent: A medicine which eats away extraneous growths; a caustic.
eutectic: a mixture of substances having a composition providing the minimum melting point ofr mixtures of those substances.  Called also a eutectic mixture.
Extensibility: The quality of being extensible; the capacity of being extended; as, the extensibility of a fiber, or of a plate of metal.
Expertly: In a skillful or dexterous manner; adroitly; with readiness and accuracy.
Echidnine: The clear, viscid fluid secreted by the poison glands of certain serpents; also, a nitrogenous base contained in this, and supposed to be the active poisonous principle of the virus.
eleven-plus: an examination taken by 11 and 12 year old students in England to select suitable candidates for grammar school; -- now no longer used.
Enthronize: To place on a throne; hence, to induct into office, as a bishop.
Esparto: A species of Spanish grass (Macrochloa tenacissima), of which cordage, shoes, baskets, etc., are made. It is also used for making paper.
Extravasate: To pass by infiltration or effusion from the normal channel, such as a blood vessel or a lymphatic, into the surrounding tissue; -- said of blood, lymph, etc.
Emotive: Attended by, or having the character of, emotion.
Equatorially: So as to have motion or direction parallel to the equator.
Exasperater: One who exasperates or inflames anger, enmity, or violence.
exercisable: That may be exercised, used, or exerted; as, the stock options are exercisable for only five years from the date of issue.
Enteradenology: The science which treats of the glands of the alimentary canal.
Electrolyte: A compound decomposable, or subjected to decomposition, by an electric current.
Extirpate: To pluck up by the stem or root; to root out; to eradicate, literally or figuratively; to destroy wholly; as, to extirpate weeds; to extirpate a tumor; to extirpate a sect; to extirpate error or heresy.
energy-absorbing: capable of absorbing energy; as, energy-absorbing bumpers reduce injury and damage in vehicle collisions.
elongated: having a length noticeably longer than the width.
Endecagynous: Having eleven pistils; as, an endecagynous flower.
Euplexoptera: An order of insects, including the earwig. The anterior wings are short, in the form of elytra, while the posterior wings fold up beneath them. See Earwig.
Enteradenography: A treatise upon, or description of, the intestinal glands.
Enthrone: To seat on a throne; to exalt to the seat of royalty or of high authority; hence, to invest with sovereign authority or dignity.
Egestion: Act or process of egesting; a voiding.
Epichordal: Upon or above the notochord; -- applied esp. to a vertebral column which develops upon the dorsal side of the notochord, as distinguished from a perichordal column, which develops around it.
ecobabble: using the technical language of ecology to make the user seem ecologically aware.
Exegetic: Pertaining to exegesis; tending to unfold or illustrate; explanatory; expository.
Emmenagogue: A medicine that promotes the menstrual discharge.
Eanling: A lamb just brought forth; a yeanling.
Estoile: A six-pointed star whose rays are wavy, instead of straight like those of a mullet.
Epigenetic: Of or pertaining to the epigenesis; produced according to the theory of epigenesis.
Efforce: To force; to constrain; to compel to yield.
Exordial: Pertaining to the exordium of a discourse: introductory.
Encomium: Warm or high praise; panegyric; strong commendation.
Emulative: Inclined to emulation; aspiring to competition; rivaling; as, an emulative person or effort.
Epicoele: A cavity formed by the invagination of the outer wall of the body, as the atrium of an amphioxus and possibly the body cavity of vertebrates.
Endermic: Acting through the skin, or by direct application to the skin.
Exorbitate: To go out of the track; to deviate.
Eddy kite: A quadrilateral, tailless kite, with convex surfaces exposed to the wind. This kite was extensively used by Eddy in his famous meteorological experiments. It is now generally superseded by the box kite.
Eponym: The hypothetical individual who is assumed as the person from whom any race, city, etc., took its name; as, Hellen is an eponym of the Hellenes.
Escalop: A bivalve shell of the genus Pecten. See Scallop.
Excite: To call to activity in any way; to rouse to feeling; to kindle to passionate emotion; to stir up to combined or general activity; as, to excite a person, the spirits, the passions; to excite a mutiny or insurrection; to excite heat by friction.
Esculin: A glucoside obtained from the Æsculus hippocastanum, or horse-chestnut, and characterized by its fine blue fluorescent solutions.
Eburnification: The conversion of certain substances into others which have the appearance or characteristics of ivory.
Eradiate: To shoot forth, as rays of light; to beam; to radiate.
Easel: A frame (commonly) of wood serving to hold a canvas upright, or nearly upright, for the painter's convenience or for exhibition.
Exchanger: One who exchanges; one who practices exchange.
Egregious: Surpassing; extraordinary; distinguished (in a bad sense); -- formerly used with words importing a good quality, but now joined with words having a bad sense; as, an egregious rascal; an egregious ass; an egregious mistake.
Elide: To break or dash in pieces; to demolish; as, to elide the force of an argument.
Extraphysical: Not subject to physical laws or methods.
Excoct: To boil out; to produce by boiling.
Episcopate: To act as a bishop; to fill the office of a prelate.
Erlking: A personification, in German and Scandinavian mythology, of a spirit or natural power supposed to work mischief and ruin, esp. to children.
Encyclopedia: The circle of arts and sciences; a comprehensive summary of knowledge, or of a branch of knowledge; esp., a work in which the various branches of science or art are discussed separately, and usually in alphabetical order; a cyclopedia.
Eremacausis: A gradual oxidation from exposure to air and moisture, as in the decay of old trees or of dead animals.
Encyclopedic: Pertaining to, or of the nature of, an encyclopedia; broad in scope or content; embracing a wide range of subjects; as, a person having encyclopedic knowledge of a subject.
Entrap: To catch in a trap; to insnare; hence, to catch, as in a trap, by artifices; to involve in difficulties or distresses; to catch or involve in contradictions; as, to be entrapped by the devices of evil men.
endpoint: A point of termination or completion.
Expanding: That expands, or may be expanded; extending; spreading; enlarging.
Escarp: To make into, or furnish with, a steep slope, like that of a scrap.
Equilibrate: To balance two scales, sides, or ends; to keep even with equal weight on each side; to keep in equipoise.
Embracery: An attempt to influence a court, jury, etc., corruptly, by promises, entreaties, money, entertainments, threats, or other improper inducements.
Emplaster: To plaster over; to cover over so as to present a good appearance.
Elementalism: The theory that the heathen divinities originated in the personification of elemental powers.
Excelsior: A kind of stuffing for upholstered furniture, mattresses, etc., in which curled shreds of wood are substituted for curled hair.
Eurasiatio: Of or pertaining to the continents of Europe and Asia combined.
Elephantine: Pertaining to the elephant, or resembling an elephant (commonly, in size); hence, huge; immense; heavy; as, of elephantine proportions; an elephantine step or tread.
Espadon: A long, heavy, two-handed and two-edged sword, formerly used by Spanish foot soldiers and by executioners.
Enactment: The passing of a bill into a law; the giving of legislative sanction and executive approval to a bill whereby it is established as a law.
Epilogic: Of or pertaining to an epilogue.
Enjail: To put into jail; to imprison.
Exaggeratory: Containing, or tending to, exaggeration; exaggerative.
Exaspidean: Having the anterior scutes extending around the tarsus on the outer side, leaving the inner side naked; -- said of certain birds.
Egyptologer: One skilled in the antiquities of Egypt; a student of Egyptology.
Eurypterus: A genus of extinct Merostomata, found in Silurian rocks. Some of the species are more than three feet long.
eucalyptol: A volatile, terpenelike oil (C10H18O), which is the main constituent of the oil of eucalyptus.  It has cockroach repellent activity and is used as a flavoring aid in pharmaceuticals.  Chemically it is 1,3,3-trimethyl-2-oxabicyclo-[2,2,2]-octane.
Engrave: To cut in; to make by incision.
Evidential: Relating to, or affording, evidence; indicative; especially, relating to the evidences of Christianity.
Extrafoliaceous: Away from the leaves, or inserted in a different place from them; as, extrafoliaceous prickles.
Evenness: The state of being ven, level, or disturbed; smoothness; horizontal position; uniformity; impartiality; calmness; equanimity; appropriate place or level; as, evenness of surface, of a fluid at rest, of motion, of dealings, of temper, of condition.
electron-volt: a unit of energy, being equal to the kinetic energy acquired by an electron when accelerated through a potential difference of one volt.  It is equal to 1.602 x 10-19 Joules.  It is abbreviated eV.
Exploiture: The act of exploiting or accomplishing; achievement.
Etherealize: To convert into ether, or into subtile fluid; to saturate with ether.
Edging: That which forms an edge or border, as the fringe, trimming, etc., of a garment, or a border in a garden.
Endogenous: Increasing by internal growth and elongation at the summit, instead of externally, and having no distinction of pith, wood, and bark, as the rattan, the palm, the cornstalk.
earpiece: a device for converting electric signals into sounds, designed to be held over or inserted into the ear; as, The common telephone handset has a speaker and an earpiece.
Eucrasy: Such a due mixture of qualities in bodies as constitutes health or soundness.
Extravasation: The act of forcing or letting out of its proper vessels or ducts, as a fluid; effusion; as, an extravasation of blood after a rupture of the vessels.
emancipated: free from traditional social restraints; -- used especially of women; as, an emancipated young woman pursuing her career.
Eliquation: The process of separating a fusible substance from one less fusible, by means of a degree of heat sufficient to melt the one and not the other, as an alloy of copper and lead; liquation.
Exclusionism: The character, manner, or principles of an exclusionist.
Eternization: The act of eternizing; the act of rendering immortal or famous.
Electron: Amber; also, the alloy of gold and silver, called electrum.
Elucidative: Making clear; tending to elucidate; as, an elucidative note.
Embasement: Act of bringing down; depravation; deterioration.
Ecthyma: A cutaneous eruption, consisting of large, round pustules, upon an indurated and inflamed base.
Exemplify: To show or illustrate by example.
Emetine: A white crystalline bitter alkaloid extracted from ipecacuanha root, and regarded as its peculiar emetic principle.
Esophagotomy: The operation of making an incision into the esophagus, for the purpose of removing any foreign substance that obstructs the passage.
Easily: With ease; without difficulty or much effort; as, this task may be easily performed; that event might have been easily foreseen.
Ebrious: Inclined to drink to excess; intoxicated; tipsy.
Elusive: Tending to elude; using arts or deception to escape; adroitly escaping or evading; eluding the grasp; fallacious.
Enterology: The science which treats of the viscera of the body.
Erse: Of or pertaining to the Celtic race in the Highlands of Scotland, or to their language.
entrepreneurship: the activity of organizing, managing, and assuming the risks of a business enterprise.
Epipolized: Changed to the epipolic condition, or that in which the phenomenon of fluorescence is presented; produced by fluorescence; as, epipolized light.
Elysium: A dwelling place assigned to happy souls after death; the seat of future happiness; Paradise.
Excoction: The act of excocting or boiling out.
Epilogistic: Of or pertaining to epilogue; of the nature of an epilogue.
Emir: An Arabian military commander, independent chieftain, or ruler of a province; also, an honorary title given to the descendants of Mohammed, in the line of his daughter Fatima; among the Turks, likewise, a title of dignity, given to certain high officials.
Emit: To send forth; to throw or give out; to cause to issue; to give vent to; to eject; to discharge; as, fire emits heat and smoke; boiling water emits steam; the sun emits light.
\u00c9coute: One of the small galleries run out in front of the glacis. They serve to annoy the enemy's miners.
Ejectment: A casting out; a dispossession; an expulsion; ejection; as, the ejectment of tenants from their homes.
Enclitic: A word which is joined to another so closely as to lose its proper accent, as the pronoun thee in prithee (pray thee).
Excessive: Characterized by, or exhibiting, excess; overmuch.
Enteroc\u0153le: A perivisceral cavity which arises as an outgrowth or outgrowths from the digestive tract; distinguished from a schizocœle, which arises by a splitting of the mesoblast of the embryo.
Extrude: To thrust out; to force, press, or push out; to expel; to drive off or away.
Electro-: A prefix or combining form signifying pertaining to electricity, produced by electricity, producing or employing electricity, etc.; as, electro-negative; electro-dynamic; electro-magnet.
Epithelial: Of or pertaining to epithelium; as, epithelial cells; epithelial cancer.
ego: The conscious and permanent subject of all psychical experiences, whether held to be directly known or the product of reflective thought; the subject consciously considered as “I” by a person; -- opposed to non-ego.
Eavesdropping: The habit of lurking about dwelling houses, and other places where persons meet for private intercourse, secretly listening to what is said, and then tattling it abroad. The offense is indictable at common law.
Euthanasia: An easy death; a mode of dying to be desired.
encased: covered or protected with or as if with a case; as, products encased in leatherette.
escape velocity: The minimum velocity at which an object must be moving in order for it to overcome the gravitational attraction of a massive celestial body, such as the earth or the sun, and escape beyond its gravitational field into free space.  The velocity is calculated as though attained instantaneously at the surface of the celestial body, and is pointed directly away from its center, and neglecting effects of atmospheric friction.  Rockets, which accelerate gradually and are moving rapidly at a high altitude when their fuel is exhausted or their engines shut off, may escape even if moving slightly slower at that point than the surface escape velocity.  Compare orbital velocity.
Entablature: The superstructure which lies horizontally upon the columns. See Illust. of Column, Cornice.
Expurgatory: Serving to purify from anything noxious or erroneous; cleansing; purifying.
Extrinsicality: The state or quality of being extrinsic.
Emulgent: A medicine that excites the flow of bile.
eye-deceiving: creating the illusion of seeing reality.
Erosive: That erodes or gradually eats away; tending to erode; corrosive.
Erysipelatous: Resembling erysipelas, or partaking of its nature.
Ergotized: Affected with the ergot fungus; as, ergotized rye.
Ento-: A combining form signifying within; as, entoblast.
Extensive: Having wide extent; of much superficial extent; expanded; large; broad; wide; comprehensive; as, an extensive farm; an extensive lake; an extensive sphere of operations; extensive benevolence; extensive greatness.
Expurgation: The act of expurgating, purging, or cleansing; purification from anything noxious, offensive, sinful, or erroneous.
Eternalist: One who holds the existence of matter to be from eternity.
Exclusivist: One who favor or practices any from of exclusiveness or exclusivism.
Euhemerism: The theory, held by Euhemerus, that the gods of mythology were but deified mortals, and their deeds only the amplification in imagination of human acts.
Essoiner: An attorney who sufficiently excuses the absence of another.
emaciated: having become so thin that the bones noticeably protude under the skin; as, emaciated bony hands.
Excellently: In an excellent manner; well in a high degree.
Enclave: To inclose within an alien territory.
Equivalent: To make the equivalent to; to equal; equivalence.
Emissive: Sending out; emitting; as, emissive powers.
Encashment: The payment in cash of a note, draft, etc.
Endoplastica: A group of Rhizopoda having a distinct nucleus, as the amœba.
Entad: Toward the inside or central part; away from the surface; -- opposed to ectad.
Experimental: Pertaining to experiment; founded on, or derived from, experiment or trial; as, experimental science; given to, or skilled in, experiment; as, an experimental philosopher.
Enduring: Lasting; durable; long-suffering; as, an enduring disposition.
Effrontery: Impudence or boldness in confronting or in transgressing the bounds of duty or decorum; insulting presumptuousness; shameless boldness; barefaced assurance.
Enfranchise: To set free; to liberate from slavery, prison, or any binding power.
Enjoy: To take satisfaction; to live in happiness.
Episcopalianism: The doctrine and usages of Episcopalians; episcopacy.
Excoriate: To strip or wear off the skin of; to abrade; to gall; to break and remove the cuticle of, in any manner, as by rubbing, beating, or by the action of acrid substances.
Err: To wander; to roam; to stray.
Entomophthorales: an order of fungi coextensive with the family Entomophthoraceae.
Epicranium: The upper and superficial part of the head, including the scalp, muscles, etc.
Electro-negative: A body which passes to the positive pole in electrolysis; an anion.
Enterotomy: Incision of the intestines, especially in reducing certain cases of hernia.
Erf: A garden plot, usually about half an acre.
Erg: The unit of work or energy in the C. G. S. system, being the amount of work done by a dyne working through a distance of one centimeter; the amount of energy expended in moving a body one centimeter against a force of one dyne (981 dynes exert the same force as a one gram mass in the earth's gravitational field). One foot pound is equal to 13,560,000 ergs.  The absolute Joule is equivalent to 107 ergs, which are equivalent to 0.2389 gram-calories at 15° C.  See also mechanical equivalent of heat under equivalent.
Era: A fixed point of time, usually an epoch, from which a series of years is reckoned.
Euphorbium: An inodorous exudation, usually in the form of yellow tears, produced chiefly by the African Euphorbia resinifera. It was formerly employed medicinally, but was found so violent in its effects that its use is nearly abandoned.
Ern: To stir with strong emotion; to grieve; to mourn. [Corrupted into yearn in modern editions of Shakespeare.]
embezzled: taken for one's own use in violation of a trust; -- of money; as, the banker absconded with embezzled payroll; the embezzled funds amounted to millions of dollars.
Empressement: Demonstrative warmth or cordiality of manner; display of enthusiasm.
Emollition: The act of softening or relaxing; relaxation.
Erewhon: the fictitious land described in the novel Erewhon by Samuel Butler.
expansivity: the fractional change in length or area or volume per unit change in temperature at a given constant pressure.
Ergotism: A diseased condition produced by eating rye affected with the ergot fungus.
Expectant: One who waits in expectation; one held in dependence by hope of receiving some good.
Epididymitis: Inflammation of the epididymis, one of the common results of gonorrhea.
Edulcoration: The act of sweetening or edulcorating.
evasiveness: Deliberate vagueness or ambiguity; failing to answer a question while trying to seem as though one is answering.
Enthronization: The act of enthroning; hence, the admission of a bishop to his stall or throne in his cathedral.
Entireness: The state or condition of being entire; completeness; fullness; totality; as, the entireness of an arch or a bridge.
Epitrochoid: A kind of curve. See Epicycloid, any Trochoid.
Estrange: To withdraw; to withhold; hence, reflexively, to keep at a distance; to cease to be familiar and friendly with.
Episodial: Pertaining to an episode; by way of episode; episodic.
Epaulet: A shoulder ornament or badge worn by military and naval officers, differences of rank being marked by some peculiar form or device, as a star, eagle, etc.; a shoulder knot.
End: To come to the ultimate point; to be finished; to come to a close; to cease; to terminate; as, a voyage ends; life ends; winter ends.
Emigrationist: An advocate or promoter of emigration.
Emburse: To furnish with money; to imburse.
Excreate: To spit out; to discharge from the throat by hawking and spitting.
Execrable: Deserving to be execrated; accursed; damnable; detestable; abominable; as, an execrable wretch.
Ens: Entity, being, or existence; an actually existing being; also, God, as the Being of Beings.
Entoperipheral: Being, or having its origin, within the external surface of the body; -- especially applied to feelings, such as hunger, produced by internal disturbances. Opposed to epiperipheral.
Epigraphist: A student of, or one versed in, epigraphy.
Emollient: An external something or soothing application to allay irritation, soreness, etc.
edged: having a specified kind of border or edge; as, a black-edged card; dried sweat left salt-edged patches.
Essorant: Standing, but with the wings spread, as if about to fly; -- said of a bird borne as a charge on an escutcheon.
Erosion: The act or operation of eroding or eating away.
Entastic: Relating to any disease characterized by tonic spasms.
E-: A Latin prefix meaning out, out of, from; also, without. See Ex-.
Enable: To give strength or ability to; to make firm and strong.
Entogastric: Pertaining to the interior of the stomach; -- applied to a mode of budding from the interior of the gastric cavity, in certain hydroids.
Embroilment: The act of embroiling, or the condition of being embroiled; entanglement in a broil.
Earth flax: A variety of asbestus. See Amianthus.
Evaluate: To fix the value of; to rate; to appraise.
Endosteal: Relating to endostosis; as, endosteal ossification.
engrossing: capable of holding the attention completely; very interesting.
Eight: The number greater by a unit than seven; eight units or objects.
Expectable: That may be expected or looked for.
Evolutionism: The theory of, or belief in, evolution. See Evolution, 6 and 7.
Epileptogenous: Producing epilepsy or epileptoid convulsions; -- applied to areas of the body or of the nervous system, stimulation of which produces convulsions.
Equivocation: The use of expressions susceptible of a double signification, with a purpose to mislead.
Easement: That which gives ease, relief, or assistance; convenience; accommodation.
Exeunt: They go out, or retire from the scene; as, exeunt all except Hamlet. See 1st Exit.
Ecclesiasticism: Strong attachment to ecclesiastical usages, forms, etc.
Estufa: An assembly room in dwelling of the Pueblo Indians.
Equation: A making equal; equal division; equality; equilibrium.
En-: A prefix signifying in or into, used in many English words, chiefly those borrowed from the French. Some English words are written indifferently with en-or in-. For ease of pronunciation it is commonly changed to em-before p, b, and m, as in employ, embody, emmew. It is sometimes used to give a causal force, as in enable, enfeeble, to cause to be, or to make, able, or feeble; and sometimes merely gives an intensive force, as in enchasten. See In-.
enveloping: the act or process of enclosing something inside something else.
Ecbole: A digression in which a person is introduced speaking his own words.
Eupepsia: Soundness of the nutritive or digestive organs; good concoction or digestion; -- opposed to dyspepsia.
Engagedness: The state of being deeply interested; earnestness; zeal.
Exculpation: The act of exculpating from alleged fault or crime; that which exculpates; excuse.
Em: The portion of a line formerly occupied by the letter m, then a square type, used as a unit by which to measure the amount of printed matter on a page; the square of the body of a type.
Emanatory: Emanative; of the nature of an emanation.
En: Half an em, that is, half of the unit of space in measuring printed matter. See Em.
Erwinia: a genus of rod-shaped motile bacteria, classed among the Enterobacteriaceae, that may attack plants.  Species of Erwinia may also be cultured on artificial growth media.
Eh: An expression of inquiry or slight surprise.
Erythrodextrin: A dextrin which gives a red color with iodine. See Dextrin.
Ea: the Akkadian god of wisdom; son of Apsu and father of Marduk; counterpart of the Sumerian Enki.
Eriosoma: a genus of plant lice of the family Aphididae, consisting of one type of the wooly aphids.
Exprobrate: To charge upon with reproach; to upbraid.
Ecphractic: Serving to dissolve or attenuate viscid matter, and so to remove obstructions; deobstruent.
Enlace: To bind or encircle with lace, or as with lace; to lace; to encircle; to enfold; hence, to entangle.
Eczema: An inflammatory disease of the skin, characterized by the presence of redness and itching, an eruption of small vesicles, and the discharge of a watery exudation, which often dries up, leaving the skin covered with crusts; -- called also tetter, milk crust, and salt rheum.
Eu: A prefix used frequently in composition, signifying well, good, advantageous; -- the opposite of dys-.
Economist: One who economizes, or manages domestic or other concerns with frugality; one who expends money, time, or labor, judiciously, and without waste.
Es: the chemical symbol for einsteinium, a transuranic element with atomic number 99.  The atomic weight of the longest-lived isotope, with a half-life of 276 days, is 254.  The first isotope discovered, having atomic weight 253 and a half-life of 20 days, was recognized in 1952 in the debris from a hydrogen bomb test.  As much as 3 micrograms of einsteinium were produced by a complex process involving long irradiation of plutonium isotopes in nuclear reactors.  Its chemical properties are those of a trivalent actinide element.
Embogue: To disembogue; to discharge, as a river, its waters into the sea or another river.
Entotic: Pertaining to the interior of the ear.
Excitative: Having power to excite; tending or serving to excite; excitatory.
Elastic: An elastic woven fabric, as a belt, braces or suspenders, etc., made in part of India rubber.
Expediential: Governed by expediency; seeking advantage; as an expediential policy.
Edenite: A variety of amphibole. See Amphibole.
Elastin: A nitrogenous substance, somewhat resembling albumin, which forms the chemical basis of elastic tissue. It is very insoluble in most fluids, but is gradually dissolved when digested with either pepsin or trypsin.
Epodic: Pertaining to, or resembling, an epode.
Earthnut: A name given to various roots, tubers, or pods grown under or on the ground
Emblazonry: The act or art of an emblazoner; heraldic or ornamental decoration, as pictures or figures on shields, standards, etc.; emblazonment.
Expressible: Capable of being expressed, squeezed out, shown, represented, or uttered.
Enwallow: To plunge into, or roll in, flith; to wallow.
Elaphure: A species of deer (Elaphurus Davidianus) found in china. It is about four feet high at the shoulder and has peculiar antlers.
euphoria: a strong pleasant feeling of well-being or happiness; it is often caused by attainment of a desired goal or other incident of accomplishment, but may irrationally accompany a pathological manic state.
Electro-physiology: That branch of physiology which treats of electric phenomena produced through physiological agencies; it is especially concerned with electrical impulses generated by and conducted between nerves.
Extravagantly: In an extravagant manner; wildly; excessively; profusely.
equating: the act of regarding as equal.
Editorially: In the manner or character of an editor or of an editorial article.
East Indian: Belonging to, or relating to, the East Indies.
Eating: The act of tasking food; the act of consuming or corroding.
efficiency apartment: a small apartment{4}, sometimes furnished, with minimal kitchen and bath facilities.  The unit may comprise a single room plus a bathroom, and the kitchen facilities are often open to the main room, or may form a small niche in a corner.  There are many variations of efficiency apartment, including some in which furnishings such as a bed may be pulled out from a wall recess and stored there again when not in use.  Also called an efficiency.
Endophyllous: Wrapped up within a leaf or sheath.
Enchantment: The act of enchanting; the production of certain wonderful effects by the aid of demons, or the agency of supposed spirits; the use of magic arts, spells, or charms; incantation.
Expounder: One who expounds or explains; an interpreter.
Erased: Rubbed or scraped out; effaced; obliterated.
Equivalve: Having the valves equal in size and from, as in most bivalve shells.
endangered species: A species of plant or animal that has declined in numbers to a point where further irreversible decline and extinction{3} has a significant chance.  Lists of endangered species are maintained by government agencies, and in many cases the killing of such species or destruction of their habitat is prohibited by law.
Emancipation: The act of setting free from the power of another, from slavery, subjection, dependence, or controlling influence; also, the state of being thus set free; the act or process of emancipation, or the state thereby achieved; liberation; as, the emancipation of slaves; the emancipation of minors; the emancipation of a person from prejudices; the emancipation of the mind from superstition; the emancipation of a nation from tyranny or subjection.
Entobronchium: One of the main bronchi in the lungs of birds.
expanded: increased in extent or size or bulk or scope.  Opposite of contracted.
Exorcise: To cast out, as a devil, evil spirits, etc., by conjuration or summoning by a holy name, or by certain ceremonies; to expel (a demon) or to conjure (a demon) to depart out of a person possessed by one.
El\u00e6optene: The more liquid or volatile portion of certain oily substance, as distinguished from stearoptene, the more solid parts.
Enstatite: A mineral of the pyroxene group, orthorhombic in crystallization; often fibrous and massive; color grayish white or greenish. It is a silicate of magnesia with some iron. Bronzite is a ferriferous variety.
Europeanize: To cause to become like the Europeans in manners or character; to habituate or accustom to European usages.
Exactor: One who exacts or demands by authority or right; hence, an extortioner; also, one unreasonably severe in injunctions or demands.
Examining: Having power to examine; appointed to examine; as, an examining committee.
Evulsion: The act of plucking out; a rooting out.
Extradictionary: Consisting not in words, but in realities.
Excepting: With rejection or exception of; excluding; except.
Exacting: Oppressive or unreasonably severe in making demands or requiring the exact fulfillment of obligations; harsh; severe.
Enervative: Having power, or a tendency, to enervate; weakening.
Elongation: The act of lengthening, or the state of being lengthened; protraction; extension.
Exequatur: A written official recognition of a consul or commercial agent, issued by the government to which he is accredited, and authorizing him to exercise his powers in the place to which he is assigned.
Exophthalmia: The protrusion of the eyeball so that the eyelids will not cover it, in consequence of disease.
Engaol: To put in jail; to imprison.
encompassing: closely enveloping or surrounding on all sides.
Encrimson: To give a crimson or red color to; to crimson.
Exude: To flow from a body through the pores, or by a natural discharge, as juice.
Eunomy: Equal law, or a well-adjusted constitution of government.
Express rifle: A sporting rifle for use at short ranges, employing a large charge of powder and a light (short) bullet, giving a high initial velocity and consequently a flat trajectory. It is usually of moderately large caliber.
Eyebright: A small annual plant (Euphrasia officinalis), formerly much used as a remedy for diseases of the eye.
Eagerness: The state or quality of being eager; ardent desire.
Equipment: The act of equipping, or the state of being equipped, as for a voyage or expedition.
Equator: The imaginary great circle on the earth's surface, everywhere equally distant from the two poles, and dividing the earth's surface into two hemispheres.
Eductor: One who, or that which, brings forth, elicits, or extracts.
Erebus: A place of nether darkness, being the gloomy space through which the souls passed to Hades. See Milton's “Paradise Lost,” Book II., line 883.
Electro-thermancy: That branch of electrical science which treats of the effect of an electric current upon the temperature of a conductor, or a part of a circuit composed of two different metals.
Enmesh: To catch or entangle in, or as in, meshes.
Effervescent: Gently boiling or bubbling, by means of the disengagement of gas
Escambio: A license formerly required for the making over a bill of exchange to another over sea.
Eucharis: A genus of South American amaryllidaceous plants with large and beautiful white blossoms.
Extinction: The act of extinguishing or making extinct; a putting an end to; the act of putting out or destroying light, fire, life, activity, influence, etc.
entranceway: a passage allowing entry or exit; an entryway.
Emulsion: Any liquid preparation of a color and consistency resembling milk; as: (a) In pharmacy, an extract of seeds, or a mixture of oil and water united by a mucilaginous substance. (b) In photography, a liquid preparation of collodion holding salt of silver, used in the photographic process.
Equilibrist: One who balances himself in unnatural positions and hazardous movements; a balancer.
Euonymus: A genus of small European and American trees; the spindle tree. The bark is used as a cathartic.
Estancia: A grazing farm; a country house.
Erythematic: Characterized by, or causing, a morbid redness of the skin; relating to erythema.
Elemental: Pertaining to the elements, first principles, and primary ingredients, or to the four supposed elements of the material world; as, elemental air.
Empirically: By experiment or experience; without science; in the manner of quacks.
Epaxial: Above, or on the dorsal side of, the axis of the skeleton; episkeletal.
Encave: To hide in, or as in, a cave or recess.
Enunciatory: Pertaining to, or containing, enunciation or utterance.
Eastward: Toward the east; in the direction of east from some point or place; as, New Haven lies eastward from New York.
Explosive: An explosive agent; a compound or mixture susceptible of a rapid chemical reaction, as gunpowder, TNT, dynamite, or nitro-glycerine.
evasion: The act of eluding or avoiding, particularly the pressure of an argument, accusation, charge, or interrogation; artful means of eluding.
empowered: invested with legal power or official authority especially as symbolized by having a scepter.
Ergograph: An instrument for measuring and recording the work done by a single muscle or set of muscles, the rate of fatigue, etc.
Entoptic: Relating to objects situated within the eye; esp., relating to the perception of objects in one's own eye.
Empiric: Pertaining to, or founded upon, experiment or experience; depending upon the observation of phenomena; versed in experiments.
Electro-magnet: A mass, usually of soft iron, but sometimes of some other magnetic metal, as nickel or cobalt, rendered temporarily magnetic by being placed within a coil of wire through which a current of electricity is passing. The metal is generally in the form of a bar, either straight, or bent into the shape of a horseshoe.
Equitable: Possessing or exhibiting equity; according to natural right or natural justice; marked by a due consideration for what is fair, unbiased, or impartial; just; as, an equitable decision; an equitable distribution of an estate; equitable men.
egg-shaped: Resembling an egg in form; ovoid.
Electrophone: An instrument for producing sound by means of electric currents.
Exstrophy: The eversion or turning out of any organ, or of its inner surface; as, exstrophy of the eyelid or of the bladder.
\u00c9cru: Having the color or appearance of unbleached stuff, as silk, linen, or the like.
Eelspear: A spear with barbed forks for spearing eels.
Erection: The act of erecting, or raising upright; the act of constructing, as a building or a wall, or of fitting together the parts of, as a machine; the act of founding or establishing, as a commonwealth or an office; also, the act of rousing to excitement or courage.
Easter lily: Any one of various lilies or lilylike flowers which bloom about Easter;
Eureka: The exclamation attributed to Archimedes, who is said to have cried out “Eureka! eureka!” (I have found it! I have found it!), upon suddenly discovering a method of finding out how much the gold of King Hiero's crown had been alloyed. Hence, an expression of triumph concerning a discovery.
Emersed: Standing out of, or rising above, water.
Ephor: A magistrate; one of a body of five magistrates chosen by the people of ancient Sparta. They exercised control even over the king.
Extemporize: To do, make, or utter extempore or off-hand; to prepare in great haste, under urgent necessity, or with scanty or unsuitable materials; as, to extemporize a dinner, a costume, etc.
Eggler: One who gathers, or deals in, eggs.
Equipensate: To weigh equally; to esteem alike.
Economically: With economy; with careful management; with prudence in expenditure.
Epworth League: A religious organization of Methodist young people, founded in 1889 at Cleveland, Ohio, and taking its name from John Wesley's birthplace, Epworth, Lincolnshire, England.
Eradicate: To pluck up by the roots; to root up; as, an oak tree eradicated.
Executorial: Of or pertaining to an executive.
Egypt: a country at the northeastern corner of Africa.  At one time it was joined with Syria to form the United Arab Republic.
Ectypal: Copied, reproduced as a molding or cast, in contradistinction from the original model.
Encouraging: Furnishing ground to hope; inspiriting; favoring.
Elogium: The praise bestowed on a person or thing; panegyric; eulogy.
Edge: To move sideways; to move gradually; as, edge along this way.
Episyllogism: A syllogism which assumes as one of its premises a proposition which was the conclusion of a preceding syllogism, called, in relation to this, the prosyllogism.
endoscopic: Of or pertaining to endoscopy or an endoscope.
Epithema: A horny excrescence upon the beak of birds.
end-user: a person who uses an item of commerce for its designed purpose; -- contrasted with those who produce or resell the item or incorporate the item into another product.
Engrail: To form an edging or border; to run in curved or indented lines.
Effectless: Without effect or advantage; useless; bootless.
Erato: The Muse who presided over lyric and amatory poetry.
Expressure: The act of expressing; expression; utterance; representation.
Effeminateness: The state of being effeminate; unmanly softness.
Extraversion: The act of throwing out; the state of being turned or thrown out.
Ergometer: A device for measuring, or an instrument for indicating, energy expended or work done; a dynamometer.
Echometer: A graduated scale for measuring the duration of sounds, and determining their different, and the relation of their intervals.
Epichirema: A syllogism in which the proof of the major or minor premise, or both, is introduced with the premises themselves, and the conclusion is derived in the ordinary manner.
Electro-telegraphic: Pertaining to the electric telegraph, or by means of it.
Eleutherodactylus: a genus of completely terrestrial robber frogs.
Embush: To place or hide in a thicket; to ambush.
Esculent: Anything that is fit for eating; that which may be safely eaten by man.
Ellagic: Pertaining to, or derived from, gallnuts or gallic acid; as, ellagic acid.
Elixate: To boil; to seethe; hence, to extract by boiling or seething.
Exanthesis: An eruption of the skin; cutaneous efflorescence.
enzyme: A protein produced by a living organism, capable of catalyzing a chemical reaction.  Almost all processes in living organisms require some form of enzyme to cause the reactions to occur at a rate sufficient to support life.  There are a very wide variety of enzymes, each specifically catalyzing a different chemical reaction, the sum of which cause the bulk of the physiological changes observed as life processes.  Enzymes, like most proteins, are synthesized by the protein-synthetic mechanism of the living cell, at special sites on ribosomes, using the genetic information in messenger RNA transcribed from the genetic instructions stored as nuleotide sequences in the DNA (or in some viruses, the RNA) of the genome.  Some examples of enzymes are: pepsin, diastase, rennet, DNA polymerase, invertase, glucose oxidase, protease, and ribonuclease.  There are many other types of enzyme.
Eikonogen: The sodium salt of a sulphonic acid of a naphthol, C10H5(OH)(NH2)SO3Na used as a developer.
Expressman: A person employed in the express business; also, the driver of a job wagon.
Erastian: One of the followers of Thomas Erastus, a German physician and theologian of the 16th century. He held that the punishment of all offenses should be referred to the civil power, and that holy communion was open to all. In the present day, an Erastian is one who would see the church placed entirely under the control of the State.
Ex parte: Upon or from one side only; one-sided; partial; as, an ex parte statement.
Emulous: Ambitiously desirous to equal or even to excel another; eager to emulate or vie with another; desirous of like excellence with another; -- with of; as, emulous of another's example or virtues.
Extrageneous: Belonging to another race or kind.
Epipharynx: A structure which overlaps the mouth of certain insects.
Emigrant: One who emigrates, or quits one country or region to settle in another.
Eucalyptus: A myrtaceous genus of trees, mostly Australian. Many of them grow to an immense height, one or two species exceeding the height even of the California Sequoia.
Eleemosynary: One who subsists on charity; a dependent.
Escutcheon: The surface, usually a shield, upon which bearings are marshaled and displayed. The surface of the escutcheon is called the field, the upper part is called the chief, and the lower part the base (see Chiff, and Field.). That side of the escutcheon which is on the right hand of the knight who bears the shield on his arm is called dexter, and the other side sinister.
Equivocal: A word or expression capable of different meanings; an ambiguous term; an equivoque.
Enamel: Relating to the art of enameling; as, enamel painting.
ethyl mercaptan: A gaseous substance (C2H5.SH) used as an odorant in natural gas and propane to facilitate detection and serve as a warning of leaks.
Exuviation: The rejecting or casting off of some part, more particularly, the outer cuticular layer, as the shells of crustaceans, skins of snakes, etc.; molting; ecdysis.
\u00c9corch\u00e9: A manikin, or image, representing an animal, especially man, with the skin removed so that the muscles are exposed for purposes of study.
Electrepeter: An instrument used to change the direction of electric currents; a commutator.
Emmanthe: a genus of plants consisting of one species, the yellow bells.
Efformation: The act of giving shape or form.
Enation: Any unusual outgrowth from the surface of a thing, as of a petal; also, the capacity or act of producing such an outgrowth.
Externally: In an external manner; outwardly; on the outside; in appearance; visibly.
Enchondroma: A cartilaginous tumor growing from the interior of a bone.
Expel: To drive or force out from that within which anything is contained, inclosed, or situated; to eject; as, to expel air from a bellows.
Endometrium: The membrane lining the inner surface of the uterus, or womb.
Empeople: To form into a people or community; to inhabit; to people.
Eryngo: A plant of the genus Eryngium.
Encephalology: The science which treats of the brain, its structure and functions.
Epideictic: Serving to show forth, explain, or exhibit; -- applied by the Greeks to a kind of oratory, which, by full amplification, seeks to persuade.
Encounterer: One who encounters; an opponent; an antagonist.
Enragement: Act of enraging or state of being enraged; excitement.
Eking: A lengthening or filling piece to make good a deficiency in length.
Emplace: To put into place or position; to fix on an emplacement.
Ewe-necked: Having a neck like a ewe; -- said of horses in which the arch of the neck is deficient, being somewhat hollowed out.
Equipollence: Equality of power, force, signification, or application.
Exposedness: The state of being exposed, laid open, or unprotected; as, an exposedness to sin or temptation.
Elephantiasis: A disease of the skin, in which it become enormously thickened, and is rough, hard, and fissured, like an elephant's hide.
Eyeservice: Service performed only under inspection, or the eye of an employer.
Elflock: Hair matted, or twisted into a knot, as if by elves.
Enchylemma: The basal substance of the cell nucleus; a hyaline or granular substance, more or less fluid during life, in which the other parts of the nucleus are imbedded.
enveloped: enclosed or surrounded completely; as, the fog-enveloped city.
Elbowchair: A chair with arms to support the elbows; an armchair.
Easterling: Relating to the money of the Easterlings, or Baltic traders. See Sterling.
Exaggeration: The act of heaping or piling up.
Electro-motive: Producing electro-motion; producing, or tending to produce, electricity or an electric current; causing electrical action or effects.
egocentrism: the personality trait that causes one to attempt to get personal recognition for oneself (especially by unacceptable means).
elderberry: The berrylike drupe of the elder. That of the Old World elder (Sambucus nigra) and that of the American sweet elder (S. Canadensis) are sweetish acid, and are eaten as a berry or made into wines or jellies.
Ergmeter: An instrument for measuring energy in ergs.
Exon: An officer of the Yeomen of the Guard; an Exempt.
establishmentarian: One who regards the Church primarily as an establishment formed by the State, and overlooks its intrinsic spiritual character.
Euphonious: Pleasing or sweet in sound; euphonic; smooth-sounding.
Exodus: A going out; particularly (the Exodus), the going out or journey of the Israelites from Egypt under the conduct of Moses; and hence, any large migration from a place.
Ex libris: An inscription, label, or the like, in a book indicating its ownership; esp., a bookplate.
Eruca: An insect in the larval state; a caterpillar; a larva.
Ebullience: A boiling up or over; effervescence.
Effulgence: The state of being effulgent; extreme brilliancy; a flood of light; great luster or brightness; splendor.
Elementary: Having only one principle or constituent part; consisting of a single element; simple; uncompounded; as, an elementary substance.
Effigiation: The act of forming in resemblance; an effigy.
Elfish: Of or relating to the elves; elflike; implike; weird; scarcely human; mischievous, as though caused by elves.
Enigmatist: One who makes, or talks in, enigmas.
Enargite: An iron-black mineral of metallic luster, occurring in small orthorhombic crystals, also massive. It contains sulphur, arsenic, copper, and often silver.
Edentata: An order of mammals including the armadillos, sloths, and anteaters; -- called also Bruta. The incisor teeth are rarely developed, and in some groups all the teeth are lacking.
Erythrite: A colorless crystalline substance, C4H6.(OH)4, of a sweet, cooling taste, extracted from certain lichens, and obtained by the decomposition of erythrin; -- called also erythrol, erythroglucin, erythromannite, pseudorcin, cobalt bloom, and under the name phycite obtained from the alga Protococcus vulgaris. It is a tetrabasic alcohol, corresponding to glycol and glycerin.
Enlard: To cover or dress with lard or grease; to fatten.
erysipelas: St. Anthony's fire; a febrile disease accompanied with a diffused red edematous inflammation of the skin, which, starting usually from a single point, spreads gradually over its surface. It is often accompanied by severe constitutional symptoms.  It is caused by a group A hemolytic streptococcus (Streptococcus pyogenes), is contagious, and formerly often occured epidemically.
Expatiate: To expand; to spread; to extend; to diffuse; to broaden.
Eventuation: The act of eventuating or happening as a result; the outcome.
Effervesce: To be in a state of natural ebullition; to bubble and hiss, as fermenting liquors, or any fluid, when some part escapes in a gaseous form.
Emaciation: The act of making very lean.
eggplant: A plant (Solanum Melongena), of East Indian origin, allied to the tomato, and bearing a large, glossy, edible fruit, shaped somewhat like an egg; mad-apple.  It is widely cultivated for its fruit, commonly eaten as a vegetable.
entrenchment: an entrenched fortification; a position protected by trenches.
Embox: To inclose, as in a box; to imbox.
Equicrural: Having equal legs or sides; isosceles.
Eidograph: An instrument for copying drawings on the same or a different scale; a form of the pantograph.
Excito-motory: Exciting motion; -- said of that portion of the nervous system concerned in reflex actions, by which impressions are transmitted to a nerve center and then reflected back so as to produce muscular contraction without sensation or volition.
Empetraceae: a natural family of heathlike shrubs including the crowberry (Empetrum nigrum).
electrician: An investigator of electricity; one versed in the science of electricity.
Epipharyngeal: Pertaining to the segments above the epibranchial in the branchial arches of fishes.
Exculpate: To clear from alleged fault or guilt; to prove to be guiltless; to relieve of blame; to acquit.
Expletively: In the manner of an expletive.
English: To translate into the English language; to Anglicize; hence, to interpret; to explain.
Expectative: Something in expectation; esp., an expectative grace.
Eccritic: A remedy which promotes discharges, as an emetic, or a cathartic.
Ensoul: To indue or imbue (a body) with soul.
Exhalation: The act or process of exhaling, or sending forth in the form of steam or vapor; evaporation.
Encysted: Inclosed in a cyst, or a sac, bladder, or vesicle; as, an encysted tumor.
Erasure: The act of erasing; a scratching out; obliteration.
Evanescent: Liable to vanish or pass away like vapor; vanishing; fleeting; as, evanescent joys.
Exalted: Raised to lofty height; elevated; extolled; refined; dignified; sublime.
Eye-minded: Having one's mental imagery prevailingly of the visual type; having one's thoughts and memories mainly in the form of visual images.
Equidistant: Being at an equal distance from the same point or thing.
espanole: a rich beef stock with tomatoes and madeira and minced carrots and onions and celery.
Exalter: One who exalts or raises to dignity.
Expend: To be laid out, used, or consumed.
Especially: In an especial manner; chiefly; particularly; peculiarly; in an uncommon degree.
Elope: To run away, or escape privately, from the place or station to which one is bound by duty; -- said especially of a woman or a man, either married or unmarried, who runs away with a paramour or a sweetheart.
evildoer: a person who performs an evil deed; one who sins (without repenting).
Epipterygoid: Situated upon or above the pterygoid bone.
Epineural: Arising from the neurapophysis of a vertebra.
Elops: A genus of fishes. See Saury.
Entoplastron: The median plate of the plastron of turtles; -- called also entosternum.
Euosmitte: A fossil resin, so called from its strong, peculiar, pleasant odor.
earflap: one of two flaps attached to a cap to keep the ears warm.  On some hats the earflaps may be adjusted or tied to the top of the hat, and lowered when needed in colder weather.
Epigrammatizer: One who writes in an affectedly pointed style.
Extraprovincial: Not within of pertaining to the same province or jurisdiction.
Epimeron: In crustaceans: The part of the side of a somite external to the basal joint of each appendage.
Eructation: The act of belching wind from the stomach; a belch.
Exhale: To rise or be given off, as vapor; to pass off, or vanish.
Extra-uterine: Outside of the uterus, or womb.
Emblazon: To depict or represent; -- said of heraldic bearings. See Blazon.
Electro-physiological: Pertaining to electrical results produced through physiological agencies, or by change of action in a living organism.
Ectoderm: The outer layer of the blastoderm; epiblast.
Epiblast: The outer layer of the blastoderm; the ectoderm. See Blastoderm, Delamination.
Eatable: Capable of being eaten; fit to be eaten; proper for food; esculent; edible.
Eggery: A place where eggs are deposited (as by sea birds) or kept; a nest of eggs.
Electrolyze: To decompose by the direct action of electricity.
Escalade: To mount and pass or enter by means of ladders; to scale; as, to escalate a wall.
Earliness: The state of being early or forward; promptness.
Eminence: That which is eminent or lofty; a high ground or place; a height.
Emboss: To seek the bushy forest; to hide in the woods.
Ecclesiology: The science or theory of church building and decoration.
Exogamous: Relating to exogamy; marrying outside of the limits of one's own tribe; -- opposed to endogenous.
Epiphyte: An air plant which grows on other plants, but does not derive its nourishment from them. See Air plant.
emphasizing: The act of giving special importance or significance to something.
Espouser: One who espouses; one who embraces the cause of another or makes it his own.
Emaculation: The act of clearing from spots.
Educt: That which is educed, as by analysis.
E-mail: to send (an e-mail message) to someone; as, I emailed the article to the editor; she emailed me her report.
Ericaceous: Belonging to the Heath family, or resembling plants of that family; consisting of heats.
Epeira: A genus of spiders, including the common garden spider (E. diadema). They spin geometrical webs. See Garden spider.
Easter: To veer to the east; -- said of the wind.
Educe: To bring or draw out; to cause to appear; to produce against counter agency or influence; to extract; to evolve; as, to educe a form from matter.
Eaglet: A young eagle, or a diminutive eagle.
Endophl\u0153um: The inner layer of the bark of trees.
Eolis: A genus of nudibranch mollusks having clusters of branchial papillæ along the back. See Ceratobranchia.
Epidermoid: Like epidermis; pertaining to the epidermis.
Enshrine: To inclose in a shrine or chest; hence, to preserve or cherish as something sacred; as, to enshrine something in memory.
Eleven: The sum of ten and one; eleven units or objects.
Ectocyst: The outside covering of the Bryozoa.
Ectoparasite: Any parasite which lives on the exterior of animals; -- opposed to endoparasite.
Eyed: Heaving (such or so many) eyes; -- used in composition; as, sharp-eyed; blue-eyed; dull-eyed; sad-eyed; ox-eyed Juno; myriad-eyed.
Earthly: In the manner of the earth or its people; worldly.
energizing: imparting or capable of imparting vitality and energy.
Exothermic: Characterized by, or formed with, evolution of heat; as, an exothermic reaction; -- opposed to endothermic.
Emyd: A fresh-water tortoise of the family Emydidæ.
Escutcheoned: Having an escutcheon; furnished with a coat of arms or ensign.
