Egg-bird: A species of tern, esp. the sooty tern (Sterna fuliginosa) of the West Indies. In the Bahama Islands the name is applied to the tropic bird, Phaëthon flavirostris.
Eject: An object that is a conscious or living object, and hence not a direct object, but an inferred object or act of a subject, not myself; -- a term invented by W. K. Clifford.
enterics: rod-shaped gram-negative bacteria of the family Enterobacteriaceae; most occur normally or pathogenically in intestines of humans and other animals; those of the genus Erwinia are found in plants.
Edam: A mild Dutch pressed cheese of yellow color and fine flavor, made in balls weighing three or four pounds, and usually colored crimson outside; -- so called from the village of Edam, near Amsterdam. Also, cheese of the same type, wherever made.
Ejection: The act of ejecting or casting out; discharge; expulsion; evacuation.
Epacris: A genus of shrubs, natives of Australia, New Zealand, etc., having pretty white, red, or purple blossoms, and much resembling heaths.
Embranchment: The branching forth, as of trees.
Et cetera: Others of the like kind; and the rest; and so on; -- used to point out that other things which could be mentioned are to be understood. Usually abbreviated into etc. or &c. (&c.)
Extenuation: The act of axtenuating or the state of being extenuated; the act of making thin, slender, or lean, or of palliating; diminishing, or lessening; palliation, as of a crime; mitigation, as of punishment.
Erythrophyll: The red coloring matter of leaves, fruits, flowers, etc., in distinction from chlorophyll.
Evoke: To call out; to summon forth.
Exoterics: The public lectures or published writings of Aristotle. See Esoterics.
Elater: The active principle of elaterium, being found in the juice of the wild or squirting cucumber (Ecballium agreste, formerly Motordica Elaterium) and other related species. It is extracted as a bitter, white, crystalline substance, which is a violent purgative.
Equable: Equal and uniform; continuing the same at different times; -- said of motion, and the like; uniform in surface; smooth; as, an equable plain or globe.
Eschatological: Pertaining to the last or final things.
Equitably: In an equitable manner; justly; as, the laws should be equitably administered.
Eutexia: The principle or process of forming from given components the eutectic alloy, or alloy of maximum fusibility.
Endecagon: A plane figure of eleven sides and angles.
Eldritch: Hideous; ghastly; as, an eldritch shriek or laugh.
Encumbrance: That which encumbers; a burden which impedes action, or renders it difficult and laborious; a clog; an impediment. See Incumbrance.
Exogamy: The custom, or tribal law, which prohibits marriage between members of the same tribe; marriage outside of the tribe; -- opposed to endogamy.
Eudemonism: That system of ethics which defines and enforces moral obligation by its relation to happiness or personal well-being.
Excambion: Exchange; barter; -- used commonly of lands.
Electro-biology: That branch of biology which treats of the electrical phenomena of living organisms.
Electrolyzation: The act or the process of electrolyzing.
Emgalla: The South African wart hog. See Wart hog.
Erinaceous: Of the Hedgehog family; like, or characteristic of, a hedgehog.
Endoblastic: Relating to the endoblast; as, the endoblastic layer.
erysipeloid: a usually self-limiting cellulitis of the hand somewhat resembling erysipelas, caused by the bacterium Erysipelothrix rhusiopathiae.  It may start at the site of a wound obtained while handling meat or fish, and may occasionally become generalizd with protracted illness and severe toxemia.
Elaphine: Pertaining to, resembling, or characteristic of, the stag, or Cervus elaphus.
eyeglasses: a pair of lenses fixed together in a frame, used for correcting defective vision.  Also called a pair of eyeglasses.  See also eyeglass{1}.
Exchequer: To institute a process against (any one) in the Court of Exchequer.
Epiclinal: Situated on the receptacle or disk of a flower.
Eleusinian: Pertaining to Eleusis, in Greece, or to secret rites in honor of Ceres, there celebrated; as, Eleusinian mysteries or festivals.
Exhortation: The act of practice of exhorting; the act of inciting to laudable deeds; incitement to that which is good or commendable.
Emphyteutic: Of or pertaining to an emphyteusis; as, emphyteutic lands.
Enema: An injection, or clyster, thrown into the rectum as a medicine, or to impart nourishment.
Elutriation: The process of elutriating; a decanting or racking off by means of water, as finer particles from heavier.
Epiphyllous: Growing upon, or inserted into, the leaf.
Etherization: The administration of ether to produce insensibility.
Exclusion: The act of excluding, or of shutting out, whether by thrusting out or by preventing admission; a debarring; rejection; prohibition; the state of being excluded.
Extraditable: Subject, or liable, to extradition, as a fugitive from justice.
Epizo\u00f6tic: A disease attacking many animals at the same time; an epizootic disease.
Experimentalist: One who makes experiments, especially one who likes to experiment; an experimenter.
Endogamous: Marrying within the same tribe; -- opposed to exogamous.
Embellish: To make beautiful or elegant by ornaments; to decorate; to adorn; as, to embellish a book with pictures, a garden with shrubs and flowers, a narrative with striking anecdotes, or style with metaphors.
Ethylsulphuric: Pertaining to, or containing, ethyl and sulphuric acid.
Endogamy: Marriage only within the tribe; a custom restricting a man in his choice of a wife to the tribe to which he belongs; -- opposed to exogamy.
Exclamatory: Containing, expressing, or using exclamation; as, an exclamatory phrase or speaker.
Eulerian: Pertaining to Euler, a German mathematician of the 18th century.
Emendator: One who emends or critically edits.
Enterorrhaphy: The operation of sewing up a rent in the intestinal canal.
Exciteful: Full of exciting qualities; as, an exciteful story; exciteful players.
Erythrozyme: A ferment extracted from madder root, possessing the power of inducing alcoholic fermentation in solutions of sugar.
Erythrophleine: A white crystalline alkaloid, extracted from sassy bark (Erythrophleum Guineense).
Explication: The act of opening, unfolding, or explaining; explanation; exposition; interpretation.
Etiolin: A yellowish coloring matter found in plants grown in darkness, which is supposed to be an antecedent condition of chlorophyll.
Engross: To make gross, thick, or large; to thicken; to increase in bulk or quantity.
Electronic mail: a message transmitted from one computer to another, accessible by means of a mail reading program on the receiving computer.  The message may have one or many intended recipients, and may be directed by the sending program to one or to multiple receiving computers.  The message is typically in the form of a computer file, and may be a simple ASCII text, or any other type of binary coded information
Euganoidei: A group which includes the bony ganoids, as the gar pikes.
entangled: in a confused mass.  Contrasted with untangled.
Enhance: To be raised up; to grow larger; as, a debt enhances rapidly by compound interest.
Exuberant: Characterized by abundance or superabundance; plenteous; rich; overflowing; copious or excessive in production; as, exuberant goodness; an exuberant intellect; exuberant foliage.
Examinership: The office or rank of an examiner.
Ebb: Receding; going out; falling; shallow; low.
Ecballium: A genus of cucurbitaceous plants consisting of the single species Ecballium agreste (or Elaterium), the squirting cucumber. Its fruit, when ripe, bursts and violently ejects its seeds, together with a mucilaginous juice, from which elaterium, a powerful cathartic medicine, is prepared.
Ensign: To designate as by an ensign.
Emprosthotonos: A drawing of the body forward, in consequence of the spasmodic action of some of the muscles.
Egress: To go out; to depart; to leave.
Etymon: An original form; primitive word; root.
Enchantress: A woman versed in magical arts; a sorceress; also, a woman who fascinates.
Enunciable: Capable of being enunciated or expressed.
Ensue: To follow or come afterward; to follow as a consequence or in chronological succession; to result; as, an ensuing conclusion or effect; the year ensuing was a cold one.
ecology: the branch of biology concerned with the various relations of animals and plants to one another and to their surrounding environment.
Eelgrass: A plant (Zostera marina), with very long and narrow leaves, growing abundantly in shallow bays along the North Atlantic coast.
Equanimity: Evenness of mind; that calm temper or firmness of mind which is not easily elated or depressed; patience; calmness; composure; as, to bear misfortunes with equanimity.
Elatrometer: An instrument for measuring the degree of rarefaction of air contained in the receiver of an air pump.
Exsiccative: Tending to make dry; having the power of drying.
Erative: Pertaining to the Muse Erato who presided over amatory poetry.
Exilic: Pertaining to exile or banishment, esp. to that of the Jews in Babylon.
Endolymphatic: Pertaining to, or containing, endolymph; as, the endolymphatic duct.
escargot: any edible terrestrial snail prepared as food; as a dish, it is usually served in the shell with a sauce of melted butter and garlic.
Episode: A separate incident, story, or action, introduced for the purpose of giving a greater variety to the events related; an incidental narrative, or digression, separable from the main subject, but naturally arising from it.
Epiperipheral: Connected with, or having its origin upon, the external surface of the body; -- especially applied to the feelings which originate at the extremities of nerves distributed on the outer surface, as the sensation produced by touching an object with the finger; -- opposed to entoperipheral.
espadrille: a sandal with a sole made of rope or rubber and a cloth upper part.
easygoing: Moving easily; hence, mild-tempered; relaxed and casual; ease-loving; inactive.  Contrasted with tense.
Embrocation: The act of moistening and rubbing a diseased part with spirit, oil, etc.
Evil eye: See Evil eye under Evil, a.
Expansive: Having a capacity or tendency to expand or dilate; diffusive; of much expanse; wide-extending; as, the expansive force of heat; the expansive quality of air.
Eikosane: A solid hydrocarbon, C20H42, of the paraffin series, of artificial production, and also probably occurring in petroleum.
Enthrall: To hold in thrall; to enslave. See Inthrall.
Emeto-cathartic: Producing vomiting and purging at the same time.
Egyptology: The science or study of Egyptian antiquities, esp. the hieroglyphics.
Excrementive: Serving to excrete; connected with excretion or excrement.
Epipedometry: The mensuration of figures standing on the same base.
Eupatrid: One well born, or of noble birth.
Emblematist: A writer or inventor of emblems.
Eyetooth: A canine tooth of the upper jaw.
Eulogistic: Of or pertaining to eulogy; characterized by eulogy; bestowing praise; panegyrical; commendatory; laudatory; as, eulogistic speech or discourse.
Epistler: A writer of epistles, or of an epistle of the New Testament.
Etter pike: The stingfish, or lesser weever (Tranchinus vipera).
Extraordinary: That which is extraordinary; -- used especially in the plural; as, extraordinaries excepted, there is nothing to prevent success.
Enfeeblement: The act of weakening; enervation; weakness.
eruption: The act of breaking out or bursting forth;
Endoplasm: The protoplasm in the interior of a cell.
Economics: The science of household affairs, or of domestic management.
Equal: To be or become equal to; to have the same quantity, the same value, the same degree or rank, or the like, with; to be commen&unr_;urate with.
Easy-chair: An armchair for ease or repose.
Endosmometer: An instrument for measuring the force or amount of endosmotic action.
Entrancement: The act of entrancing, or the state of trance or ecstasy.
Expedient: That which serves to promote or advance; suitable means to accomplish an end.
Ear-shell: any of various large edible marine gastropod mollusks of the genus Haliotis, having a flattened ear-shaped shell with a pearly interior; -- called also sea-ear. See Abalone.
Exarticulate: Having but one joint; -- said of certain insects.
Egregiously: Greatly; enormously; shamefully; as, egregiously cheated.
Earthwork: Any construction, whether a temporary breastwork or permanent fortification, for attack or defense, the material of which is chiefly earth.
Earthworm: Any worm of the genus Lumbricus and allied genera, found in damp soil. One of the largest and most abundant species in Europe and America is L. terrestris; many others are known; -- called also angleworm and dewworm.
Effectuate: To bring to pass; to effect; to achieve; to accomplish; to fulfill.
Exterior: The outward surface or part of a thing; that which is external; outside.
Engirdle: To surround as with a girdle; to girdle.
Epigrammatize: To represent by epigrams; to express by epigrams.
Episcopally: By episcopal authority; in an episcopal manner.
Easting: The distance measured toward the east between two meridians drawn through the extremities of a course; distance of departure eastward made by a vessel.
Epiornis: One of the gigantic ostrichlike birds of the genus Æpiornis, only recently extinct. Its remains have been found in Madagascar.
endozoic: Living within a living animal, usually as a parasite; as, endozoic worms.  Contrasted with epizoic.
Exordium: A beginning; an introduction; especially, the introductory part of a discourse or written composition, which prepares the audience for the main subject; the opening part of an oration.
Elk: a member of the fraternal organization named Benevolent and Protective Order of Elks, supporting various services to their communities.
Emendation: The act of altering for the better, or correcting what is erroneous or faulty; correction; improvement.
Evaporable: Capable of being converted into vapor, or dissipated by evaporation.
eaten: ingested through the mouth.  Contrasted with uneaten.
Elm: A tree of the genus Ulmus, of several species, much used as a shade tree, particularly in America. The English elm is Ulmus campestris; the common American or white elm is U. Americana; the slippery or red elm, U. fulva.
Enlimn: To adorn by illuminating or ornamenting with colored and decorated letters and figures, as a book or manuscript.
Elf: To entangle mischievously, as an elf might do.
Everything: Whatever pertains to the subject under consideration; all things.
Errancy: A wandering; state of being in error.
Exposition: The act of exposing or laying open; a setting out or displaying to public view.
Eclectic: One who follows an eclectic method.
Ecchymose: To discolor by the production of an ecchymosis, or effusion of blood, beneath the skin; -- chiefly used in the passive form; as, the parts were much ecchymosed.
Enfeoff: To give a feud, or right in land, to; to invest with a fief or fee; to invest (any one) with a freehold estate by the process of feoffment.
Evilness: The condition or quality of being evil; badness; viciousness; malignity; vileness; as, evilness of heart; the evilness of sin.
Experimentally: By experiment; by experience or trial.
evangelism: The preaching or promulgation of the gospel.
Eliminant: The result of eliminating n variables between n homogeneous equations of any degree; -- called also resultant.
Explanation: The act of explaining, expounding, or interpreting; the act of clearing from obscurity and making intelligible; as, the explanation of a passage in Scripture, or of a contract or treaty.
Embrew: To imbrue; to stain with blood.
Every: All the parts which compose a whole collection or aggregate number, considered in their individuality, all taken separately one by one, out of an indefinite number.
Evict: To dispossess by a judicial process; to dispossess by paramount right or claim of such right; to eject; to oust.
Extractiform: Having the form, appearance, or nature, of an extract.
Estimate: A valuing or rating by the mind, without actually measuring, weighing, or the like; rough or approximate calculation; as, an estimate of the cost of a building, or of the quantity of water in a pond.
Enchanting: Having a power of enchantment; charming; fascinating.
Equilateral: A side exactly corresponding, or equal, to others; also, a figure of equal sides.
Exorable: Capable of being moved by entreaty; pitiful; tender.
Earles penny: Earnest money. Same as Arles penny.
Externalism: The quality of being manifest to the senses; external acts or appearances; regard for externals.
Escot: To pay the reckoning for; to support; to maintain.
Ecbasis: A figure in which the orator treats of things according to their events consequences.
Eleusine: a genus of annual and perennial grasses of savannas and upland grasslands.
Extispicious: Relating to the inspection of entrails for prognostication.
Electrification: The act of electrifying, or the state of being charged with electricity.
Entoplasm: The inner granular layer of protoplasm in a developing ovum.
Eventually: In an eventual manner; finally; ultimately.
Evenly: With an even, level, or smooth surface; without roughness, elevations, or depression; uniformly; equally; comfortably; impartially; serenely.
Emeraldine: A green compound used as a dyestuff, produced from aniline blue when acted upon by acid.
Encyclopedian: Embracing the whole circle of learning, or a wide range of subjects.
Enclavement: The state of being an enclave.
Epicure: A follower of Epicurus; an Epicurean.
Eviction: The act or process of evicting; or state of being evicted; the recovery of lands, tenements, etc., from another's possession by due course of law; dispossession by paramount title or claim of such title; ejectment; ouster.
Egg squash: A variety of squash with small egg-shaped fruit.
Elegant: Very choice, and hence, pleasing to good taste; characterized by grace, propriety, and refinement, and the absence of every thing offensive; exciting admiration and approbation by symmetry, completeness, freedom from blemish, and the like; graceful; tasteful and highly attractive; as, elegant manners; elegant style of composition; an elegant speaker; an elegant structure.
epicyclic: Pertaining to, resembling, or having the motion of, an epicycle.
Endless: Without end; having no end or conclusion; perpetual; interminable; -- applied to length, and to duration; as, an endless line; endless time; endless bliss; endless praise; endless clamor.
Edgeless: Without an edge; not sharp; blunt; obtuse; as, an edgeless sword or weapon.
Enablement: The act of enabling, or the state of being enabled; ability.
Extrajudicial conveyance: A conveyance, as by deed, effected by the act of the parties and not involving, as in the fine and recovery, judicial proceedings.
Envenom: To taint or impregnate with venom, or any substance noxious to life; to poison; to render dangerous or deadly by poison, as food, drink, a weapon; as, envenomed meat, wine, or arrow; also, to poison (a person) by impregnating with venom.
Eau de vie: French name for brandy.  Cf. Aqua vitæ, under Aqua.
Excisable: Liable or subject to excise; as, tobacco in an excisable commodity.
Enneagonal: Belonging to an enneagon; having nine angles.
Externalize: To make external; to manifest by outward form.
Exogen: A plant belonging to one of the greater part of the vegetable kingdom, and which the plants are characterized by having c wood bark, and pith, the wood forming a layer between the other two, and increasing, if at all, by the animal addition of a new layer to the outside next to the bark. The leaves are commonly netted-veined, and the number of cotyledons is two, or, very rarely, several in a whorl.  Cf. Endogen.
Espousal: The act of espousing or betrothing; especially, in the plural, betrothal; plighting of the troths; a contract of marriage; sometimes, the marriage ceremony.
Elementally: According to elements; literally; as, the words, “Take, eat; this is my body,” elementally understood.
Electant: One who has the power of choosing; an elector.
Eumolpus: A genus of small beetles, one species of which (E. viti) is very injurious to the vines in the wine countries of Europe.
Establishment: The act of establishing; a ratifying or ordaining; settlement; confirmation.
exposit: to set forth reasons; to explain or expound.
Ergot: A diseased condition of rye and other cereals, in which the grains become black, and often spur-shaped. It is caused by a parasitic fungus, Claviceps purpurea.
Encircle: To form a circle about; to inclose within a circle or ring; to surround; as, to encircle one in the arms; the army encircled the city.
Exegetist: One versed in the science of exegesis or interpretation; -- also called exegete.
Envelop: To put a covering about; to wrap up or in; to inclose within a case, wrapper, integument or the like; to surround entirely; as, to envelop goods or a letter; the fog envelops a ship.
Enframe: To inclose, as in a frame.
Embower: To cover with a bower; to shelter with trees.
Exertive: Having power or a tendency to exert; using exertion.
earth-shaking: sufficiently significant to affect the whole world; as, earth-shaking proposals; an earth-shaking event.
Experientialist: One who accepts the doctrine of experientialism.  Also used adjectively.
Endmost: Farthest; remotest; at the very end.
Eagle-winged: Having the wings of an eagle; swift, or soaring high, like an eagle.
Excalceation: The act of depriving or divesting of shoes.
Equidiurnal: Pertaining to the time of equal day and night; -- applied to the equinoctial line.
Exactitude: The quality of being exact; exactness.
Envoy: One dispatched upon an errand or mission; a messenger; esp., a person deputed by a sovereign or a government to negotiate a treaty, or transact other business, with a foreign sovereign or government; a minister accredited to a foreign government. An envoy's rank is below that of an ambassador.
Envault: To inclose in a vault; to entomb.
Empiristic: Relating to, or resulting from, experience, or experiment; following from empirical methods or data; -- opposed to nativistic.
Endorhizal: Having the radicle of the embryo sheathed by the cotyledon, through which the embryo bursts in germination, as in many monocotyledonous plants.
Electrically: In the manner of electricity, or by means of it; thrillingly.
Embody: To unite in a body, a mass, or a collection; to coalesce.
Etiology: The science of causes. Same as &unr_;tiology.
Electorality: The territory or dignity of an elector; electorate.
Epicardiac: Of or relating to the epicardium.
Exoteric: External; public; suitable to be imparted to the public; hence, capable of being readily or fully comprehended; -- opposed to esoteric, or secret.
Earpick: An instrument for removing wax from the ear.
Etnean: Pertaining to Etna, a volcanic mountain in Sicily.
Elegy: A mournful or plaintive poem; a funereal song; a poem of lamentation.
Enrich: To make rich with any kind of wealth; to render opulent; to increase the possessions of; as, to enrich the understanding with knowledge.
Epistoler: One of the clergy who reads the epistle at the communion service; an epistler.
Establish: To make stable or firm; to fix immovably or firmly; to set (a thing) in a place and make it stable there; to settle; to confirm.
Essoin: To excuse for nonappearance in court.
Emersion: The act of emerging, or of rising out of anything; as, emersion from the sea; emersion from obscurity or difficulties.
egg-and-dart: a decorative ovolo molding, having a series of egg-shaped figures alternating with another shape in the form of a dart or anchor.  Also used attributively; as, an egg-and-dart molding; an egg-and-dart design.  Called also egg and dart, and egg and tongue
Encowl: To make a monk (or wearer of a cowl) of.
Effete: No longer capable of producing young, as an animal, or fruit, as the earth; hence, worn out with age; exhausted of energy; incapable of efficient action; no longer productive; barren; sterile.
Endo-: A combining form signifying within; as, endocarp, endogen, endocuneiform, endaspidean.
Engrain: To dye in grain, or of a fast color. See Ingrain.
Employable: Capable of being employed; capable of being used; fit or proper for use.
Expressional: Of, or relating to, expression; phraseological; also, vividly representing or suggesting an idea or sentiment.
existing: having existence or being or actuality; as, much of the beluga caviar existing in the world is found in the Soviet Union and Iran.  Opposite of nonexistent.
Expiator: One who makes expiation or atonement.
eupyrion: A contrivance for obtaining a light instantaneously, such as a lucifer match.
Etrurian: Of or relating to ancient Etruria, in Italy.
Envelopment: The act of enveloping or wrapping; an inclosing or covering on all sides.
Expenditure: The act of expending; a laying out, as of money; disbursement.
Euterpean: Of or pertaining to Euterpe or to music.
eukaryote: an organism with "good" or membrane-bound nuclei having multiple chromosomes; eucaryotes also have other membrane-bound organelles such as mitochondria or chloroplasts, within the cytoplasm enclosed by the outer membrane.  Such cells are characteristic of all life forms except primitive microorganisms such as bacteria and blue-green algae.  Contrasted with prokaryote.
Executory: Pertaining to administration, or putting the laws in force; executive.
expelling: any of several bodily processes by which substances go out of the body.
Extrication: The act or process of extricating or disentangling; a freeing from perplexities; disentanglement.
Engarrison: To garrison; to put in garrison, or to protect by a garrison.
Erectility: The quality or state of being erectile.
Eelpout: A European fish (Zoarces viviparus), remarkable for producing living young; -- called also greenbone, guffer, bard, and Maroona eel. Also, an American species (Z. anguillaris), -- called also mutton fish, and, erroneously, congo eel, ling, and lamper eel. Both are edible, but of little value.
Exarate: To plow up; also, to engrave; to write.
Effectible: Capable of being done or achieved; practicable; feasible.
Eleuthero-petalous: Having the petals free, that is, entirely separate from each other; -- said of both plant and flower.
Exothecium: The outer coat of the anther.
Eagre: A wave, or two or three successive waves, of great height and violence, at flood tide moving up an estuary or river; -- commonly called the bore. See Bore.
Emasculate: To deprive of virile or procreative power; to castrate power; to castrate; to geld.
Edomite: One of the descendants of Esau or Edom, the brother of Jacob; an Idumean.
Exportation: The act of exporting; the act of conveying or sending commodities abroad or to another country, in the course of commerce.
entrepot: A warehouse; a magazine for depositing goods, stores, etc.
Ejaculatory: Casting or throwing out; fitted to eject; as, ejaculatory vessels.
Eventless: Without events; tame; monotonous; marked by nothing unusual; uneventful.
Eloquence: Fluent, forcible, elegant, and persuasive speech in public; the power of expressing strong emotions in striking and appropriate language either spoken or written, thereby producing conviction or persuasion.
Englishry: The state or privilege of being an Englishman.
Equity: Equality of rights; natural justice or right; the giving, or desiring to give, to each man his due, according to reason, and the law of God to man; fairness in determination of conflicting claims; impartiality.
Emulator: One who emulates, or strives to equal or surpass.
Evirate: To emasculate; to dispossess of manhood.
Elbow: To jut into an angle; to project or to bend after the manner of an elbow.
Extortion: The act of extorting; the act or practice of wresting anything from a person by force, by threats, or by any undue exercise of power; undue exaction; overcharge.
Endow: To furnish with money or its equivalent, as a permanent fund for support; to make pecuniary provision for; to settle an income upon; especially, to furnish with dower; as, to endow a wife; to endow a public institution.
Embryo: Pertaining to an embryo; rudimentary; undeveloped; as, an embryo bud.
Endosperm: The albumen of a seed; -- limited by recent writers to that formed within the embryo sac.
Erucic: Pertaining to, or derived from, a genus of cruciferous Mediterranean herbs (Eruca or Brassica); as, erucic acid, a fatty acid resembling oleic acid, and found in colza oil, mustard oil, etc.
Embolism: Intercalation; the insertion of days, months, or years, in an account of time, to produce regularity; as, the embolism of a lunar month in the Greek year.
Edder: To bind the top interweaving edder; as, to edder a hedge.
Expetible: Worthy of being wished for; desirable.
Encrinus: A genus of fossil encrinoidea, from the Mesozoic rocks.
Ejecta: Matter ejected; material thrown out; as, the ejecta of a volcano; the ejecta, or excreta, of the body.
Entonic: Having great tension, or exaggerated action.
Earthdrake: A mythical monster of the early Anglo-Saxon literature; a dragon.
evangelize: To instruct in the gospel; to preach the gospel to; to convert to Christianity; as, to evangelize the world.
Enterotome: A kind of scissors used for opening the intestinal canal, as in post-mortem examinations.
Er: the chemical symbol for erbium, a rare earth element.  It has atomic number 68 and an atomic weight of 167.26.
Escritorial: Of or pertaining to an escritoire.
Effervescence: A kind of natural ebullition; that commotion of a fluid which takes place when some part of the mass flies off in a gaseous form, producing innumerable small bubbles; as, the effervescence of a carbonate with citric acid.
Epenthetic: Inserted in the body of a word; as, an epenthetic letter or sound.
Entr\u00e9e: A coming in, or entrance; hence, freedom of access; permission or right to enter; as, to have the entrée of a house.
Entitative: Considered as pure entity; abstracted from all circumstances.
Endoscopy: The art or process of examination or treatment by means of an endoscope.
Escheatage: The right of succeeding to an escheat.
Epig\u00e6a: An American genus of plants, containing but a single species (E. repens), the trailing arbutus.
expunging: deletion by an act of expunging or erasing.
enclosed: surrounded or closed in, usually on all sides.  Opposite of unenclosed.
Eophyte: A fossil plant which is found in the lowest beds of the Silurian age.
Endoscope: An instrument for examining the interior of the body, consisting of a flexible tube with lenses and optical fibers permitting illumination of the interior site to be inspected, and visualization of the interior site from outside the  body; it often has small surgical instruments attached to the end and manipulable from the outside, permitting biopsy or surgery.  It is used as a non-invasive or minimally invasive tool for diagnosis or treatment, especially in organs having an external opening such as the rectum, the urethra, and the bladder.
Equerry: A large stable or lodge for horses.
Enrange: To range in order; to put in rank; to arrange.
Eriometer: An instrument for measuring the diameters of minute particles or fibers, from the size of the colored rings produced by the diffraction of the light in which the objects are viewed.
Emplacement: A putting in, or assigning to, a definite place; localization; as, the emplacement of a structure.
Entrance: To put into a trance; to make insensible to present objects.
Eridanus: A long, winding constellation extending southward from Taurus and containing the bright star Achernar.
Energetic: Having energy or energies; possessing a capacity for vigorous action or for exerting force; active.
Exasperate: To irritate in a high degree; to provoke; to enrage; to excite or to inflame the anger of; as, to exasperate a person or his feelings.
Eccle: The European green woodpecker; -- also called ecall, eaquall, yaffle.
Echinochloa: annual or perennial succulent grasses of warm regions.
Embossment: The act of forming bosses or raised figures, or the state of being so formed.
Emulation: The endeavor to equal or to excel another in qualities or actions; an assiduous striving to equal or excel another; rivalry.
Emasculator: One who, or that which, emasculates.
Epig\u00e6ous: Growing on, or close to, the ground.
Euryalida: A tribe of Ophiuroidea, including the genera Euryale, Astrophyton, etc. They generally have the arms branched. See Astrophyton.
Enuresis: An involuntary discharge of urine; incontinence of urine.
Enhedge: To surround as with a hedge.
Empaistic: Having to do with inlaid work; -- especially used with reference to work of the ancient Greeks.
Existence: The state of existing or being; actual possession of being; continuance in being; as, the existence of body and of soul in union; the separate existence of the soul; immortal existence.
eucaryote: an organism with "good" or membrane-bound nuclei having multiple chromosomes; eucaryotes also have other membrane-bound organelles such as mitochondria or chloroplasts, within the cytoplasm enclosed by the outer membrane.  Such cells are characteristic of all life forms except primitive microorganisms such as bacteria and blue-green algae.  Contrasted with prokaryote.
exchange: The act of giving or taking one thing in return for another which is regarded as an equivalent; as, an exchange of cattle for grain.
Enviable: Fitted to excite envy; capable of awakening an ardent desire to posses or to resemble.
Electroscope: An instrument for detecting the presence of electricity, or changes in the electric state of bodies, or the species of electricity present, as by means of pith balls, and the like.
Emborder: To furnish or adorn with a border; to imborder.
Embow: To bend like a bow; to curve.
Ectoplastic: Pertaining to, or composed of, ectoplasm.
Exemplary: An exemplar; also, a copy of a book or writing.
Eclectically: In an eclectic manner; by an eclectic method.
Eunuch: To make a eunuch of; to castrate. as a man.
eightvo: the size of a book (ca. 16 x 23 cm) whose pages are made by folding a sheet of paper three times to form eight leaves.  The pages have about half the area of a quarto. Symbolized as 8vo, and 8°.
Energy: Internal or inherent power; capacity of acting, operating, or producing an effect, whether exerted or not; as, men possessing energies may suffer them to lie inactive.
Ensnare: To catch in a snare. See Insnare.
Elude: To avoid slyly, by artifice, stratagem, or dexterity; to escape from in a covert manner; to mock by an unexpected escape; to baffle; as, to elude an officer; to elude detection, inquiry, search, comprehension; to elude the force of an argument or a blow.
Erubescence: The act of becoming red; redness of the skin or surface of anything; a blushing.
Expressage: The charge for carrying a parcel by express.
Expectorate: To discharge matter from the lungs or throat by hawking and spitting; to spit.
Euphony: A pleasing or sweet sound; an easy, smooth enunciation of sounds; a pronunciation of letters and syllables which is pleasing to the ear.
Epizoic: Living upon the exterior of another animal; ectozoic; -- said of external parasites.
Embolden: To give boldness or courage to; to encourage.
Extratropical: Beyond or outside of the tropics.
Euphotide: A rock occurring in the Alps, consisting of saussurite and smaragdite; -- sometimes called gabbro.
Estrapade: The action of a horse, when, to get rid of his rider, he rears, plunges, and kicks furiously.
Eloquent: Having the power of expressing strong emotions or forcible arguments in an elevated, impassioned, and effective manner; as, an eloquent orator or preacher.
ensign: A flag; a banner; a standard; esp., the national flag, or a banner indicating nationality, carried by a ship or a body of soldiers; -- as distinguished from flags indicating divisions of the army, rank of naval officers, or private signals, and the like.
Extradotal: Forming no part of the dowry; as, extradotal property.
Espalier: To form an espalier of, or to protect by an espalier.
Exit: The departure of a player from the stage, when he has performed his part.
Electro-gilt: Gilded by means of voltaic electricity.
Electrogenic: Of or pertaining to electrogenesis; as, an electrogenic condition.
Elvan: The rock of an elvan vein, or the elvan vein itself; an elvan course.
Exploring: Employed in, or designed for, exploration.
Elcaja: An Arabian tree (Trichilia emetica). The fruit, which is emetic, is sometimes employed in the composition of an ointment for the cure of the itch.
Erinite: A hydrous arseniate of copper, of an emerald-green color; -- so called from Erin, or Ireland, where it occurs.
Exsert: To thrust out; to protrude; as, some worms are said to exsert the proboscis.
Encephalic: Pertaining to the encephalon or brain.
Ebullioscope: An instrument for observing the boiling point of liquids, especially for determining the alcoholic strength of a mixture by the temperature at which it boils.
Expropriate: To put out of one's possession; to surrender the ownership of; also, to deprive of possession or proprietary rights.
En passant: In passing; in the course of any procedure;
Eskimo: One of a peculiar race inhabiting Arctic America and Greenland. In many respects the Eskimos resemble the Mongolian race.
Enameled: Coated or adorned with enamel; having a glossy or variegated surface; glazed.
Effluvium: Subtile or invisible emanation; exhalation perceived by the sense of smell; especially, noisome or noxious exhalation; as, the effluvium from diseased or putrefying bodies, or from ill drainage.
Epicede: A funeral song or discourse; an elegy.
Erratum: An error or mistake in writing or printing.
Eavesdropper: One who stands under the eaves, or near the window or door of a house, to listen; hence, a secret listener.
Enallage: A substitution, as of one part of speech for another, of one gender, number, case, person, tense, mode, or voice, of the same word, for another.
Extermination: The act of exterminating; total destruction; eradication; excision; as, the extermination of inhabitants or tribes, of error or vice, or of weeds from a field.
Endospermic: Relating to, accompanied by, or containing, endosperm.
Erewhile: Some time ago; a little while before; heretofore.
Enameler: One who enamels; a workman or artist who applies enamels in ornamental work.
Editorial: A leading article in a newspaper or magazine; an editorial article; an article published as an expression of the views of the editor.
Extroitive: Seeking or going out after external objects.
External: Something external or without; outward part; that which makes a show, rather than that which is intrinsic; visible form; -- usually in the plural.
Emporium: A place of trade; a market place; a mart; esp., a city or town with extensive commerce; the commercial center of a country.
Edelweiss: A little, perennial, white, woolly plant (Leontopodium alpinum), growing at high elevations in the Alps.  It is the national flower of Austria.
Entomotomy: The science of the dissection of insects.
Esplanade: A clear space between a citadel and the nearest houses of the town.
Eightscore: Eight times twenty; a hundred and sixty.
Eulogist: One who eulogizes or praises; panegyrist; encomiast.
Escorial: A palace and mausoleum of the kings of Spain, being a vast and wonderful structure about twenty-five miles northwest of Madrid; called also escurial.  It was erected in 1563-1584 and contains a monastery.
Egence: The state of needing, or of suffering a natural want.
Extract: That which is extracted or drawn out.
Escharine: Like, or pertaining to, the genus Eschara, or family Escharidæ.
Epipolic: Producing, or relating to, epipolism or fluorescence.
Evolvement: The act of evolving, or the state of being evolved; evolution.
Execrate: To denounce evil against, or to imprecate evil upon; to curse; to protest against as unholy or detestable; hence, to detest utterly; to abhor; to abominate.
Espauliere: A defense for the shoulder, composed of flexible overlapping plates of metal, used in the 15th century; -- the origin of the modern epaulette.
Erythrina: A genus of leguminous plants growing in the tropics; coral tree; -- so called from its red flowers.
Erigeron: a cosmopolitan genus of usually perennial herbs with asterlike flowers; the leaves were formerly used medicinally, but now are only occasionally so used.
Exsertile: Capable of being thrust out or protruded.
Encourage: To give courage to; to inspire with courage, spirit, or hope; to raise, or to increase, the confidence of; to animate; enhearten; to incite; to help forward; -- the opposite of discourage.
Elgin marbles: Greek sculptures in the British Museum. They were obtained at Athens, about 1811, by Lord Elgin.
Eriach: A recompense formerly given by a murderer to the relatives of the murdered person.
Extrusion: The act of thrusting or pushing out; a driving out; expulsion.
expandable: able to expand or to be expanded.
Electuary: A medicine composed of powders, or other ingredients, incorporated with some convserve, honey, or sirup; a confection. See the note under Confection.
Esurine: A medicine which provokes appetites, or causes hunger.
Everlasting: Eternal duration, past or future; eternity.
Electro-capillarity: The occurrence or production of certain capillary effects by the action of an electrical current or charge.
Equiponderate: To make equal in weight; to counterbalance.
Ensweep: To sweep over or across; to pass over rapidly.
Elucidate: To make clear or manifest; to render more intelligible; to illustrate; as, an example will elucidate the subject.
Eugetic: Pertaining to, or derived from, eugenol; as, eugetic acid.
Embracement: A clasp in the arms; embrace.
Ebionite: One of a sect of heretics, in the first centuries of the church, whose doctrine was a mixture of Judaism and Christianity. They denied the divinity of Christ, regarding him as an inspired messenger, and rejected much of the New Testament.
Esoterics: Mysterious or hidden doctrines; secret science.
Emphysematous: Pertaining to, or of the nature of, emphysema; swelled; bloated.
Emeritus: A veteran who has honorably completed his service.
Exostosis: Any protuberance of a bone which is not natural; an excrescence or morbid enlargement of a bone.
Emphaticalness: The quality of being emphatic; emphasis.
Echinococcus: A parasite of man and of many domestic and wild animals, forming compound cysts or tumors (called hydatid cysts) in various organs, but especially in the liver and lungs, which often cause death. It is the larval stage of the Tænia echinococcus, a small tapeworm peculiar to the dog.  The adult form is not found in man.
Engraving: The act or art of producing upon hard material incised or raised patterns, characters, lines, and the like; especially, the art of producing such lines, etc., in the surface of metal plates or blocks of wood. Engraving is used for the decoration of the surface itself; also, for producing an original, from which a pattern or design may be printed on paper.
Elapse: To slip or glide away; to pass away silently, as time; -- used chiefly in reference to time.
Eudemonics: That part of moral philosophy which treats of happiness; the science of happiness; -- contrasted with aretaics.
Eared: Having (such or so many) ears; -- used in composition; as, long-eared-eared; sharp-eared; full-eared; ten-eared.
Eger: An impetuous flood; a bore. See Eagre.
Etymologist: One who investigates the derivation of words.
Enlink: To chain together; to connect, as by links.
Embracive: Disposed to embrace; fond of caressing.
Encarpus: An ornament on a frieze or capital, consisting of festoons of fruit, flowers, leaves, etc.
Expulsion: The act of expelling; a driving or forcing out; summary removal from membership, association, etc.
Ebonize: To make black, or stain black, in imitation of ebony; as, to ebonize wood.
Eleutheromania: A mania or frantic zeal for freedom.
Encrinic: Relating to encrinites; containing encrinites, as certain kinds of limestone.
Enervate: Weakened; weak; without strength of force.
Eightieth: The quotient of a unit divided by eighty; one of eighty equal parts.
Effusion: The act of pouring out; as, effusion of water, of blood, of grace, of words, and the like.
Exossate: To deprive of bones; to take out the bones of; to bone.
Europium: A metallic element of the rare-earth group (Lanthanide series), discovered spectroscopically by Demarcay in 1896. Symbol, Eu; atomic number 63; at. wt., 151.965 (C=12.011); valence = +2 or +3.
Efflation: The act of filling with wind; a breathing or puffing out; a puff, as of wind.
Electroplate: To plate or cover with a coating of metal, usually silver, nickel, chromium, or gold, by means of electrolysis.
Edulcorative: Tending to &unr_;weeten or purify by affusions of water.
Exuberate: To abound; to be in great abundance.
Engulf: To absorb or swallow up as in a gulf.
Eschew: To shun; to avoid, as something wrong, or from a feeling of distaste; to keep one's self clear of.
Emanant: Issuing or flowing forth; emanating; passing forth into an act, or making itself apparent by an effect; -- said of mental acts; as, an emanant volition.
Executant: One who executes or performs; esp., a performer on a musical instrument.
Emetic: Inducing to vomit; exciting the stomach to discharge its contents by the mouth.
Expensive: Occasioning expense; calling for liberal outlay; costly; dear; liberal; as, expensive dress; an expensive house or family.
Euchologion: A formulary of prayers; the book of offices in the Greek Church, containing the liturgy, sacraments, and forms of prayers.
Estramacon: A straight, heavy sword with two edges, used in the 16th and 17th centuries.
Epexegesis: A full or additional explanation; exegesis.
Eikon: An image or effigy; -- used rather in an abstract sense, and rarely for a work of art.
Embosom: To take into, or place in, the bosom; to cherish; to foster.
Estafet: A courier who conveys messages to another courier; a military courier sent from one part of an army to another.
Evanesce: To vanish away; to become dissipated and disappear, like vapor.
Euisopoda: A group which includes the typical Isopoda.
Espinel: A kind of ruby. See Spinel.
Exegesis: Exposition; explanation; especially, a critical explanation of a text or portion of Scripture.
euphuism: An affectation of excessive elegance and refinement of language; high-flown diction.
Electrocute: To execute or put to death by electricity.
Exist: To be as a fact and not as a mode; to have an actual or real being, whether material or spiritual.
Emergency: Sudden or unexpected appearance; an unforeseen occurrence; a sudden occasion.
Emulatory: Pertaining to emulation; connected with rivalry.
Emboil: To cause to boil with anger; to irritate; to chafe.
Ecclesiastical: Of or pertaining to the church; relating to the organization or government of the church; not secular; as, ecclesiastical affairs or history; ecclesiastical courts.
Edgeshot: Having an edge planed, -- said of a board.
Electrolyzable: Capable of being electrolyzed, or decomposed by electricity.
Electro-vitalism: The theory that the functions of living organisms are dependent upon electricity or a kindred force.
Emergence: The act of rising out of a fluid, or coming forth from envelopment or concealment, or of rising into view; sudden uprisal or appearance.
Entomere: The more granular cells, which finally become internal, in many segmenting ova, as those of mammals.
Extrinsic: Not contained in or belonging to a body; external; outward; unessential; -- opposed to intrinsic.
Encyclopedism: The art of writing or compiling encyclopedias; also, possession of the whole range of knowledge; encyclopedic learning.
Exoneration: The act of disburdening, discharging, or freeing morally from a charge or imputation; also, the state of being disburdened or freed from a charge.
Erinaceus: the type genus of the family Erinaceidae, composed of hedgehogs.
Equisonant: Of the same or like sound.
escape wheel: The rotating wheel in an escapement mechanism which has notches that are periodically engaged and disengaged by the anchor.
Ecclesiastically: In an ecclesiastical manner; according ecclesiastical rules.
Endurer: One who, or that which, endures or lasts; one who bears, suffers, or sustains.
Extra-: A Latin preposition, denoting beyond, outside of; -- often used in composition as a prefix signifying outside of, beyond, besides, or in addition to what is denoted by the word to which it is prefixed.
Enrage: To fill with rage; to provoke to frenzy or madness; to make furious.
Estimableness: The quality of deserving esteem or regard.
Epiphragm: A membranaceous or calcareous septum with which some mollusks close the aperture of the shell during the time of hibernation, or estivation.
Ectocuneriform: One of the bones of the tarsus. See Cuneiform.
Equalitarian: One who believes in equalizing the condition of men; a leveler.
Eparch: In ancient Greece, the governor or perfect of a province; in modern Greece, the ruler of an eparchy.
environmental: of or pertaining to the environment; as, environmental factors.
Entourage: Surroundings; specif., collectively, one's attendants or associates.
entrench: To surround with a trench or with intrenchments, as in fortification; to fortify with a ditch and parapet. Same as intrench.
Ephod: A part of the sacerdotal habit among Jews, being a covering for the back and breast, held together on the shoulders by two clasps or brooches of onyx stones set in gold, and fastened by a girdle of the same stuff as the ephod. The ephod for the priests was of plain linen; that for the high priest was richly embroidered in colors. The breastplate of the high priest was worn upon the ephod in front.
Esemplastic: Shaped into one; tending to, or formative into, unity.
Earwitness: A witness by means of his ears; one who is within hearing and does hear; a hearer.
Excavate: To hollow out; to form cavity or hole in; to make hollow by cutting, scooping, or digging; as, to excavate a ball; to excavate the earth.
easterner: an inhabitant of an eastern area; especially of the eastern U. S.
Entrails: The internal parts of animal bodies; the bowels; the guts; viscera; intestines.
\u00c6mail ombrant: An art or process of flooding transparent colored glaze over designs stamped or molded on earthenware or porcelain.
Ellwand: Formerly, a measuring rod an ell long.
Entheal: Divinely inspired; wrought up to enthusiasm.
Endoskeletal: Pertaining to, or connected with, the endoskeleton; as, endoskeletal muscles.
Extremist: A supporter of extreme doctrines or practice; one who holds extreme opinions.
Electro-bioscopy: A method of determining the presence or absence of life in an animal organism with a current of electricity, by noting the presence or absence of muscular contraction.
Epiphyseal: Pertaining to, or having the nature of, an epiphysis.
Engrailment: The ring of dots round the edge of a medal, etc.
escarole: a variety of endive (Cichorium endivia) often used in salads, having leaves with irregular frilled edges.
Excursus: A dissertation or digression appended to a work, and containing a more extended exposition of some important point or topic.
Epistle: To write; to communicate in a letter or by writing.
Extirpation: The act of extirpating or rooting out, or the state of being extirpated; eradication; excision; total destruction; as, the extirpation of weeds from land, of evil from the heart, of a race of men, of heresy.
Endochondral: Growing or developing within cartilage; -- applied esp. to developing bone.
Eidolon: An image or representation; a form; a phantom; an apparition.
Enjoyment: The condition of enjoying anything; pleasure or satisfaction, as in the possession or occupancy of anything; possession and use; as, the enjoyment of an estate.
ethyl alcohol: the organic compound C2H5.OH, which is the intoxicating agent in beer, wine, and other fermented and distilled liquors; it is used pure or denatured as a solvent or in medicines and colognes and cleaning solutions and rocket fuel.
Efflorescence: Flowering, or state of flowering; the blooming of flowers; blowth.
Enfleurage: A process of extracting perfumes by exposing absorbents, as fixed oils or fats, to the exhalations of the flowers. It is used for plants whose volatile oils are too delicate to be separated by distillation.
Ermine: To clothe with, or as with, ermine.
Entoil: To take with toils or bring into toils; to insnare.
Enforcive: Serving to enforce or constrain; compulsive.
Ensearch: To make search; to try to find something.
Echidna: A monster, half maid and half serpent.
Encloister: To shut up in a cloister; to cloister.
Efflorescency: The state or quality of being efflorescent; efflorescence.
Expone: To expound; to explain; also, to expose; to imperil.
electronics: the branch of physics that deals with the behavior of electrons.  Electronics is primarily concerned with phenomena other than simple conduction, such as emission of electrons, storage of electrical charge, the effects of electrical fields on the conduction of electrons through a circuit, and amplification and manipulation of electric signals such as voltage or current by design of circuits.  Electronics also encompasses the application of such fundamental principles to the construction of devices using the manipulation of electrons in their operation, known as electronic devices.
extricated: freed from an entanglement or difficulty.
Elaborative: Serving or tending to elaborate; constructing with labor and minute attention to details.
Engle: To cajole or coax, as favorite.
Electro-kinetics: That branch of electrical science which treats of electricity in motion.
Exhibiter: One who exhibits; one who presents a petition, charge or bill.
Eariness: Fear or timidity, especially of something supernatural.
Excerption: The act of excerpting or selecting.
Erbium: A rare earth element of the lanthanide series associated with several other rare elements in the mineral gadolinite from Ytterby in Sweden. Symbol Er.  It has atomic number 68 and an atomic weight of 167.26.  The pure element is metallic with a bright, silvery luster. It is relatively stable in air, not oxidizing as quickly as some other rare earths.  Its salts are rose-colored and give characteristic spectra, and the pink oxide has been added as a colorant in glass and porcelain enamel glazes. Its sesquioxide Er2O3 is called erbia.
Emery: Corundum in the form of grains or powder, used in the arts for grinding and polishing hard substances. Native emery is mixed with more or less magnetic iron. See the Note under Corundum.
Electorate: The territory, jurisdiction, or dignity of an elector, as in the old German empire.
Eyasmusket: An unfledged or young male sparrow hawk.
Enflower: To cover or deck with flowers.
Expense: A spending or consuming; disbursement; expenditure.
eyebrow pencil: a cosmetic pencil-like device used to apply a tint to the eyebrows, or darken lighter areas on the eyebrows.  It is sometimes used to create a “beauty mark” on the face.
Enterobacteriaceae: a natural family of rod-shaped gram-negative bacteria, most of which occur normally or pathogenically in intestines of humans and other animals, and some of which grow in plants.  The type genus is Escherichia.  They are aerobic and facultatively anaerobic, and may be motile or non-motile.  Most are easily cultured on artificial growth media.  Both pathogenic and non-pathogenic strains exist.
Ensilage: To preserve in a silo; as, to ensilage cornstalks.
Eddaic: Relating to the Eddas; resembling the Eddas.
\u00c9crasement: The operation performed with an écraseur.
Exciple: The outer part of the fructification of most lichens.
Earthward: Toward the earth; -- opposed to heavenward or skyward.
Endowment: The act of bestowing a dower, fund, or permanent provision for support.
Extersion: The act of wiping or rubbing out.
Elaidic: Relating to oleic acid, or elaine.
Entailment: The act of entailing or of giving, as an estate, and directing the mode of descent.
Espouse: To betroth; to promise in marriage; to give as spouse.
Ellipsoid: Pertaining to, or shaped like, an ellipsoid; as, ellipsoid or ellipsoidal form.
Enstamp: To stamp; to mark as with a stamp; to impress deeply.
eightsome: eight people considered as a unit; as, there was an eightsome ahead of us on the golf course.
Elaidin: A solid isomeric modification of olein.
Epistolean: One who writes epistles; a correspondent.
embarrassed: feeling uneasily or unpleasantly self-conscious due to some event or circumstance; as, she was embarrassed by her child's tantrums.
Enpatron: To act the part of a patron towards; to patronize.
Expeditionist: One who goes upon an expedition. [R].
Ethyl: A monatomic, hydrocarbon radical, C2H5 of the paraffin series, forming the essential radical of ethane, and of common alcohol and ether.
Eschscholtzia: A genus of papaveraceous plants, found in California and upon the west coast of North America, some species of which produce beautiful yellow, orange, rose-colored, or white flowers; the California poppy.
Exercise: To exercise one's self, as under military training; to drill; to take exercise; to use action or exertion; to practice gymnastics; as, to exercise for health or amusement.
earth-colored: having the color of soil or earth; reddish or reddish-brown.
Eastern: Situated or dwelling in the east; oriental; as, an eastern gate; Eastern countries.
Euchlorine: A yellow or greenish yellow gas, first prepared by Davy, evolved from potassium chlorate and hydrochloric acid. It is supposed to consist of chlorine tetroxide with some free chlorine.
Equitation: A riding, or the act of riding, on horseback; horsemanship.
Eviscerate: To take out the entrails of; to disembowel; to gut.
Earnest: Something given, or a part paid beforehand, as a pledge; pledge; handsel; a token of what is to come.
Emblematic: Pertaining to, containing, or consisting in, an emblem; symbolic; typically representative; representing as an emblem; as, emblematic language or ornaments; a crown is emblematic of royalty; white is emblematic of purity.
Entozoal: Pertaining to, or consisting of, the Entozoa.
Episternal: Of or pertaining to the episternum.
Exception: The act of excepting or excluding; exclusion; restriction by taking out something which would otherwise be included, as in a class, statement, rule.
Envolume: To form into, or incorporate with, a volume.
electronic device: a device depending on the principles of electronics and using the manipulation of electron flow for its operation.
Eclampsia: A fancied perception of flashes of light, a symptom of epilepsy; hence, epilepsy itself; convulsions.
Elocular: Having but one cell, or cavity; not divided by a septum or partition.
Electrometry: The art or process of making electrical measurements.
Exploitation: The act of exploiting or utilizing.
emasculated: having the testicles removed; -- of a male animal.
Educationist: One who is versed in the theories of, or who advocates and promotes, education.
Electro-dynamics: The phenomena of electricity in motion.
Engorged: Swallowed with greediness, or in large draughts.
Existent: Having being or existence; existing; being; occurring now; taking place.
Explainable: Capable of being explained or made plain to the understanding; capable of being interpreted.
Encollar: To furnish or surround with a collar.
Entasia: Tonic spasm; -- applied generically to denote any disease characterized by tonic spasms, as tetanus, trismus, etc.
Execution: The act of executing; a carrying into effect or to completion; performance; achievement; consummation; as, the execution of a plan, a work, etc.
Enlarger: One who or that which enlarges.
Extra-ocular: Inserted exterior to the eyes; -- said of the antennæ of certain insects.
Executrix: A woman exercising the functions of an executor.
Epithetic: Pertaining to, or abounding with, epithets.
El Dorado: A name given by the Spaniards in the 16th century to an imaginary country in the interior of South America, reputed to abound in gold and precious stones.
exterminable: capable of being totally destroyed or wiped out.
Edition: A literary work edited and published, as by a certain editor or in a certain manner; as, a good edition of Chaucer; Chalmers' edition of Shakespeare.
Enlarged: Made large or larger; extended; swollen.
Excrete: To separate and throw off; to excrete urine.
Epitaph: To write or speak after the manner of an epitaph.
Embryonal: Pertaining to an embryo, or the initial state of any organ; embryonic.
Emphasize: To utter or pronounce with a particular stress of voice; to make emphatic; as, to emphasize a word or a phrase.
Executable: Capable of being executed; feasible; as, an executable project.
Exspuition: A discharge of saliva by spitting.
Evaporative: Pertaining to, or producing, evaporation; as, the evaporative process.
Electrographic: Of or pertaining to an electrograph or electrography.
Eschevin: The alderman or chief officer of an ancient guild.
English-weed: a South African bulbous wood sorrel (Oxalis cernua) with showy yellow flowers.
Enface: To write or print on the face of (a draft, bill, etc.); as, to enface drafts with memoranda.
\u00c9tude: A composition in the fine arts which is intended, or may serve, for a study.
Endiaper: To decorate with a diaper pattern.
Erinaceidae: a natural family including the true hedgehogs.
Edenic: Of or pertaining to Eden; paradisaic.
Esoteric: An esoteric doctrine or treatise; esoteric philosophy; esoterics.
Epistolography: The art or practice of writing epistles.
Extensile: Suited for, or capable of, extension; extensible.
Effluxion: The act of flowing out; effusion.
effusiveness: a friendly open trait of a talkative person; enthusiasm exhibited with little restraint.
Epanadiplosis: A figure by which the same word is used both at the beginning and at the end of a sentence; as, “Rejoice in the Lord always: and again I say, Rejoice.”
Ethylin: Any one of the several complex ethers of ethyl and glycerin.
Earthstar: A curious fungus of the genus Geaster, in which the outer coating splits into the shape of a star, and the inner one forms a ball containing the dustlike spores.
Exemption: The act of exempting; the state of being exempt; freedom from any charge, burden, evil, etc., to which others are subject; immunity; privilege; as, exemption of certain articles from seizure; exemption from military service; exemption from anxiety, suffering, etc.
Engulfment: A swallowing up as if in a gulf.
Ectrotic: Having a tendency to prevent the development of anything, especially of a disease.
Engouled: Partly swallowed; disappearing in the jaws of anything; as, an infant engouled by a serpent; said also of an ordinary, when its two ends to issue from the mouths of lions, or the like; as, a bend engouled.
Embo\u00eetement: The hypothesis that all living things proceed from preëxisting germs, and that these encase the germs of all future living things, inclosed one within another.
Essentially: In an essential manner or degree; in an indispensable degree; really; as, essentially different.
Ekabor: The name given by Mendelejeff in accordance with the periodic law, and by prediction, to a hypothetical element then unknown, but since discovered and named scandium; -- so called because it was a missing analogue of the boron group. See Scandium.
Embankment: The act of surrounding or defending with a bank.
Enter: To go or come in; -- often with in used pleonastically; also, to begin; to take the first steps.
Electrotyping: The act or the process of making electrotypes.
Exquisitive: Eager to discover or learn; curious.
expired: having come to an end or become void after passage of a period of time; as, an expired passport; caught driving with an expired license.  Opposite of unexpired.
Esperanto: An artificial language, intended to be universal, devised by Dr. Zamenhof, a Russian, who adopted the pseudonym “Dr. Esperanto” in publishing his first pamphlet regarding it in 1887. The vocabulary is very largely based upon words common to the chief European languages, and sounds peculiar to any one language are eliminated. The spelling is phonetic, and the accent (stress) is always on the penult.  A revised and simplified form, called Ido was developed in 1907, but Esperanto remained at the end of the 20th century the most popular aritficial language designed for normal human linguistic communication.
Equalizer: One who, or that which, equalizes anything.
Exceed: To go too far; to pass the proper bounds or measure.
Eremitism: The state of a hermit; a living in seclusion from social life.
Emblemize: To represent by an emblem; to emblematize.
Expropriation: The act of expropriating; the surrender of a claim to exclusive property; the act of depriving of ownership or proprietary rights.
Elementariness: The state of being elementary; original simplicity; uncompounded state.
Enfeeble: To make feeble; to deprive of strength; to reduce the strength or force of; to weaken; to debilitate.
Eccaleobion: A contrivance for hatching eggs by artificial heat.
Export: The act of exporting; exportation; as, to prohibit the export of wheat or tobacco.
Explorator: One who explores; one who examines closely; a searcher.
Eubryales: an order of mosses with perennial erect gametophores and stems with rows of leaves and drooping capsules.
Essayist: A writer of an essay, or of essays.
Earwig: To influence, or attempt to influence, by whispered insinuations or private talk.
Eucopepoda: A group which includes the typical copepods and the lerneans.
Extrajudicial: Out of or beyond the power authority of a court or judge; beyond jurisdiction; not valid as a part of a judicial proceeding; as, extrajudicial oaths, judgments, etc., are null and void.
Engarboil: To throw into disorder; to disturb.
Excitatory: Tending to excite; containing excitement; excitative.
Ethereality: The state of being ethereal; etherealness.
Engrailed: Indented with small concave curves, as the edge of a bordure, bend, or the like.
Easiness: The state or condition of being easy; freedom from distress; rest.
Encalendar: To register in a calendar; to calendar.
Entoglossal: Within the tongue; -- applied to the glossohyal bone.
Exanimation: Deprivation of life or of spirits.
Enterography: A treatise upon, or description of, the intestines; enterology.
earned: Gained as a result of effort or action; -- used especially of income; as, earned income.  Contrasted with unearned.
endogamic: fertilized by pollen from another flower of the same plant.
Educative: Tending to educate; that gives education; as, an educative process; an educative experience.
Egranulose: Having no granules, as chlorophyll in certain conditions.
Excursion: A running or going out or forth; an expedition; a sally.
Exauthoration: Deprivation of authority or dignity; degration.
earner: someone who earns wages in return for labor.
euphoric: strongly experiencing a feeling of well-being; feeling euphoria.  Opposite of dysphoric.
Encoubert: One of several species of armadillos of the genera Dasypus and Euphractus, having five toes both on the fore and hind feet.
Elixir: A tincture with more than one base; a compound tincture or medicine, composed of various substances, held in solution by alcohol in some form.
Elimination: The act of expelling or throwing off
emitting: giving off light or heat or radiation; as, the physical temperature of the emitting material.
Excito-secretory: Exciting secretion; -- said of the influence exerted by reflex action on the function of secretion, by which the various glands are excited to action.
Elocutionist: One who is versed in elocution; a teacher of elocution.
Earshrift: A nickname for auricular confession; shrift.
Embroider: To ornament with needlework; as, to embroider a scarf.
Expilation: The act of expilating or stripping off; plunder; pillage.
Epanody: The abnormal change of an irregular flower to a regular form; -- considered by evolutionists to be a reversion to an ancestral condition.
Eglomerate: To unwind, as a thread from a ball.
Exclave: A portion of a country which is separated from the main part and surrounded by politically alien territory.
Emirship: The rank or office of an Emir.
Electrifiable: Capable of receiving electricity, or of being charged with it.
Epiphysis: The end, or other superficial part, of a bone, which ossifies separately from the central portion, or diaphysis.
econometrician: an economist who uses statistical and mathematical methods.
Epidote: A mineral, commonly of a yellowish green (pistachio) color, occurring granular, massive, columnar, and in monoclinic crystals. It is a silicate of alumina, lime, and oxide of iron, or manganese.
enlisting: the act of getting recruits; convincing people to join the army, take a job, support a cause etc.
Evermore: During eternity; always; forever; for an indefinite period; at all times; -- often used substantively with for.
eyebrow: The brow or hairy arch above the eye.
Eclaircissement: The clearing up of anything which is obscure or not easily understood; an explanation.
Epibranchial: Pertaining to the segment between the ceratobranchial and pharyngobranchial in a branchial arch.
Excrescence: An excrescent appendage, as, a wart or tumor; anything growing out unnaturally from anything else; a preternatural or morbid development; hence, a troublesome superfluity; an incumbrance; as, an excrescence on the body, or on a plant.
ear-shaped: having the shape of an ear.
editorialize: to write an opinion in an editorial in a publication.
econometric: of or pertaining to econometrics; as, econometric theories.
Envisage: To look in the face of; to apprehend; to regard.
Engarland: To encircle with a garland, or with garlands.
-ed: The termination of the past participle of regular, or weak, verbs; also, of analogous participial adjectives from nouns; as, pigmented; talented.
Emperorship: The rank or office of an emperor.
Euharmonic: Producing mathematically perfect harmony or concord; sweetly or perfectly harmonious.
-en: A suffix from AS. -an, formerly used to form the plural of many nouns, as in ashen, eyen, oxen, all obs. except oxen. In some cases, such as children and brethren, it has been added to older plural forms.
Exclusionary: Tending to exclude; causing exclusion; exclusive.
Errand: A special business intrusted to a messenger; something to be told or done by one sent somewhere for the purpose; often, a verbal message; a commission; as, the servant was sent on an errand; to do an errand. Also, one's purpose in going anywhere.
Equableness: Quality or state of being equable.
Explicitly: In an explicit manner; clearly; plainly; without disguise or reservation of meaning; not by inference or implication; as, he explicitly avows his intention.
Entermewer: A hawk gradually changing the color of its feathers, commonly in the second year.
Enrockment: A mass of large stones thrown into water at random to form bases of piers, breakwaters, etc.
ex-officio: by virtue of an office or position.
Exacerbescence: Increase of irritation or violence, particularly the increase of a fever or disease.
Eudiometer: An instrument for the volumetric measurement of gases; -- so named because frequently used to determine the purity of the air.
Epihyal: A segment next above the ceratohyal in the hyoidean arch.
Exclamation: A loud calling or crying out; outcry; loud or emphatic utterance; vehement vociferation; clamor; that which is cried out, as an expression of feeling; sudden expression of sound or words indicative of emotion, as in surprise, pain, grief, joy, anger, etc.
Epulary: Of or pertaining to a feast or banquet.
Elasipoda: An order of holothurians mostly found in the deep sea. They are remarkable for their bilateral symmetry and curious forms.
Endoderm: The inner layer of the skin or integument of an animal.
Endothelium: The thin epithelium lining the blood vessels, lymphatics, and serous cavities. See Epithelium.
eyepatch: a protective covering, usually made of cloth, for an injured eye.
Estoppel: A stop; an obstruction or bar to one's alleging or denying a fact contrary to his own previous action, allegation, or denial; an admission, by words or conduct, which induces another to purchase rights, against which the party making such admission can not take a position inconsistent with the admission.
Eroteme: A mark indicating a question; a note of interrogation.
Euthyneura: A large division of gastropod molluske, including the Pulmonifera and Opisthobranchiata.
Epigastric: Pertaining to the epigastrium, or to the epigastric region.
Exostome: The small aperture or foremen in the outer coat of the ovule of a plant.
Emaculate: To clear from spots or stains, or from any imperfection.
Expeditionary: Of or pertaining to an expedition; as, an expeditionary force.
Equalization: The act of equalizing, or state of being equalized.
efficience: The quality of being efficient or producing an effect or effects; efficient power; effectual agency.
Enisled: Placed alone or apart, as if on an island; severed, as an island.
Epipodiale: One of the bones of either the forearm or shank, the epipodialia being the radius, ulna, tibia, and fibula.
Excerebration: The act of removing or beating out the brains.
Elytron: One of the anterior pair of wings in the Coleoptera and some other insects, when they are thick and serve only as a protection for the posterior pair.
Exclude: To shut out; to hinder from entrance or admission; to debar from participation or enjoyment; to deprive of; to except; -- the opposite to admit; as, to exclude a crowd from a room or house; to exclude the light; to exclude one nation from the ports of another; to exclude a taxpayer from the privilege of voting.
Epigraph: Any inscription set upon a building; especially, one which has to do with the building itself, its founding or dedication.
Emmetropic: Pertaining to, or characterized by, emmetropia.
Entirely: In an entire manner; wholly; completely; fully; as, the trace is entirely lost.
Emmetropia: That refractive condition of the eye in which the rays of light are all brought accurately and without undue effort to a focus upon the retina; -- opposed to hypermetropia, myopia, and astigmatism.
Elsewhere: In any other place; as, these trees are not to be found elsewhere.
Emotion: A moving of the mind or soul; excitement of the feelings, whether pleasing or painful; disturbance or agitation of mind caused by a specific exciting cause and manifested by some sensible effect on the body.
Emblematiccize: To render emblematic; as, to emblematicize a picture.
eucaryotic: of or pertaining to eukaryotes; same as eukaryotic.  Contrasted with prokaryotic.
Ebb tide: The reflux of tide water; the retiring tide; -- opposed to flood tide.
Effluviable: Capable of being given off as an effluvium.
Edgeways: With the edge towards anything; in the direction of the edge.
Elevate: To bring from a lower place to a higher; to lift up; to raise; as, to elevate a weight, a flagstaff, etc.
Estimator: One who estimates or values; a valuer.
Epaulement: A side work, made of gabions, fascines, or bags, filled with earth, or of earth heaped up, to afford cover from the flanking fire of an enemy.
Exogenetic: Arising or growing from without; exogenous.
Ensiform: Having the form of a sword blade; sword-shaped; as, an ensiform leaf.
Erignathus: a genus including the bearded seal, Erignathus barbatus.
Extinguisher: One who, or that which, extinguishes; esp., a hollow cone or other device for extinguishing a flame, as of a torch or candle.
Echinodermal: Relating or belonging to the echinoderms.
Egg-glass: A small sandglass, running about three minutes, for marking time in boiling eggs; also, a small glass for holding an egg, at table.
Enslave: To reduce to slavery; to make a slave of; to subject to a dominant influence.
Expeditious: Possessed of, or characterized by, expedition, or efficiency and rapidity in action; performed with, or acting with, expedition; quick; having celerity; speedily; as, an expeditious march or messenger.
Endopodite: The internal or principal branch of the locomotive appendages of Crustacea. See Maxilliped.
Echinodermata: One of the grand divisions of the animal kingdom. By many writers it was formerly included in the Radiata.
Elevation: The act of raising from a lower place, condition, or quality to a higher; -- said of material things, persons, the mind, the voice, etc.; as, the elevation of grain; elevation to a throne; elevation of mind, thoughts, or character.
Edifying: Instructing; improving; as, an edifying conversation.
Expos\u00e9: A formal recital or exposition of facts; exposure, or revelation, of something which some one wished to keep concealed.
\u00c9pergne: A centerpiece for table decoration, usually consisting of several dishes or receptacles of different sizes grouped together in an ornamental design.
Exactness: The condition of being exact; accuracy; nicety; precision; regularity; as, exactness of judgement or deportment.
Epagoge: The adducing of particular examples so as to lead to a universal conclusion; the argument by induction.
Emmantle: To cover over with, or as with, a mantle; to put about as a protection.
Erythrosin: A red substance formed by the oxidation of tyrosin.
Eruct: To eject, as wind, from the stomach; to belch.
eye-lotion: a solution used as a cleanser for the eyes.
Ergal: Potential energy; negative value of the force function.
eye dropper: a small dropping tube for delivering drops of a liquid; same as dropper{2}.
Expeller: One who, or that which, expels.
Eduction: The act of drawing out or bringing into view.
Ecbatic: Denoting a mere result or consequence, as distinguished from telic, which denotes intention or purpose; thus the phrase "i`na plhrw`qh, if rendered “so that it was fulfilled,” is ecbatic; if rendered “in order that it might be.” etc., is telic.
Epiphany: An appearance, or a becoming manifest.
Excrescent: Growing out in an abnormal or morbid manner or as a superfluity.
exogenous: derived from or originating outside; pertaining to, or having the character of, an exogen; -- the opposite of endogenous.
Exercisible: Capable of being exercised, employed, or enforced; as, the authority of a magistrate is exercisible within his jurisdiction.
Ellachick: A fresh-water tortoise (Chelopus marmoratus) of California; -- used as food.
Endochrome: The coloring matter within the cells of plants, whether green, red, yellow, or any other color.
Enunciative: Pertaining to, or containing, enunciation; declarative.
Expirant: One who expires or is expiring.
Enterprising: Having a disposition for enterprise; characterized by enterprise; resolute, active or prompt to attempt; as, an enterprising man or firm.
Elderly: Somewhat old; advanced beyond middle age; bordering on old age; as, elderly people.
Eyewater: A wash or lotion for application to the eyes.
Electro-telegraphy: The art or science of constructing or using the electric telegraph; the transmission of messages by means of the electric telegraph.
Eleventh: The quotient of a unit divided by eleven; one of eleven equal parts.
economiser: a person who economizes and avoids waste.
Ensate: Having sword-shaped leaves, or appendages; ensiform.
eastbound: moving toward the east; as, eastbound trains.
eyeliner: a cosmetic powder of a dark tint, applied to the eyelid close to the base of the eyelashes to accentuate the eyes.  Compare eye shadow.
expended: nonexistent or unavailable as a consequence of use or exchange.
eyecup: A small oval porcelain or glass cup, having a rim curved to fit the orbit of the eye. it is used in the application of liquid remedies to eyes; -- called also eyeglass.
