Eros: Love; the god of love; -- by earlier writers represented as one of the first and creative gods, by later writers as the son of Aphrodite, equivalent to the Latin god Cupid.
Elapidae: a natural family of snakes including the cobras, kraits, mambas, the New World coral snakes, and Australian taipan and tiger snakes.
Exclusionist: One who would exclude another from some right or privilege; esp., one of the anti-popish politicians of the time of Charles II.
Elliptic: Of or pertaining to an ellipse; having the form of an ellipse; oblong, with rounded ends.
earthball: any of various fungi of the genus Scleroderma having hard-skinned subterranean trufflelike fruiting bodies.
Engagement: The act of engaging, pledging, enlisting, occupying, or entering into contest.
Execute: To do one's work; to act one's part or purpose.
Epididymis: An oblong vermiform mass on the dorsal side of the testicle, composed of numerous convolutions of the excretory duct of that organ.
emancipating: permitting or conducive to the reduction of restraints on behavior.
Easterly: Toward, or in the direction of, the east.
Efflorescent: That effloresces, or is liable to effloresce on exposure; as, an efflorescent salt.
Egest: To cast or throw out; to void, as excrement; to excrete, as the indigestible matter of the food; in an extended sense, to excrete by the lungs, skin, or kidneys.
Enfiled: Having some object, as the head of a man or beast, impaled upon it; as, a sword which is said to be “enfiled of” the thing which it pierces.
Emerited: Considered as having done sufficient public service, and therefore honorably discharged.
Eccentric: A circle not having the same center as another contained in some measure within the first.
Earl marshal: An officer of state in England who marshals and orders all great ceremonials, takes cognizance of matters relating to honor, arms, and pedigree, and directs the proclamation of peace and war. The court of chivalry was formerly under his jurisdiction, and he is still the head of the herald's office or college of arms.
Evaginate: To become evaginate; to cause to be evaginate.
Earthliness: The quality or state of being earthly; worldliness; grossness; perishableness.
Expose: To set forth; to set out to public view; to exhibit; to show; to display; as, to expose goods for sale; to expose pictures to public inspection.
Exfoliative: Having the power of causing exfoliation.
Erudiate: To instruct; to educate; to teach.
Excerptor: One who makes excerpts; a picker; a culler.
Endostosis: A process of bone formation in which ossification takes place within the substance of the cartilage.
Enactive: Having power to enact or establish as a law.
Electro-metallurgy: The act or art precipitating a metal electro-chemical action, by which a coating is deposited, on a prepared surface, as in electroplating and electrotyping; galvanoplasty.
Eglantine: A species of rose (Rosa Eglanteria), with fragrant foliage and flowers of various colors.
Endemiology: The science which treats of endemic affections.
Extancy: The state of rising above others; a projection.
Endoneurium: The delicate bands of connective tissue among nerve fibers.
\u00c9cart\u00e9: A game at cards for two persons, with 32 cards, ranking K, Q, J, A, 10, 9, 8, 7. Five cards are dealt each player, and the 11th turned as trump. Five points constitute a game.
Epistyle: A massive piece of stone or wood laid immediately on the abacus of the capital of a column or pillar; -- now called architrave.
Eaves: The edges or lower borders of the roof of a building, which overhang the walls, and cast off the water that falls on the roof.
Eleidin: Lifeless matter deposited in the form of minute granules within the protoplasm of living cells.
Ethnarchy: The dominion of an ethnarch; principality and rule.
Ephoralty: The office of an ephor, or the body of ephors.
Entozoa: A group of worms, including the tapeworms, flukes, roundworms, etc., most of which live parasitically in the interior of other animals; the Helminthes.
Elohistic: Relating to Elohim as a name of God; -- said of passages in the Old Testament.
Euphemism: A figure in which a harsh or indelicate word or expression is softened; a way of describing an offensive thing by an inoffensive expression; a mild name for something disagreeable.
Embitterment: The act of embittering; also, that which embitters.
Eragrostis: a genus of annual or perennial grasses of tropics and subtropics.
Emergent: Rising or emerging out of a fluid or anything that covers or conceals; issuing; coming to light.
Extricate: To free, as from difficulties or perplexities; to disentangle; to disembarrass; as, to extricate a person from debt, peril, etc.
Exploit: A deed or act; especially, a heroic act; a deed of renown; an adventurous or noble achievement; as, the exploits of Alexander the Great.
Enthetic: Caused by a pathogenic organism implanted in the system; as, an enthetic disease like syphilis.
Euphoniad: An instrument in which are combined the characteristic tones of the organ and various other instruments.
Expressive: Serving to express, utter, or represent; indicative; communicative; -- followed by of; as, words expressive of his gratitude.
Extol: To place on high; to lift up; to elevate.
Emunctory: Any organ or part of the body (as the kidneys, skin, etc.,) which serves to carry off excrementitious or waste matter.
Eider: Any species of sea duck of the genus Somateria, esp. Somateria mollissima, which breeds in the northern parts of Europe and America, and lines its nest with fine down (taken from its own body) which is an article of commerce; -- called also eider duck. The American eider (S. Dresseri), the king eider (S. spectabilis), and the spectacled eider (Arctonetta Fischeri) are related species.
Euphemistic: Pertaining to euphemism; containing a euphemism; softened in expression.
Eupione: A limpid, oily liquid obtained by the destructive distillation of various vegetable and animal substances; -- specifically, an oil consisting largely of the higher hydrocarbons of the paraffin series.
Eupn\u00e6a: Normal breathing where arterialization of the blood is normal, in distinction from dyspnæa, in which the blood is insufficiently arterialized.
Eugubian: Of or pertaining to the ancient town of Eugubium (now Gubbio); as, the Eugubine tablets, or tables, or inscriptions.
Endaspidean: Having the anterior scutes extending around the tarsus on the inner side; -- said of certain birds.
Encystment: A process which, among some of the lower forms of life, precedes reproduction by budding, fission, spore formation, etc.
Essentiality: The quality of being essential; the essential part.
Enubilate: To clear from mist, clouds, or obscurity.
Enhydros: A variety of chalcedony containing water.
Eponymous: Relating to an eponym; giving one's name to a tribe, people, country, and the like.
Enchafe: To chafe; to enrage; to heat.
Elanet: A kite of the genus Elanus.
Exaugurate: To annul the consecration of; to secularize; to unhellow.
Emetical: Inducing to vomit; producing vomiting; emetic.
Epilogue: A speech or short poem addressed to the spectators and recited by one of the actors, after the conclusion of the play.
Electroscopic: Relating to, or made by means of, the electroscope.
enterobacteria: rod-shaped gram-negative bacteria of the family Enterobacteriaceae; most occur normally or pathogenically in intestines of humans and other animals; some, such as those of the genus Erwinia, are found in plants.
Exposure: The act of exposing or laying open, setting forth, laying bare of protection, depriving of care or concealment, or setting out to reprobation or contempt.
Electrolysis: The act or process of chemical decomposition, by the action of electricity; as, the electrolysis of silver or nickel for plating; the electrolysis of water.
Exponential: Pertaining to exponents; involving variable exponents; as, an exponential expression; exponential calculus; an exponential function.
Ericinol: A colorless oil (quickly becoming brown), with a pleasant odor, obtained by the decomposition of ericolin.
Entomophaga: a group of hymenopterous insects whose larvæ feed parasitically upon living insects. See Ichneumon, 2.
Economize: To be prudently sparing in expenditure; to be frugal and saving; as, to economize in order to grow rich.
Eschynite: A rare mineral, containing chiefly niobium, titanium, thorium, and cerium. It was so called by Berzelius on account of the inability of chemical science, at the time of its discovery, to separate some of its constituents.
Epidermic: Epidermal; connected with the skin or the bark.
Estuation: The act of estuating; commotion, as of a fluid; agitation.
Epode: The after song; the part of a lyric ode which follows the strophe and antistrophe, -- the ancient ode being divided into strophe, antistrophe, and epode.
Embryoplastic: Relating to, or aiding in, the formation of an embryo; as, embryoplastic cells.
Escaloped: Cut or marked in the form of an escalop; scalloped.
Epicondyle: A projection on the inner side of the distal end of the humerus; the internal condyle.
Ergotine: A powerful astringent alkaloid extracted from ergot as a brown, amorphous, bitter substance. It is used to produce contraction of the uterus.
Evolutionary: Relating to evolution; as, evolutionary discussions.
Exsiccant: Having the quality of drying up; causing a drying up.
Effigy: The image, likeness, or representation of a person, whether a full figure, or a part; an imitative figure; -- commonly applied to sculptured likenesses, as those on monuments, or to those of the heads of princes on coins and medals, sometimes applied to portraits.
Emargination: The act of notching or indenting the margin, or the state of being so notched; also, a notch or shallow sinus in a margin.
Eyeful: Filling or satisfying the eye; visible; remarkable.
Embowl: To form like a bowl; to give a globular shape to.
Exportability: The quality or state of being suitable for exportation.
Eclaircise: To make clear; to clear up what is obscure or not understood; to explain.
Emacerate: To make lean or to become lean; to emaciate.
Excuseless: Having no excuse; not admitting of excuse or apology.
Exasperation: The act of exasperating or the state of being exasperated; irritation; keen or bitter anger.
Enormity: The state or quality of exceeding a measure or rule, or of being immoderate, monstrous, or outrageous.
Equisonance: An equal sounding; the consonance of the unison and its octaves.
Excerpt: An extract; a passage selected or copied from a book or record.
Expellable: Capable of being expelled or driven out.
Equicrescent: Increasing by equal increments; as, an equicrescent variable.
Epigenesist: One who believes in, or advocates the theory of, epigenesis.
eased: made less severe or intense; mitigated.
Electro-dynamometer: An instrument for measuring the strength of electro-dynamic currents.
Eerie: Serving to inspire fear, esp. a dread of seeing ghosts; wild; weird; as, eerie stories.
Elusory: Tending to elude or deceive; evasive; fraudulent; fallacious; deceitful; deceptive.
Ejaculate: To utter ejaculations; to make short and hasty exclamations.
Excel: To surpass others in good qualities, laudable actions, or acquirements; to be distinguished by superiority; as, to excel in mathematics, or classics.
Elbowboard: The base of a window casing, on which the elbows may rest.
electric current: the movement of electrically charged particles, atoms, or ions, through solids, liquids, gases, or free space; the term is usually used of relatively smooth movements of electric charge through conductors, whether constant or variable.  Sudden movements of charge are usually referred to by other terms, such as spark or lightning or discharge.  In metallic conductors the electric current is usually due to movement of electrons through the metal.  The current is measured as the rate of movement of charge per unit time, and is counted in units of amperes.  As a formal definition, the direction of movement of electric current is considered as the same as the direction of movement of positive charge, or in a direction opposite to the movement of negative charge.  Electric current may move constantly in a single direction, called direct current (abbreviated DC), or may move alternately in one direction and then the opposite direction, called alternating current (abbreviated AC).
electrocutioner: an executioner who uses electricity to kill the condemned person.
Euphorbin: A principle, or mixture of principles, derived from various species of Euphorbia.
Electro-metric: Pertaining to electrometry; made by means of an electrometer; as, an electrometrical experiment.
Emodin: An orange-red crystalline substance, C15H10O5, obtained from the buckthorn, rhubarb, etc., and regarded as a derivative of anthraquinone; -- so called from a species of rhubarb (Rheum emodei).
Editor: One who edits; esp., a person who prepares, superintends, revises, and corrects a book, magazine, or newspaper, etc., for publication.
Entrain: To go aboard a railway train; as, the troops entrained at the station.
Elench: That part of an argument on which its conclusiveness depends; that which convinces of refutes an antagonist; a refutation.
econometrics: the application of mathematics and statistics to the study of economic and financial data.
Euphorbia: Spurge, or bastard spurge, a genus of plants of many species, mostly shrubby, herbaceous succulents, affording an acrid, milky juice. Some of them are armed with thorns. Most of them yield powerful emetic and cathartic products.
echo chamber: A room with walls that resonate sound, producing audible echoes; it is used especially to create special sound effects in recording music.
Educated: Formed or developed by education; as, an educated man.
earth-closet: a small building with a bench having holes through which a user can defecate.
Exesion: The act of eating out or through.
Eugenics: The science of improving stock, whether human or animal.
Enneaspermous: Having nine seeds; -- said of fruits.
Endodermis: A layer of cells forming a kind of cuticle inside of the proper cortical layer, or surrounding an individual fibrovascular bundle.
electroplating: The art or process of depositing a coating (commonly) of silver, gold, or nickel on an inferior metal, by means of an electric current.  The metal to be deposited on an article is usually used as the anode and the article to be plated as the cathode, in an electrolyte solution in which the plating metal is the cation.  The process is conducted in a tank called an electroplating bath, which holds the electrolyte solution.
Eccentricity: The state of being eccentric; deviation from the customary line of conduct; oddity.
Epitrite: A foot consisting of three long syllables and one short syllable.
Eatage: Eatable growth of grass for horses and cattle, esp. that of aftermath.
Extracapsular: Situated outside of a capsule, esp. outside the capsular ligament of a joint.
Esthete: Same as Æsthete, Æsthetic, Æsthetical, Æsthetics, etc.
Eden: The garden where Adam and Eve first dwelt; hence, a delightful region or residence.
Enkerchiefed: Bound with a kerchief; draped; hooded; covered.
Expressly: In an express manner; in direct terms; with distinct purpose; particularly; as, a book written expressly for the young.
Expunction: The act of expunging or erasing; the condition of being expunged.
Echoscope: An instrument for intensifying sounds produced by percussion of the thorax.
Externe: a person affiliated with an institution who does not reside there;
epidemiology: That branch of medicine which studies the incidence and distribution of disease in a population, and uses such information to find the causes, modes of transmission, and methods for control of disease.
Expository: Pertaining to, or containing, exposition; serving to explain; explanatory; illustrative; exegetical.
Energizer: One who, or that which, gives energy, or acts in producing an effect.
Empire State: New York; -- a nickname alluding to its size and wealth.
Equivorous: Feeding on horseflesh; as, equivorous Tartars.
Exult: To be in high spirits; figuratively, to leap for joy; to rejoice in triumph or exceedingly; to triumph; as, an exulting heart.
Excitement: The act of exciting, or the state of being roused into action, or of having increased action; impulsion; agitation; as, an excitement of the people.
Exorbitance: A going out of or beyond the usual or due limit; hence, enormity; extravagance; gross deviation from rule, right, or propriety; as, the exorbitances of the tongue or of deportment; exorbitance of demands.
Expedience: The quality of being expedient or advantageous; fitness or suitableness to effect a purpose intended; adaptedness to self-interest; desirableness; advantage; advisability; -- sometimes contradistinguished from moral rectitude or principle.
Electrical light: the light produced by a current of electricity which in passing through a resisting medium heats it to incandescence or burns it. See under Carbon.
Ecbolic: A drug, as ergot, which by exciting uterine contractions promotes the expulsion of the contents of the uterus.
ecological: of or pertaining to ecology; as, an ecological disaster.
Excito-motor: Excito-motory; as, excito-motor power or causes.
Epicolic: Situated upon or over the colon; -- applied to the region of the abdomen adjacent to the colon.
Eyebar: A bar with an eye at one or both ends.
Engrossment: The act of engrossing; as, the engrossment of a deed.
Emotionalize: To give an emotional character to.
Embiotocidae: a natural family of viviparous percoid fishes comprising the surf fishes.
Ependyma: The epithelial lining of the ventricles of the brain and the canal of the spinal cord; endyma; ependymis.
Entoblast: The inner germ layer; endoderm. See Nucleolus.
Electropathy: The treatment of disease by electricity.
Elasticness: The quality of being elastic; elasticity.
Execration: The act of cursing; a curse dictated by violent feelings of hatred; imprecation; utter detestation expressed.
Earless: Without ears; hence, deaf or unwilling to hear.
Everglade: A swamp or low tract of land inundated with water and interspersed with hummocks, or small islands, and patches of high grass; as, the everglades of Florida.
Endrudge: To make a drudge or slave of.
Engineman: A man who manages, or waits on, an engine.
Embreathement: The act of breathing in; inspiration.
Euphonic: Pertaining to, or exhibiting, euphony; agreeable in sound; pleasing to the ear; euphonious; as, a euphonic expression; euphonical orthography.
Erysimum: a large genus of annual or perennial herbs of the Old World and North America; some are grown for their flowers and some for their attractive evergreen leaves.
erumpent: Breaking out; -- said of certain fungi which burst through the texture of leaves.
Extradition: The surrender or delivery of an alleged criminal by one State or sovereignty to another having jurisdiction to try charge.
Exertion: The act of exerting, or putting into motion or action; the active exercise of any power or faculty; an effort, esp. a laborious or perceptible effort; as, an exertion of strength or power; an exertion of the limbs or of the mind; it is an exertion for him to move, to-day.
Elvish: Pertaining to elves; implike; mischievous; weird; also, vacant; absent in demeanor. See Elfish.
Exploratory: Serving or intended to explore; searching; examining; explorative.
Erective: Making erect or upright; raising; tending to erect.
Ecthoreum: The slender, hollow thread of a nettling cell or cnida. See Nettling cell.
Everich: each one; every one; each of two. See Every.
Explicit: Not implied merely, or conveyed by implication; distinctly stated; plain in language; open to the understanding; clear; not obscure or ambiguous; express; unequivocal; as, an explicit declaration.  Opposite of implicit.
Expletory: Serving to fill up; expletive; superfluous; as, an expletory word.
Etiolate: Having a blanched or faded appearance, as birds inhabiting desert regions.
Excorticate: To strip of bark or skin; to decorticate.
Etna: A kind of small, portable, cooking apparatus for which heat is furnished by a spirit lamp.
Excommunicate: To put out of communion; especially, to cut off, or shut out, from communion with the church, by an ecclesiastical sentence.
Espial: The act of espying; notice; discovery.
Eponymy: The derivation of the name of a race, tribe, etc., from that of a fabulous hero, progenitor, etc.
Euryale: A genus of water lilies, growing in India and China. The only species (Euryale ferox) is very prickly on the peduncles and calyx. The rootstocks and seeds are used as food.
Esplees: The full profits or products which ground or land yields, as the hay of the meadows, the feed of the pasture, the grain of arable fields, the rents, services, and the like.
Eserine: An alkaloid found in the Calabar bean, and the seed of Physostigma venenosum; physostigmine. It is used in ophthalmic surgery for its effect in contracting the pupil.
Eblis: The prince of the evil spirits; Satan.
Except: Unless; if it be not so that.
Excito-motion: Motion excited by reflex nerves. See Excito-motory.
EBCDIC: a 8-bit code for representing alphanumerical information in a digital information storage medium.  It was used expecially on IBM mainframes, and differed substantially from the ASCII code.
Evergreen State: Washington; -- a nickname alluding to the abundance of evergreen trees.
Exarticulation: Luxation; the dislocation of a joint.
Exanthematic: Of, relating to, or characterized by, exanthema; efflorescent; as, an exanthematous eruption.
Evincible: Capable of being proved or clearly brought to light; demonstrable.
Etamine: A light textile fabric, like a fine bunting.
Examiner: One who examines, tries, or inspects; one who interrogates; an officer or person charged with the duty of making an examination; as, an examiner of students for a degree; an examiner in chancery, in the patent office, etc.
Erase: To rub or scrape out, as letters or characters written, engraved, or painted; to efface; to expunge; to cross out; as, to erase a word or a name.
Epitrope: A figure by which permission is either seriously or ironically granted to some one, to do what he proposes to do; e. g., “He that is unjust, let him be unjust still.”
Epsom salts: Sulphate of magnesia having cathartic qualities; -- originally prepared by boiling down the mineral waters at Epsom, England, -- whence the name; afterwards prepared from sea water; but now from certain minerals, as from siliceous hydrate of magnesia.
Epulis: A hard tumor developed from the gums.
Echeneididae: a natural family of fishes having a sucking disk on the head for clinging to other fishes and to ships.
Electro-engraving: The art or process of engraving by means of electricity.
Epiphonema: An exclamatory sentence, or striking reflection, which sums up or concludes a discourse.
extroverted: directed outward; marked by an interest in other people or concerned primarily with external reality.
Ephah: A Hebrew dry measure, supposed to be equal to two pecks and five quarts.  Ten ephahs make one homer.
Engager: One who enters into an engagement or agreement; a surety.
Epictetian: Pertaining to Epictetus, the Roman Stoic philosopher, whose conception of life was to be passionless under whatever circumstances.
Equestrianism: The art of riding on horseback; performance on horseback; horsemanship; as, feats equestrianism.
Emphractic: Having the quality of closing the pores of the skin.
Eleme figs: A kind of figs of superior quality.
Ectolecithal: Having the food yolk, at the commencement of segmentation, in a peripheral position, and the cleavage process confined to the center of the egg; as, ectolecithal ova.
Enormous: Exceeding the usual rule, norm, or measure; out of due proportion; inordinate; abnormal.
Eardrum: The tympanum. See Illust. of Ear.
Epitaphial: Relating to, or of the nature of, an epitaph.
Epistolographic: Pertaining to the writing of letters; used in writing letters; epistolary.
Eugenia: A genus of myrtaceous plants, mostly of tropical countries, and including several aromatic trees and shrubs, among which are the trees which produce allspice and cloves of commerce.
Expiation: The act of making satisfaction or atonement for any crime or fault; the extinguishing of guilt by suffering or penalty.
Eucalyn: An unfermentable sugar, obtained as an uncrystallizable sirup by the decomposition of melitose; also obtained from a Tasmanian eucalyptus, -- whence its name.
Emblem: To represent by an emblem; to symbolize.
Elsewhither: To some, or any, other place; as, you will have to go elsewhither for it.
Eminently: In an eminent manner; in a high degree; conspicuously; as, to be eminently learned.
Exhume: To dig out of the ground; to take out of a place of burial; to disinter.
Else: Besides; except that mentioned; in addition; as, nowhere else; no one else.
Enlargement: The act of increasing in size or bulk, real or apparent; the state of being increased; augmentation; further extension; expansion.
Exchangeable: Capable of being exchanged; fit or proper to be exchanged.
Exterminatory: Of or pertaining to extermination; tending to exterminate.
Exquisitely: In an exquisite manner or degree; as, lace exquisitely wrought.
Excernent: Connected with, or pertaining to, excretion.
Eupatorin Eupatorine: A principle or mixture of principles extracted from various species of Eupatorium.
Endearing: Making dear or beloved; causing love.
Edriophthalma: A group of Crustacea in which the eyes are without stalks; the Arthrostraca.
Engineer: To lay out or construct, as an engineer; to perform the work of an engineer on; as, to engineer a road.
Euchrone: A substance obtained from euchroic acid. See Eychroic.
exploitive: tending to exploit or make use of.
Epulotic: Promoting the skinning over or healing of sores; as, an epulotic ointment.
Etypical: Diverging from, or lacking conformity to, a type.
Enumerate: To count; to tell by numbers; to count over, or tell off one after another; to number; to reckon up; to mention one by one; to name over; to make a special and separate account of; to recount; as, to enumerate the stars in a constellation.
Excruciate: To inflict agonizing pain upon; to torture; to torment greatly; to rack; as, to excruciate the heart or the body.
\u00c9lite: A choice or select body; the flower; as, the élite of society.
Elegit: A judicial writ of execution, by which a defendant's goods are appraised and delivered to the plaintiff, and, if not sufficient to satisfy the debt, all of his lands are delivered, to be held till the debt is paid by the rents and profits, or until the defendant's interest has expired.
Endure: To remain firm under; to sustain; to undergo; to support without breaking or yielding; as, metals endure a certain degree of heat without melting; to endure wind and weather.
Endive: A composite herb (Cichorium Endivia). Its finely divided and much curled leaves, when blanched, are used for salad.
Emu: A large Australian bird, of two species (Dromaius Novæ-Hollandiæ and D. irroratus), related to the cassowary and the ostrich. The emu runs swiftly, but is unable to fly.
Erythric: Pertaining to, derived from, or resembling, erythrin.
Exterminate: To drive out or away; to expel.
Erythrin: A colorless crystalline substance, C20H22O10, extracted from certain lichens, as the various species of Rocella. It is a derivative of orsellinic acid. So called because of certain red compounds derived from it. Called also erythric acid.
Endome: To cover as with a dome.
Erysipelothrix: a genus of non-motile, rod-shaped Gram-positive bacteria of the family Corynebacteriaceae.  They are facultatively anaerobic and produce acid but no gas from glucose.  Members of this genus are parasitic on fish, birds, and mammals, including man.  The type species of the genus, Erysipelothrix rhusiopathiae, causes erysipeloid in man.
Effectual: Producing, or having adequate power or force to produce, an intended effect; adequate; efficient; operative; decisive.
Explainer: One who explains; an expounder or expositor; a commentator; an interpreter.
Endways: On end; erectly; in an upright position.
Epanodos: A figure of speech in which the parts of a sentence or clause are repeated in inverse order
Enlacement: The act of enlacing, or state of being enlaced; a surrounding as with a lace.
Electress: The wife or widow of an elector in the old German empire.
Exoccipital: Pertaining to a bone or region on each side of the great foremen of the skull.
Earthenware: Vessels and other utensils, ornaments, or the like, made of baked clay. See Crockery, Pottery, Stoneware, and Porcelain.
Excogitation: The act of excogitating; a devising in the thoughts; invention; contrivance.
